# text = Al-Zaman : American forces killed Shaikh Abdullah al-Ani, the preacher at the mosque in the town of Qaim, near the Syrian border.
# text = [This killing of a respected cleric will be causing us trouble for years to come.]
# text = DPA: Iraqi authorities announced that they had busted up 3 terrorist cells operating in Baghdad.
# text = Two of them were being run by 2 officials of the Ministry of the Interior!
# text = The MoI in Iraq is equivalent to the US FBI, so this would be like having J. Edgar Hoover unwittingly employ at a high level members of the Weathermen bombers back in the 1960s.
# text = The third was being run by the head of an investment firm.
# text = You wonder if he was manipulating the market with his bombing targets.
# text = The cells were operating in the Ghazaliyah and al-Jihad districts of the capital.
# text = Although the announcement was probably made to show progress in identifying and breaking up terror cells, I don't find the news that the Baathists continue to penetrate the Iraqi government very hopeful.
# text = It reminds me too much of the ARVN officers who were secretly working for the other side in Vietnam.
# text = Al-Zaman : Guerrillas killed a member of the Kurdistan Democratic Party after kidnapping him in Mosul.
# text = The police commander of Ninevah Province announced that bombings had declined 80 percent in Mosul, whereas there had been a big jump in the number of kidnappings.
# text = On Wednesday guerrillas had kidnapped a cosmetic surgeon and his wife while they were on their way home.
# text = In Suwayrah, Kut Province, two car bombs were discovered before they could be detonated.
# text = (Kut is in southeastern Iraq and has an overwhelmingly Shiite population, who are on the lookout for Baathist saboteurs and willingly turn them in.
# text = This willingness is the main difference in the number of bombings in the south as opposed to the center-north of the country.)
# text = In Baghdad Kadhim Talal Husain, assistant dean at the School of Education at Mustansiriyah University, was assassinated with his driver in the Salikh district.
# text = Guerrillas killed an engineer, Asi Ali, from Tikrit.
# text = They also killed Shaikh Hamid 'Akkab, a clan elder of a branch of the Dulaim tribe in Tikrit.
# text = His mother was also killed in the attack.
# text = Two other Dulaim leaders have been killed in the past week and a half.
# text = Guerrillas near Hawijah launched an attack that left 6 dead, including 4 Iraqi soldiers.
# text = One of them was from the Jubur tribe and was deputy commander of the Hawijah garrison.
# text = Two hundred members of the Batawi clan of the Dulaim demonstrated in Baghdad on Friday, protesting the killing of their clan elder, Shaikh Kadhim Sarhid and 4 of his sons, by gunmen wearing Iraqi army uniforms.
# text = (This is a largely Sunni Arab clan, and some Sunni observers have accused Shiite elements in the government of being behind the assassination; it is more likely the work of Sunni Arab guerrillas punishing the Batawi leaders for cooperating with the Dec. 15 elections.)
# text = Al-Zaman : The Iraqi High Electoral Commission on Friday denied a request of the Debaathification Commission to exclude 51 individuals from running on party lists in the Dec. 15 elections on grounds of having been sufficiently involved in Baath activities to warrant their being excluded from civil office.
# text = The Commission said it had no legal grounds for such an exclusion.
# text = This item is a small one and easily missed.
# text = But in my view it is highly significant.
# text = The Debaathification Commission had been pushed by Ahmad Chalabi and his Iraqi National Congress very hard, and had pushed many Sunni Arabs into the arms of the guerrillas.
# text = Chalabi has been increasingly marginalized within Iraq, however, despite his ties of clientelage with Washington and Tehran.
# text = He is no longer in the dominant Shiite list, the United Iraqi Alliance, and won't have many seats in the new parliament.
# text = Some 2,000 junior officers of the old Baath army have been recalled to duty in recent months, something Chalabi would have blocked if he could have.
# text = Now the Electoral Commission is refusing to punish people for mere past Baath Party membership.
# text = The situation in Iraq is only going to get better this way.
# text = If someone committed a crime against humanity, prosecute the person.
# text = If he or she did not, then they should have all the same rights as other Iraqis.
# text = Al-Sharq al-Awsat reports that a key eyewitness in the trial of Saddam Hussein for a 1982 massacre at Dujail has died.
# text = A team from the court managed to take his deposition before he died.
# text = The trial begins again Nov.28.
# text = In Baghdad the fighting still continues in several areas, mostly in Sadr city and Adhamiya.
# text = Baghdadis don't venture much out of their neighbourhoods any more, you never know where you might get stuck.
# text = There has been talk that the night curfew might be implemented again.
# text = My neighbourhood has been surrounded by American troops for three days now, helicopters have been circling over our heads non-stop.
# text = Fedayeen are now visible on the street and they have become bolder than ever.
# text = Yesterday there were tens of them putting road blocks on our street and setting up mortars, they only come out in the open when Americans leave the area, then they start firing mortars indiscriminately and shooting their AK-47's in the air.
# text = They are setting the road blocks at the exact same positions they were during the war last year, which indicates they are the same people.
# text = And there is nothing we can do about it really, people who are suggesting that we go out and fight them are living in dream land.
# text = Even the IP and ICDC have abandoned the neighbourhood, and those are trained and armed, so don't expect scared civilians to do anything except to hide inside and pray a helicopter or a tank doesn't bomb them, and also how are American soldiers going to distinguish the brave and valiant civilians from the Fedayeen?
# text = Everyone is apprehensive, there is some talk that April 9th and 10th are going to be bloody days.
# text = Most people haven't gone to work the last few days, although it seems that the rest of Baghdad is 'normal' (if you can define what normal is).
# text = There are rumours about preparations by slum dwellers for another looting spree against banks, governmental and public property similar to the one that took place last April, and I have already overheard youngsters in my neighbourhood joking about it and saying things like "This time we will be the first to loot, we didn't get anything the last time".
# text = Mosques are calling for donating blood, food, and medicine for Fallujah, and several convoys have already headed out for Fallujah, most of them returned later though.
# text = What irritates me is this sudden false 'solidarity' between Sunni and Shi'ite clerics, we all know that they would be glad to get at each others throats when they have the chance, and Shia clerics were describing Fallujan insurgents as 'Ba'athists', 'Saddamites', 'Wahhabis', and 'terrorists' just a few days ago.
# text = So what happened?
# text = I guess it's just the old new Arab 'Me against my brother, me and my brother against my cousin, me and my cousin against my enemy', or 'The enemy of my enemy is my friend' thing going on again.
# text = Speaking of Fallujah, we have only Al-Jazeera to rely on for our news from there.
# text = They have sent over their top reporter Ahmed Mansour to the town, and he is spouting all kinds of propaganda hourly reminding me of Al-Sahhaf.
# text = "They are targetting ambulances", "American snipers are shooting children and pregnant women", and "They are using cluster bombs against civilians" is all you get to hear from him.
# text = He did once make an unforgivable error when he mentioned that Fallujan militants were shooting at the Marines from the roofs of mosques and houses in Hay Al-Golan, but of course that is okay for Al-Jazeera.
# text = Someone who called himself Abu Hafs from the Ibn Al-Khattab Brigades (another new group) was on Al-Jazeera describing the enormous casualties among the Marines and he sweared that American soldiers were mutilating the bodies of dead insurgents.
# text = Al-Iraqiyah tv said that ICDC were controlling Ramadi.
# text = Azzaman newspaper mentioned an announcement signed by Abdul Aziz bin Muqrin, an Al-Qaeda operative in Saudi Arabia on an Islamic website 'the voice of Jihad', in which he stated that "although mutilating dead bodies is not originally permitted in Islam, but in this case it is allowed if Muslims use it against infidels to deter them from committing criminal actions".
# text = He added that "America does not understand anything except the language of force and retaliation, they were kicked out of Somalia in humiliation after that soldier was dragged in Mogadishu for the whole world to see", and that "the day will come when the dead bodies of Americans and Jews would be dragged, defiled, and stepped on in the Arabian peninsula together with their agents and supporters".
# text = Elena's motorcycle tour through the region around Chernobyl has revived interest in one of the most serious nuclear disasters in history.
# text = We all know what happened, but even to this day, there are many different versions and opinions on how it happened and what effect Chernobyl will have on the health of people affected by the fallout.
# text = UPDATE:
# text = Now you can tour Chernobyl and write your own story.
# text = This is not a post about fault-finding or assigning blame.
# text = It is a time to learn what happened and how it may affect the future.
# text = There was a soothing authoritative UNSCEAR (United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation ) report in 2000 on the health effects of Chernobyl confirming that there was no scientific evidence of any significant radiation-related health effects to most people exposed.
# text = This was heavily promoted by the Australasian Radiation Protection Society in a press release titled THE MYTHS OF CHERNOBYL which contained the following:
# text = One of the most widespread myths of recent times is that the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident in 1986 caused many thousands of extra cancer deaths in neighbouring regions, and that public health has been severely affected by exposure to radiation.
# text = Many people still believe that to be true, even though the Ministry of Russian Federation on Civil Defence, Emergencies and Elimination of Conseguences of Natural Disasters (EMERCOM of Russia) reported this in 1996:
# text = CHERNOBYL ACCIDENT: TEN YEARS ON
# text = In the last decade, there has been a real and significant increase in childhood and, to a certain extent, adult carcinoma of the thyroid in contaminated regions of the former Soviet Union (Wi940) which should be attributed to the Chernobyl accident until proven otherwise.
# text = The prestigious IAEA (International Atomic Energy Agency) published an early report on Chernobyl which was based on information from Russian sources and stated that there was no significant health effects.
# text = However, in April 2001, the IAEA published Fifteen Years after the Chernobyl Accident - Lessons learned. which contradict the earlier reports.
# text = Here are some excerpts:
# text = The dramatic increase in radiation-induced thyroid cancers in children and adolescents in Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine, which have been observed since 1991, continues to this day.
# text = ...a drop in the birth rate, a deterioration in women's reproductive health, an increase in complications during pregnancy and birth, and a deterioration in neonatal health....
# text = The dynamics of change in the state of health of children affected by the Chernobyl accident in all three countries - Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine - in the post-accident period is characterized by persistent negative tendencies: the morbidity rate is going up, the number of really healthy children is dropping, and disability is increasing .
# text = As a parent, I can well imagine how painful it must be for those families whose children are succumbing to radiation poisoning.
# text = There is a lot to learn about Chernobyl.
# text = Being well-informed will give you certainty and that is desirable in a world of conflicting reports.
# text = There are a wealth of references on Chernobyl.
# text = Read some of the following links and draw your own conclusions.
# text = These links present the many viewpoints that existed and still exist about the disaster called Chernobyl:
# text = IAEA Report Lessons learned

# text = I would be interested in hearing what conclusions you reached and what you found that was most convincing.
# text = radiation:
# text = As a child in the 50's I had a lot of glandular problems and they treated it with radiation therapy (primitive at best!) and stopped when a lesion on my neck started enlarging--they said it was not CA but stopped the treatments....
# text = Remember the old shoe sizing machines that was a form of radiation xray?
# text = That too was stopped.
# text = Don't have to mention what radiation has done and is still doing to Hirsohima & Nagaski folks--there can be no doubts about the effects of radiation in Chernobyl.......
# text = The Chernobyl Children's Project (http://www.adiccp.org/home/default.asp) offers several ways to help the children of that region.
# text = One of them is the Rest and Recuperation Program, wherein a child can come to the US for a few weeks in the summer.
# text = Even a little time spent receiving wholesome, uncontaminated food, good medical care, etc. can add years to their lives.
# text = S. and I have an acquaintance who has hosted several of these children for many years; to see these little ones breaks the heart.
# text = The urge to protect and gather them all in is almost overwhelming, and makes me more grateful for the blessings I have.
# text = Take care, my friend, Linda
# text = I'm sorry to say Elena's story has been revealed to be a fake.
# text = What do the new al-Qaeda videotape and audio speeches of Bin Laden and Ayman al-Zawahiri tell us about the hopes of the remaining top leadership of the organization?
# text = Because the US and Pakistan have managed to capture or kill about 2/3s of the top 25 al-Qaeda commanders, the middle managers are not in close contact with al-Zawahiri and Bin Laden.
# text = The tape was a way to signal priorities.
# text = These are 1) Assassinate or overthrow Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani military "president" who had made a coup in 1999 and has thrown in his lot with the United States against the Taliban and al-Qaeda.
# text = Musharraf has been trying to purge his officer corps of the substantial number of al-Qaeda sympathizers.
# text = His military intelligence has captured major figures like Abu Zubayda and Khalid Shaykh Muhammad, as well as nearly 500 other al-Qaeda operatives, over 400 of whom the Pakistanis have turned over to the US.
# text = Musharraf held elections in October of 2002, in which center-right parties did well, but in which nearly 20 percent of parliament seats went to the fundamentalist religious party coalition, MMA.
# text = MMA also captured the Northwest Frontier Province, which probably shelters Bin Laden and al-Zawahiri, and is in a joint government of Baluchistan Province, also on the Afghanistan border.
# text = If al-Qaeda can kill Musharraf or instigate a military coup against him by Islamist junior officers, they can hope to catapult the MMA to power as political allies and hosts.
# text = They would thereby gain control of a major base for terrorist operations, which is also a nuclear power.
# text = All this is highly unlikely, as with most al-Qaeda crackpot schemes.
# text = But so was it unlikely that a small group of Arab mujahidin would virtually take over Afghanistan.
# text = Response: The US must do whatever it can to strengthen the legitimacy of the Pakistani government.
# text = On the one hand, it should pressure Musharraf to take off his uniform and run for president in a fair election, and to repeal the contentious "Legal Framework Order" that essentially perpetuates his dictatorship.
# text = On the other, restrictions should be lifted on the mainstream Muslim League-N and Pakistan People's Party, who can defeat the MMA in fair elections if not hogtied by the secret police.
# text = On the other hand, the US should strong-arm India and Pakistan into a final settlement of the Kashmir issue.
# text = Al-Zawahiri attempted to use Musharraf's lack of progress in helping the Muslims of that Indian state as a justification for his overthrow.
# text = The Kashmir issue generates far more terrorism, and even the threat of nuclear war, than Iraq ever did.
# text = 2) Target Israel and encourage the worst elements of the Palestinians by playing on the iron fist policies of the Sharon government.
# text = Response: The US has succeeded in politically isolating Hamas, and started the process of cutting off its funding.
# text = This terrorist organization can now only pull off far less sophisticated bombings and attacks.
# text = It should continue to be defanged.
# text = But Sharon's iron fist is simply not working as a means of establishing general peace, and the Bush administration will have to finally apply effective pressure on Sharon to stop his outrages in and colonization of the West Bank and Gaza.
# text = Sharon's hard line has worked in tandem with Hamas's terrorism to ratchet up tensions further and further, which spill over into the Muslim world and serve as a recruiting tool for al-Qaeda in its search for agents willing to hit the United States.
# text = Israel owes the United States at least this much, in this crisis, to cease militarily unnecessary provocations and establish genuine peace.
# text = 3) Make Iraq another Afghanistan, using the Republican Right's own tactics against them.
# text = Response: Iraq is actually hostile territory for al-Qaeda, and without Iraqi sympathizers it cannot succeed there.
# text = By moving quickly to Iraqi sovereignty and improvement of Iraqi lives, the US may be able to get Iraqis on its side, so that they turn in the foreigners.
# text = Certainly, the Shiites already hate al-Qaeda and would help; likewise the Kurds.
# text = The problem of mollifying the Sunnis, though, has to be solved to avoid giving al-Qaeda an entrée.
# text = The Americans have to put away their free-market fetishism for a while and find ways of creating jobs and pumping money into Iraqi households.
# text = We need an FDR in Iraq, not a Ronald Reagan.
# text = Of course, the sooner the US soldiers can be withdrawn in favor of less-provocative local or international forces, the better.
# text = Getting the Spanish out of Iraq isn't nearly as good a rallying cry for al-Qaeda in the Arab world as getting the Americans and British out.
# text = The thing to keep in mind is that Sunni Arab nationalists and Baathists and local Sunni radicals are likely to remain far more dangerous to the US in Iraq than al-Qaeda infiltrators, and it would be dangerous to take one's eyes off the former ball.
# text = George W. Bush alleged Thursday that John Edwards lacks the experience necessary to be president.
# text = The problem with this argument is that Bush lacked the experience necessary to be president when he ran in 2000, so this sort of cheap shot just hoists him by his own petard.
# text = Let's just remember a seminal Bush moment in 1999:
# text = ' Bush fails reporter's pop quiz on international leaders
# text = November 5, 1999
# text = Web posted at: 3:29 p.m. EST (2029 GMT)
# text = WASHINGTON (CNN) --
# text = Texas Gov. George W. Bush is enduring sharp criticism for being unable to name the leaders of four current world hot spots, but President Bill Clinton says Bush "should, and probably will, pick up" those names.
# text = The front-runner for the 2000 Republican presidential nomination faltered Thursday in an international affairs pop quiz posed by Andy Hiller, a political reporter for WHDH-TV in Boston.
# text = Bush
# text = Hiller asked Bush to name the leaders of Chechnya, Taiwan, India and Pakistan.
# text = Bush was only able to give a partial response to the query on the leader of Taiwan, referring to Taiwanese President Lee Teng-hui simply as "Lee."
# text = He could not name the others.
# text = "Can you name the general who is in charge of Pakistan?"
# text = Hiller asked, inquiring about Gen. Pervaiz Musharraf, who seized control of the country October 12.
# text = "Wait, wait, is this 50 questions?" asked Bush.
# text = Hiller replied: "No, it's four questions of four leaders in four hot spots." . . .
# text = It appears this guy is going to bring stability to the country and I think that's good news for the subcontinent."
# text = Gore released a statement Friday taking Bush to task for his comments on Pakistan's recent coup.
# text = "I find it troubling that a candidate for president in our country -- the world's oldest democracy -- would characterize the military takeover as "good news," Gore said.
# text = "Further, I find it even more disturbing that he made these comments about a nation that just last year tested nuclear weapons -- shortly after voicing his public opposition to the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.
# text = A spokesman for President Clinton also criticized Bush's comments.
# text = "It is very dangerous for this country to condone the overthrow of democratically elected governments," said David Leavy, spokesman for the National Security Council.
# text = Not only did Bush not know who General Pervez Musharraf was, he seems to have confused coup-making with "taking office," and moreover went on to suggest that the overthrow of an elected prime minister and the installation in power of the Pakistan military, then the world's strongest supporter of the Taliban, would bring "stability!"
# text = Musharraf made his coup in part because of the military's anger over Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's willingness to back down from confronting India over Kashmir, so that he explicitly came to power as a warmonger.
# text = I can't tell you how ominous I found Bush's performance in that interview.
# text = I still remember him stuttering about "the General," unable to remember Musharraf's name.
# text = He obviously had no idea what he was talking about, though he demonstrated a number of ill-fated instincts.
# text = He obviously liked authoritarian rule better than democracy, equating dictatorship with "stability."
# text = And, he didn't think he needed to know anything about South Asia, with its nuclear giants and radical religious politics--the latter a dire security threat to the US.
# text = He couldn't tell when things were becoming more unstable as opposed to less.
# text = Musharraf went on to play nuclear brinkmanship with India in 2002, risking war twice that year.
# text = Although Musharraf did turn against the Taliban after September 11, under extreme duress from the US, elements of his military continued to support radical Islamism and have recently been implicated in assassination attempts on Musharraf himself.
# text = This was the body that Bush proclaimed was bringing "stability" to the region in fall of 1999.
# text = So, one answer to Bush's charge about Edwards is that if it had any merit, Bush should have declined to run himself.
# text = Another answer is that Edwards certainly knows far more about foreign affairs now than Bush did then.
# text = Indeed, given how Bush has rampaged around the world alienating allies and ignoring vital conflicts with the potential to blow back on the US, one might well argue that Edwards knows more now than Bush does.
# text = This is what Edwards' campaign literature said about his positions: "Edwards believes that the U.S. must be an active leader to help resolve conflicts, from reducing tensions between India and Pakistan to the peace process in Northern Ireland.
# text = Edwards is a strong supporter of Israel, and believes that the U.S. has a vital role in promoting peace between the Israelis and the Palestinians."
# text = I don't see Bush doing any of this.
# text = From Friday's Daily Star
# text = By Juan Cole
# text = Friday, June 04, 2004
# text = As the American public gradually wearies of the Iraq crisis, some have begun worrying that the war could blow back on the US by creating the conditions for anti-American terrorism.
# text = Israel, however, is much closer to Iraq and is likely to suffer from Iraqi instability much more acutely than will the United States.
# text = Ironically, among the strongest proponents of war in Iraq were Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and his neoconservative supporters in the US.
# text = Have they, however, actually weakened Israeli security?
# text = The biggest threat Israel faces is not from conventional armies but from the asymmetrical tactics of Palestinian national liberation movements.
# text = The derailing of the Oslo peace process by the hard-line policies of Sharon and the Palestinian intifada has encouraged suicide bombings.
# text = This, in turn, has discouraged international investment in Israel and has made it less likely that immigrants to the country will actually remain there.
# text = Although Israel withdrew from Lebanese territory in May 2000, the radical Lebanese Shiite party, Hizbullah, has not been mollified.
# text = It is estimated to have some 5,000 armed fighters, and they have pursued attacks against Israeli forces to compel them to withdraw from the Shebaa Farms, a sliver of Syrian territory that Israel annexed after the 1967 war.
# text = Any thorough assessment of the impact of the Iraq war and its aftermath on Israel's security environment must, therefore, closely examine its likely effect on the conduct of asymmetrical warfare.
# text = Although it is often alleged (without much evidence) that Saddam Hussein gave money to the families of Palestinian suicide bombers and so encouraged asymmetrical warfare, it is not clear that he actually posed a danger to Israel.
# text = The Palestinians who have been willing to kill themselves to end the Israeli occupation of the Gaza Strip and the West Bank were not driven by economic considerations.
# text = Saddam never did anything practical to help the Palestinians.
# text = At some points, as in the late 1980s, he reportedly made behind-the-scenes overtures to the Israelis to arrive at some sort of a deal.
# text = He did not allow Palestinian radicals to launch operations against Israel from Iraq.
# text = By the late 1990s, Iraq had no nuclear or biological weapons program, and had destroyed its chemical weapons stockpiles.
# text = Its ramshackle army had virtually collapsed before the American invasion in 2003.
# text = If it is hard to see how Baathist Iraq posed any real threat to Israel, it is not so difficult to see a menace in the current instability.
# text = The bungling of post-war Iraq by the Bush administration created a weak and failed state.
# text = Armed militias, many staffed by former Iraqi military men with substantial training and experience, have proliferated.
# text = The US chose to ally itself with such groups as the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, whose 15,000-strong Badr Corps paramilitary was trained by the Iranian Revolutionary Guards.
# text = Anti-Israeli and pro-Palestinian feeling is strong among several major Iraqi ideological groups and currents.
# text = The more radical Shiites, who generally follow the theocratic notions of Iran's Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, routinely chant and demonstrate against Israel.
# text = They vehemently protested the Israeli assassination of Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, the leader of Hamas, last March.
# text = Worse for Israel, the assassination drew a denunciation even from the moderate and cautious Grand Ayatollah Ali Sistani, who wields enormous moral authority over Iraqi Shiites.
# text = These Shiite movements had been suppressed by Saddam Hussein's regime, but have now organized and armed themselves.
# text = They have also reestablished their historical links with Lebanese and Iranian Shiites.
# text = It is inevitable that most Iraqi Shiites will side with their Hizbullah coreligionists against Israel, and it seems likely that Iraqi Shiites will get rich enough from Iraqi petroleum sales in the future that they will be in a good position to bankroll Lebanese Shiite radicals.
# text = Sunni Arab fundamentalists deeply sympathize with the Palestinians and with Hamas, and those in Iraq have deep historical inks with fundamentalists in Jordan and Palestine.
# text = Iraqi cities such as Fallujah and Ramadi were on the truck route from Amman to Baghdad, and so came under the influence of the Salafi movement, which is popular in Jordan.
# text = Secular Arab nationalist groups also universally sympathize with the Palestinians, and those in post-Saddam Iraq are no exception.
# text = Whereas Saddam Hussein's dictatorship ensured that such populist currents were kept firmly under control, they are now free to organize.
# text = An Iraq in which armed fundamentalist and nationalist militias proliferate is inevitably a security worry for Israel.
# text = If even a modicum of normality and security can be returned to Iraq, its citizens will be able to benefit from the country's petroleum reserves.
# text = That private wealth can easily be funneled into aid for the Palestinians and for Lebanese Shiites.
# text = Israel's security interests are best served by peace with its neighbors, which can only be achieved by trading land for peace with the Palestinians.
# text = Ariel Sharon's aggressive near annexation of almost half of the occupied West Bank and his indefinite postponement of any Palestinian state have created unprecedented rage and violence.
# text = The anger has spread throughout the Muslim world, including Iraq.
# text = The promotion by the pro-Zionist right of twin occupations - in the West Bank and in Iraq - has profoundly weakened, not strengthened, Israeli security.
# text = Juan Cole (www.juancole.com) is a professor of modern Middle East history at the University of Michigan and author of "Sacred Space and Holy War" (I.B. Tauris, 2002).
# text = THE DAILY STAR publishes this commentary in agreement with Agence Global
# text = Tamils feel that the proposed defense agreement between India and Sri Lanka would encourage Sinhala rulers to prepare for another war abandoning the current peace process
# text = But there are strong hints in the country that a new Indo-Sri Lanka defense deal could be in the making.
# text = And this has already drawn protests from the Tamil National Alliance (TNA) which was backed by the LTTE in the April general elections held in Sri Lanka.
# text = Apart from the 1,200 Indian lives lost in 1987, the Indian peacekeeping force was immensely unpopular not only in Tamil Nadu and the Jaffna peninsula but also among the Sinhalese majority who considered it a violation of their country's sovereignty.
# text = India defensive over Sri Lanka
# text = By Ranjit Devraj
# text = NEW DELHI -
# text = While India is ready to enter into a "defense cooperation agreement" with Sri Lanka, it is wary of being drawn into any military involvement in the island nation's two decades-old civil war that has seen violent strife between ethnic Tamils and the Sinhalese majority - leaving over 60,000 dead on both sides.
# text = And that explains the delay in the signing of a formal defense agreement that was at the heart of Sri Lankan President Chandrika Kumaratunga's four-day visit to India recently.
# text = According to Professor S D Muni, South Asia expert at the Jawaharal Nehru University, the two-year peace talks between Colombo and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) are stalemated.
# text = For that reason, he said, Kumaratunga's government was keen to beef up military preparedness with Indian support.
# text = "The Sri Lankan government does not want to initiate a conflict but would be interested in deterring the LTTE from starting one.
# text = And the Tigers look as if they are on the brink of launching another offensive," Muni told IPS.
# text = Colombo held six rounds of talks with the Tigers between September 2002 and March 2003.
# text = But last April, the rebels abruptly pulled out of negotiations demanding recognition, first, for the right to self-rule before proceeding any further.
# text = Kumaratunga's India tour preceded a three-day visit to Sri Lanka by Norwegian Foreign Minister Jan Petersen in a new bid to revive the peace talks that were supposed to follow a ceasefire that Oslo successfully brokered in February 2002.
# text = Petersen held discussions with both Kumaratunga and the reclusive LTTE leader Velupillai Prabhakaran in the rebel stronghold of Kilinochchi without success, and chief Tamil rebel negotiator Anton Balasingham and Norwegian envoy Erik Solheim held closed-door talks at the international airport late Saturday in an effort to keep the salvage effort on track, diplomatic sources said.
# text = But they, too, failed.
# text = Colombo, too, seems to be in an intractable position.
# text = According to former Indian army general A S Kalkat, the difficulty for Kumaratunga's government lay in the fact that the LTTE had become a de jure power in the north and east of the island and was running every aspect of civil administration in the areas within its control.
# text = A veteran of India's military intervention in the Jaffna peninsula to help implement the 1987 Indo-Sri Lanka Peace Accord - which ambitiously provided for the disarming of the formidable LTTE - Kalkat said the new defense deal would essentially be a reiteration of the older one minus its military commitment.
# text = Kalkat, who currently chairs the independent US-based International Council on Conflict Resolution, said despite the failure of the Indian army to disarm or even subdue the Tigers, India remained the only power capable of influencing the course of the current peace talks.
# text = "The Norwegians mean well but their role is limited to that of honest broker and the LTTE is keenly aware that they do not have the power [unlike India] to underwrite any arrangement," Kalkat told IPS in an interview.
# text = In 1987, the Tamil Tigers reluctantly accepted the peace accord under Indian pressure.
# text = Under the accord, a new northeastern provincial council was formed and the Indian army was deployed as peacekeepers in the north and east.
# text = However, differences between India and LTTE soon surfaced and led to clashes between Tiger guerrillas and the Indian peace keeping force.
# text = About 1,200 Indian soldiers were killed during this phase of the conflict.
# text = India had to pull back its forces from Sri Lanka in 1989 following the election of Ranasinghe Premadasa, a strong critic of Indian mediation.
# text = Last June, an international initiative led by Japan to persuade the LTTE to come back to the negotiating table failed despite an aid package offer of US$4.5 billion.
# text = Japan's special envoy, Yasushi Akashi, who called for tangible progress in the peace process before the money would be released, came back from visits to Colombo and Kilinochchi in early November a frustrated man.
# text = He complained about the "visible lack of progress" and reaching an impasse in talks with both sides.
# text = The Tigers' chief ideologue, Balasingham, sniffed at the proposal saying that "a solution to the ethnic conflict cannot be predetermined by the resolutions or declarations of donor conferences, but has to be negotiated by the parties in conflict without the constraints of external forces."
# text = But there are strong hints in the country that a new Indo-Sri Lanka defense deal could be in the making.
# text = And this has already drawn protests from the Tamil National Alliance (TNA) which was backed by the LTTE in the April general elections held in Sri Lanka.
# text = "Tamils feel that the proposed defense agreement between India and Sri Lanka would encourage Sinhala rulers to prepare for another war abandoning the current peace process," TNA member of parliament P Sithamparanathan was quoted as saying in a statement.
# text = She added that recent visits to the island by India's top military brass including army chief General Nirmal Chander Vij have "caused apprehension among Tamils that preparations are under way for another war in the island".
# text = But Kalkat pointed out that India would be ill-advised to be involved again, militarily, with Sri Lanka if only because it still had to consider the sentiments of 45 million ethnic Tamils in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu - separated from Sri Lanka's Jaffna peninsula by the narrow Palk Straits.
# text = Apart from the 1,200 Indian lives lost in 1987, the Indian peacekeeping force was immensely unpopular not only in Tamil Nadu and the Jaffna peninsula but also among the Sinhalese majority who considered it a violation of their country's sovereignty.
# text = The best option, now, under the present difficult circumstances is for Colombo to do its own dirty work, although New Delhi can always be counted on to render good neighborly help because of the shared belief that religion, ethnicity and language cannot be the basis for secession.
# text = In any case, Kalkat puts it succinctly: "There cannot be a military option to what is a political situation."
# text = Asia Times Online 16/11/2004
# text = Unreported by the international media, the Valley of Kashmir has seen an ethnic and cultural genocide that has resulted in the fleeing from the valley of almost all the Hindu families who have been living there since human habitation was first recorded.
# text = Thus far, none of the many "human rights" busybodies across the world have bothered to even notice such a development.
# text = Musharraf calls the bluff
# text = M.D. Nalapat
# text = While most U.S. secretaries of state -- save perhaps Dean Rusk -- have gobbled up credit for outcomes that they had little to do with, few have been as brazen as Colin Powell.
# text = Two years ago, Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf was surprised when the leader of the main Islamist alliance -- Maulana Fazlur Rahman -- visited India and issued a series of highly conciliatory statements.
# text = As Pakistan's president had been telling the United States he was "forced" into taking a hawkish line on India precisely by the likes of Rahman, this was an embarrassment.
# text = The reality is that India is no longer the enemy of choice for the people of Pakistan.
# text = That distinction has now gone to the United States.
# text = Realists, and this even includes members of the U.S. Democratic foreign policy establishment such as Strobe Talbott, who have long sought to divest India of its defensive capability against another nuclear power in Asia, understand the only feasible solution for Kashmir is the acceptance of the status quo.
# text = India keeps what it has while Pakistan and China (which was gifted a slice of the territory three decades ago) do likewise.
# text = Simultaneously, New Delhi would ensure a degree of autonomy for the state that would help cut popular support off from jihadis attempting to convert Kashmir into a second Afghanistan.
# text = Bill Clinton understood this at the end of his term in office yet, under Colin Powell (who appears to have an affinity for generals active in politics), the pendulum of U.S. policy has once again swung toward a quixotic effort to prize at least the Valley of Kashmir loose from India.
# text = This, Pakistan's lobbyist in Washington Christina Rocca has been told, is the "minimum" that the Pakistan army will accept.
# text = It is also far more than what any administration in New Delhi can deliver.
# text = This writer has for years regarded the best solution to the Kashmir problem as being the trifurcation of the Indian part of the state into a Hindu-majority Jammu, a Buddhist-dominated Ladakh and the overwhelmingly Muslim Kashmir Valley, with the third state given little of taxpayers' money but substantial autonomy.
# text = With luck, the Kashmir Valley can attract investment from the Middle East and other locations where Muslims are dominant and become a tourist, education and services haven within India.
# text = The overwhelming majority of Muslims in Kashmir would be happy with such an outcome, except for the tiny jihadi segment patronized by the U.S. State Department and the Pakistan Army, which would like to even the score with India for their catastrophic defeat in Bangladesh in 1971.
# text = Unreported by the international media, the Valley of Kashmir has seen an ethnic and cultural genocide that has resulted in the fleeing from the valley of almost all the Hindu families who have been living there since human habitation was first recorded.
# text = Thus far, none of the many "human rights" busybodies across the world have bothered to even notice such a development.
# text = Indeed, their reports are filled with tales of the "atrocities" of Indian troops on the innocent jihadis.
# text = Despite Sept. 11, the United States still supports the Kashmir groups that back jihad as part of the price Washington is paying to keep Pervez Musharraf happy.
# text = Unfortunately for them, the general has decided to take seriously Colin Powell's frequent boasts that it was on his nudging that the Indians made conciliatory gestures toward Islamabad.
# text = The U.S. State Department and the misnamed think tanks that follow its lead have held numerous conferences on Kashmir and, in most of them, the solution that has emerged is a valley prized loose from Indian control and under its own version of Ibrahim Rugova.
# text = That India is not Yugoslavia and that the "foreigner-led" Indian National Congress can least afford to ignore Indian nationalism, has not struck the conferees, among whom have been several Indian "scholars" and "analysts" ready to say and endorse anything for the sake of a free trip to New York or Vienna.
# text = Despite many wrinkles, India remains a part-democracy and merely signing on to a piece of paper that calls for an independent Kashmir does not get you into the trouble that writing an op-ed piece against Sonia Gandhi or Atal Behari Vajpayee would instantly.
# text = It was the business community in India that stepped in after Vajpayee indulged in an empty bout of saber rattling in 2002, pointing out that the only beneficiary of the mythical perception that war -- especially nuclear war -- was around the corner in the subcontinent was China.
# text = The reason for this is that India is emerging as an alternative investment destination to China, hence the favor that the generals in Islamabad do to their trusty supplier of nukes and missiles by creating a scare about war involving India when in fact the real flashpoints are the Taiwan Straits and North Korea.
# text = Since then, India has talked peace while always signaling that only the status quo would be acceptable as a final settlement: a line of action that is followed in the case of disputes with China as well.
# text = Unfortunately for those eager to indefinitely carry on with the lucrative business of conflict resolution in South Asia, Pervez Musharraf has now called Colin Powell's bluff, challenging him to deliver on his frequent statements implying that the Indians jump to his commands.
# text = Once the Manmohan Singh government shows that it has little appetite for suicide, Musharraf will face the moment of truth: accept the inevitable, or once again ramp up the insurgency and spawn a fresh lot of killers that can hit not merely Mumbai and New Delhi but London and Chicago as well.
# text = The one country that has shown that it understands the realities in South Asia is China.
# text = Under President Hu Jintao, Beijing has opened out to New Delhi and Prime Minister Wen Jiabao is expected to visit early next year, making friends by formally accepting Sikkim as part of India and backing India as a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council -- thus leaving Washington as the only one of the "permanent five" that has not yet done so.
# text = With Colin Powell around, the U.S. has no need of an Osama bin Laden
# text = M.D. Nalapat, an expert on jihad, is professor of geopolitics at the Manipal Academy of Higher Education, India.
# text = Washington Times 28/10/2004
# text = Ok.
# text = We all know that John Kerry served in Vietnam.
# text = Four whole months, after which he took advantage of a little-known, little-invoked regulation that allowed him to desert his "band of brothers".
# text = We also know how Dan Rather libeled George Bush and impugned his service in the Texas Air National Guard on a "60 Minutes II" report based largely on forged documents.
# text = During his time in the Guard, George Bush flew the F-102 Delta Dagger fighter-interceptor.
# text = The F-102 saw service in the Vietnam theater between March 1962 and December 1969.
# text = During this time, F-102 squadrons were based out of Tan Son Nhut, Da Nang and Bien Hoa in Vietnam, and Udorn and Don Muang in Thailand.
# text = ( Click here for source. )
# text = As far as George Bush knew, he and his unit could have been transferred to Vietnam.
# text = In all this so-called controversy, has anyone considered that perhaps George Bush just wanted to fly jets?
# text = And, let's remember, flying supersonic fighter jets is dangerous!
# text = They don't let just anybody do it.
# text = Some reporters (you know, the ones with journalistic ethics) have actually uncovered the truth about George Bush's service in the Texas Air National Guard.
# text = For example, did you know that George Bush spent considerably more time in uniform than John Kerry?
# text = What follows is the text of an e-mail sent to me by a friend of mine (thanks to Dave Manzano).
# text = Read on to learn the facts.
# text = ---------
# text = Bush’s National Guard years
# text = Before you fall for Dems’ spin, here are the facts
# text = What do you really know about George W. Bush’s time in the Air National Guard?
# text = That he didn’t show up for duty in Alabama?
# text = That he missed a physical?
# text = That his daddy got him in?
# text = News coverage of the president’s years in the Guard has tended to focus on one brief portion of that time — to the exclusion of virtually everything else.
# text = So just for the record, here, in full, is what Bush did:
# text = The future president joined the Guard in May 1968.
# text = Almost immediately, he began an extended period of training.
# text = Six weeks of basic training.
# text = Fifty-three weeks of flight training.
# text = Twenty-one weeks of fighter-interceptor training.
# text = That was 80 weeks to begin with, and there were other training periods thrown in as well.
# text = It was full-time work.
# text = By the time it was over, Bush had served nearly two years.
# text = Not two years of weekends.
# text = Two years.
# text = After training, Bush kept flying, racking up hundreds of hours in F-102 jets.
# text = As he did, he accumulated points toward his National Guard service requirements.
# text = At the time, guardsmen were required to accumulate a minimum of 50 points to meet their yearly obligation.
# text = According to records released earlier this year, Bush earned 253 points in his first year, May 1968 to May 1969 (since he joined in May 1968, his service thereafter was measured on a May-to-May basis).
# text = Bush earned 340 points in 1969-1970.
# text = [In other words, Bush earned enough points to satisfy the requirements for his entire six year hitch in 1969-1970 alone.
# text = - acd]
# text = He earned 137 points in 1970-1971.
# text = And he earned 112 points in 1971-1972.
# text = The numbers indicate that in his first four years, Bush not only showed up, he showed up a lot.
# text = Did you know that?
# text = That brings the story to May 1972 — the time that has been the focus of so many news reports — when Bush “deserted” (according to anti-Bush filmmaker Michael Moore) or went “AWOL” (according to Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee).
# text = Bush asked for permission to go to Alabama to work on a Senate campaign.
# text = His superior officers said OK.
# text = Requests like that weren’t unusual, says retired Col. William Campenni, who flew with Bush in 1970 and 1971.
# text = “In 1972, there was an enormous glut of pilots,” Campenni says.
# text = “The Vietnam War was winding down, and the Air Force was putting pilots in desk jobs.
# text = In ’72 or ’73, if you were a pilot, active or Guard, and you had an obligation and wanted to get out, no problem.
# text = In fact, you were helping them solve their problem.”
# text = So Bush stopped flying.
# text = From May 1972 to May 1973, he earned just 56 points — not much, but enough to meet his requirement.
# text = Then, in 1973, as Bush made plans to leave the Guard and go to Harvard Business School, he again started showing up frequently.
# text = In June and July of 1973, he accumulated 56 points, enough to meet the minimum requirement for the 1973-1974 year.
# text = Then, at his request, he was given permission to go.
# text = Bush received an honorable discharge after serving five years, four months and five days of his original six-year commitment.
# text = By that time, however, he had accumulated enough points in each year to cover six years of service.
# text = During his service, Bush received high marks as a pilot.
# text = A 1970 evaluation said Bush “clearly stands out as a top notch fighter interceptor pilot” and was “a natural leader whom his contemporaries look to for leadership.”
# text = A 1971 evaluation called Bush “an exceptionally fine young officer and pilot” who “continually flies intercept missions with the unit to increase his proficiency even further.”
# text = And a 1972 evaluation called Bush “an exceptional fighter interceptor pilot and officer.”
# text = Now, it is only natural that news reports questioning Bush’s service — in The Boston Globe and The New York Times, on CBS and in other outlets — would come out now.
# text = Democrats are spitting mad over attacks on John Kerry’s record by the group Swift Boat Veterans for Truth.
# text = And, as it is with Kerry, it’s reasonable to look at a candidate’s entire record, including his military service — or lack of it.
# text = Voters are perfectly able to decide whether it’s important or not in November.
# text = The Kerry camp blames Bush for the Swift boat veterans’ attack, but anyone who has spent much time talking to the Swifties gets the sense that they are doing it entirely for their own reasons.
# text = And it should be noted in passing that Kerry has personally questioned Bush’s service, while Bush has not personally questioned Kerry’s.
# text = In April — before the Swift boat veterans had said a word — Kerry said Bush “has yet to explain to America whether or not, and tell the truth, about whether he showed up for duty.”
# text = Earlier, Kerry said, “Just because you get an honorable discharge does not, in fact, answer that question.”
# text = Now, after the Swift boat episode, the spotlight has returned to Bush.
# text = That’s fine.
# text = We should know as much as we can.
# text = And perhaps someday Kerry will release more of his military records as well.
# text = Byron York is a White House correspondent for National Review.
# text = His column appears in The Hill each week.
# text = One week to elections day and the general atmosphere in the capital is eerie, yet strikingly familiar.
# text = I suspect the streets of Baghdad will look as if a war is looming this week.
# text = There is no doubt that many Iraqis regard the date of 30 January as a day of renewed hope, one they have been awaiting all their lives, but at the same time, many others are already dreading it.
# text = The interim government has promised security measures that would reduce the violence on the day of elections, but I fail to see how they will be able to protect all 5,000 (or so) balloting centres.
# text = Many voting centres have already been successfully attacked or destroyed in many areas.
# text = Now that the picture is clear, the two main competing lists seem to be the United Iraqi Coalition list and Allawi's Al-Iraqiya list.
# text = Ayad Allawi, and other ministers running on his list, have quite expectedly used their governmental positions in campaigning.
# text = One minister reportedly handed out 100 dollar 'gifts' to journalists attending a press conference for Allawi, a practice that brings back bad memories to many Iraqis.
# text = Sheikh Naji Al-Abbudi, a spokesman for Sistani, affirmed the claims that the Grand Ayatollah is backing the United Iraqi Coalition list.
# text = Indeed, Sistani's agents all over the country have been quite active in educating Iraqi Shia on the merits of elections, which has led to the assassination of at least two of them.
# text = Al-Abbudi stated that "His Emminence" decided to openly support the list because "others" (obviously a reference to Allawi) have been abusing official state positions and media outlets in their campaigning.
# text = Again there is no official written statement from Sistani's office confirming this allegation, which I think is intentional.
# text = Ahmed Al-Chalabi and defense minister Hazim Al-Sha'lan have been engaging in shrill public attacks over the media.
# text = Chalabi describing Sha'lan as a "Ba'athist" and a "former double agent for Saddam and the CIA", while Sha'lan dismisses Chalabi as a "thief" and an "Iranian stooge who longs for his own origins by defending Iran".
# text = One remark made by Sha'lan on Al-Arabiya TV, that he couldn't say more about Chalabi because he would embarrass himself and the viewers almost made me roll on the floor.
# text = It was an extremely amusing episode, watching Chalabi looking smug and amused, contrasted with Sha'lan, all serious and barely keeping himself from swearing.
# text = Fistfights, please.
# text = Hazim Al-Sha'lan, by the way, is the son of the late Sheikh of Al-Khaza'il in Diwaniya and has the potential to replace former information minister, M.S. Al-Sahaf, in his nonsensical media statements, which can be passed as jokes.

# text = Even there, many Kurds look and act as if they are going to grab the chance to vote them out of power.
# text = I doubt that will be the outcome though.
# text = Many Iraqis, including conservative and religious Iraqis, are surprisingly rooting for the Iraqi Communist party, probably in an attempt to counter the influence of Islamists in the forthcoming National Assembly.
# text = The Communist party has the largest number of registered party members in the country and can be considered as the oldest popular political party in Iraq.
# text = Its support base is much larger than what it seems.
# text = ***
# text = Several candidates were assassinated and targeted these last two weeks, others have been forced under threats to withdraw and to follow the example of the Islamic party.
# text = Sectarian tensions are at their highest since April, 2004, with Sunni insurgents now openly attacking Husseiniyas and Shia mosques.
# text = I had an interesting conversation with a middle-aged taxi driver who used to live in Fallujah and is now at relatives in Amiriya, Baghdad.
# text = After asking me which tribe I belong to (thus assessing my sectarian background) he started hurling abuses at the Shia, calling them Persians, Majoos (fire worshippers), rabid dogs and a handful of other descriptions that I can't mention here.
# text = He described Allawi's face as that of a f*ed horse and he dismissed the whole government as a band of thieves and traitors.
# text = I didn't argue with him but I asked him what he believed would be a viable solution to this mess.
# text = He said that resistance was the only commonsense solution.
# text = First driving out the Americans, then fighting the Shia back into submission (as in 1991).
# text = Sunni Iraqis contend that elections are impossible to hold under occupation.
# text = Leaving aside the fact that this views conflicts with other historical examples in the region, Sunnis have never offered an alternative choice, which eventually leads one to guess that the opinion held by the Fallujan taxi driver above is precisely what they are planning to implement.
# text = I had another conversation some months ago with a retired Ba'athist old-timer who claimed that Ba'athists have the means to stage a third coup d'etat and return to power within 10 hours of an American withdrawal.
# text = On sensing my incredulity to his statement he asserted that Ba'athist cells exist in all parts of the country and that they do have a central command, even though many have formed seperate cells (often under Islamic labels) with their own leaderships.
# text = He said that they have the training and the funding as well as the support of neighbouring and regional governments.
# text = I concur that Ba'athists and former security forces are capable of immediately controlling at least 5 out of 18 governorates, along with the capital, if Americans are to be removed from the picture entirely.
# text = But I also see that as a fatal misconception, which is doing Sunnis harm, because I don't believe the US is going anywhere so soon.

# text = I would suggest going for tribal Sheikhs rather than clerics, since they have the upper hand in their areas and can effectively root out any Ba'athists in their midst in return for a promise of sharing power and authority.
# text = Many of these Sheikhs have been disenfranchised and abused over the last two years.

# text = Al-Gu'ud had favoured elections and was in good terms with the government.
# text = The Gu'ud family even accepted to be offered the seat of Al-Anbar governor some months back.

# text = Former Pastor, Deputy Implicated In Church Child Sex Abuse
# text = PONCHATOULA, La. --
# text = Sheriff's deputies in Louisiana made a third arrest Wednesday in the ongoing investigation of a case involving allegations of sexual abuse of children and animals at a Ponchatoula, La., church.
# text = Austin Aaron Bernard III, 36, was arrested on a charge of aggravated rape of a child under the age of 13.
# text = Police said Bernard confessed to detectives that he had sex with a young girl in November 2002 and admitted to knowing about sexual acts involving children and a dog that occurred at Hosanna Church.
# text = Tangipahoa Parish sheriff's deputy Christopher Blair Labat, 24, was booked Tuesday on one count of aggravated rape and one count of crime against nature.
# text = On Monday, Louis Lamonica, 45, the former pastor of Hosanna Church, was booked with two counts of aggravated rape and one count of crime against nature after he walked in to the Livingston Parish Sheriff's Office and said he could implicate others in a situation at the church that reportedly occurred two years ago.
