# text = + As the implications of the Andaman Islands situation sink in, Indian intelligence has inevitably come under scrutiny.
# text = In recent months, its fallibility has become evident.
# text = The inability to foresee in advance the assassination attempt on the pro-India political leader and former Bangladeshi prime minister Sheikh Hasina Wazed last August 21 at a political rally in Dhaka, and the recent "coup" by Nepalese King Gyanendra dismissing his government and imposing a virtual absolute monarchy, are glaring examples of intelligence failure. +
# text = Trouble on India's islands
# text = Ramtanu Maitra
# text = In early February, India charged 34 Arakan separatists from Myanmar with hiding in the Landfall Islands, part of the Andaman Islands group (see end note).
# text = These alleged members of the Arakan Army, the military wing of the National Unity Party in Myanmar, have been charged with illegal entry.
# text = It is likely, but not certain, that they will be deported to Myanmar.
# text = But the news of the Arakan rebels is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to growing concern in New Delhi over the security of the Andaman Islands.
# text = Reports are circulating in the intelligence community that the Andaman Islands are not only thick with Myanmar rebels.
# text = It has also become an arms depot of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE), who operate almost freely in the Andaman Sea.
# text = Information pointing in this direction came to light after the December 26 tsunami, which took a heavy toll on the Andamans.
# text = Correspondents who flocked in to cover the tsunami found they also had another story - the miserable security situation surrounding the Indian navy's Far Eastern Naval Command, now being established along with India's "blue water navy".
# text = Deteriorating security
# text = Security problems in the Andaman Sea are not new, but they have deteriorated during the past few years, in tandem with a deterioration in the security situation in Bangladesh, Nepal and Bhutan, and particularly in the northeastern Indian states of Manipur, Nagaland and Tripura.
# text = While the Indian army has become rock-solid in the western front, and has developed the capability of withstanding any Pakistani adventure in that sector, it has become highly vulnerable in its eastern sector, where its enemy is not a national army but a multitude of secessionist, terrorist and drug-running militants operating between Southeast Asia and northeastern India through Bangladesh.
# text = The Andaman Sea is a major conduit for this traffic, and the 572 large and small islands that constitute the Andaman and Nicobar group are a natural transit base.
# text = The drugs and arms travel in all directions.
# text = Since the "Sea Tigers" of the LTTE, better known as the Tamil Tigers, are the ones who rule the Andaman Sea: they carry the arms and drugs for their own use and also to deliver to rebels in Aceh and all along the east coast of Africa.
# text = It is old news that the Tamil Tigers have developed a strong network within South Africa.
# text = This is not unknown to New Delhi.
# text = A recent report by a journalist from Port Blair, in the Andamans, quoted an unnamed official saying that foreigners from Myanmar, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka have permanently settled in the islands, using fake Indian ration cards, while citizens of Thailand, China, Indonesia and Malaysia have migrated temporarily to plunder the natural resources and leave.
# text = "Port Blair, Havelock Islands, Diglipur, Middle Nicobar, Campbell's Bay, Neil Islands and Rangott are mostly overrun by foreigners," he said.
# text = An official estimate issued in 2003 suggests there are 50,000 "foreigners" in the Andaman Islands, but unofficial figures are much higher than this.
# text = A large number of them are Bangladeshis, who like millions of their countrymen have left their densely populated homeland to settle elsewhere.
# text = As most of them have few technical skills, and the Andamans have little demand for them in any case, they turn to smuggling and other unlawful activities.
# text = The presence of the Sea Tigers in the area with guns, cash and drugs makes the situation extremely dangerous.
# text = Reports from Port Blair make it evident that New Delhi gets little on-the-ground intelligence, and the Indian Coast Guard is grossly unequipped to deal with the surge of illegal migrants to the islands.
# text = One unnamed naval officer was quoted saying, "Arms smuggling is a very profitable business in this region."
# text = Considering the islands' huge strategic importance, it is amazing how lax New Delhi has been.
# text = These islands sit aside the vital sea lanes of the Strait of Malacca, through which 300 tankers and merchant ships pass daily, bringing in oil for the Far East and Southeast Asia.
# text = Intelligence lapses
# text = As the implications of the Andaman Islands situation sink in, Indian intelligence has inevitably come under scrutiny.
# text = In recent months, its fallibility has become evident.
# text = The inability to foresee in advance the assassination attempt on the pro-India political leader and former Bangladeshi prime minister Sheikh Hasina Wazed last August 21 at a political rally in Dhaka, and the recent "coup" by Nepalese King Gyanendra dismissing his government and imposing a virtual absolute monarchy, are glaring examples of intelligence failure.
# text = With growing economic and military power, India will be dependent on smaller nations in the region increasingly to maintain regional security.
# text = Unless New Delhi does better in providing security to its own nationals against rebels, secessionists, drug runners and arms traffickers, it will not generate much confidence in the capitals of surrounding nations.
# text = In fact, it would tend to encourage more organized anti-India outfits, such as the Pakistani Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) and outside-linked Maoists, to exploit these networks and weaken India's eastern flank.
# text = Indian intelligence's lackluster performance in dealing with the LTTE is startling.
# text = This formidable enemy, which gave the Indian army a black eye in the mid-1980s, has been operating in northeastern India and in the Andaman Sea for a long time.
# text = In 2001, according to Indian army officials, security forces launched a wide-ranging operation in the 300-some inhabited islands neighboring Andaman and Nicobar, and found huge caches of arms.
# text = The arms were said to belong to the LTTE and "other terrorist groups".
# text = The search-and-destroy operation was carried out by the Indian government after repeated requests from Colombo.
# text = In addition, LTTE activity in the Andaman Sea is well known to local observers.
# text = The biggest LTTE maritime disaster was reported in the now-defunct Asiaweek in 2001.
# text = A shipment of weapons, ammunition and explosives, believed to have been purchased from Cambodia and worth several million dollars, left the port of Phuket in Thailand in early February 2001 aboard the freighter Comex-Joux 3.
# text = As is LTTE standard procedure, the vessel changed its name at sea to Horizon.
# text = On its journey across the Bay of Bengal the freighter was tracked by the Indian navy and Orissa-based spy planes of India's Aviation Research Center; it was intercepted by Indian naval vessels off Sri Lanka's east coast.
# text = LTTE arms-running
# text = In 1997, the Thai navy reported the interception of a 16-meter boat after a chase off the Thai port of Ranong, and the confiscation of two tons of weapons and ammunition.
# text = Among the weapons intercepted were two rocket-propelled-grenade launchers, 20 assault rifles, M-79 grenade launchers and more than 10,000 rounds of ammunition.
# text = Four persons were arrested, reportedly belonging to the Manipur Revolutionary People's Front.
# text = Six crew members were from the Arakan region of Myanmar.
# text = The boat was heading toward Cox's Bazar in Bangladesh.
# text = Until 1995 the LTTE maintained a base at Twante, an island off the coat of Myanmar, west of the Andaman islands.
# text = Subsequently, Phuket became the LTTE's main backup base.
# text = A Sri Lanka-born Tamil with a Norwegian passport was arrested by Thai authorities in 2000 for his links with the LTTE.
# text = At the time of his arrest, the suspect was allegedly involved in constructing a "submarine" in a shipyard on the island of Sirae near Phuket on the Andaman Sea coast.
# text = Steady buildup
# text = The real threat to the Andaman Islands is the steady building-up of ports and conduits that serve the Tamil Tigers and a host of less-strong militant groups.
# text = Over the past decade, Bangladesh has steadily moved into a state of lawlessness.
# text = A number of extremist groups, under the cover of the Islamist movement, have become active in drug trafficking, gun running and anti-Indian activities.
# text = It is widely acknowledged that the Pakistani ISI has nurtured a number of extremist Islamist groups, such as the Harkat-ul-Jehad-al-Islami, in the port city of Chittagong, and put a number of secessionist rebels from India's northeast in touch with this terrorist network.
# text = As a result, north of the Andaman Islands, Bangladeshi coastal areas have become a nest of terrorists involved in the shipment of drugs and arms.
# text = A pattern of arrests and seizures indicate that arms are brought by the LTTE from Laos, Cambodia and Thailand into Chittagong, from where they are transported northward by land to Bhutan.
# text = The route from Kalikhola in Bhutan to Cox's Bazar passes through northern Bengal, Assam and Meghalaya, and on into Chittagong.
# text = Note
# text = India's Andaman and Nicobar Islands comprise more than 500 islands lying 1,000 kilometers east of Sri Lanka in the Bay of Bengal.
# text = Stretching 750 kilometers from end to end, they reach from near the coast of Myanmar almost to Sumatra in Indonesia.
# text = The Ten Degree Channel divides the Andamans, which are the larger and more heavily populated northern islands, from the 20 or so Nicobar Islands in the south.
# text = On South Andaman, the most heavily populated island, is Port Blair, which is the capital and the only large town in the entire archipelago.
# text = Travel to the Nicobar Islands is forbidden to non-Indians, and they are also not allowed in some parts of South Andaman Island.
# text = Ramtanu Maitra writes for a number of international journals and is a regular contributor to the Washington-based EIR and the New Delhi-based Indian Defense Review.
# text = He also writes for Aakrosh, India's defense-tied quarterly journal.
# text = [ Karzai also has to deal with the stepped up rivalry between India and Pakistan in Afghanistan.
# text = Islamabad accuses New Delhi of using its consulates in Kandahar and Jalalabad to train Balochi insurgents who are active in Pakistani Balochistan.
# text = Pakistani officials claim there are as many as 42 RAW agents based in Kandahar and another 12 in Jalalabad.
# text = “There have no business being there unless they are undermining Pakistan,’’ says a Pakistani official.
# text = Both India and Afghanistan deny the claim.
# text = ‘’Should Pakistan show us any evidence of an Indian hand using Afghan soil to work against our neighbours we will take it very seriously,” says Amrullah Saleh the head of Afghanistan’s National Security Directorate. ]
# text = Karzai, Musharraf new regional equations
# text = KABUL:
# text = For the past 25 years landlocked Afghanistan has suffered from constant interference from its neighbours - Pakistan, Iran and the Central Asian Republics - and regional powers -Russia and India.
# text = The neighbours are still interfering, but there are signs that rather than undermining Afghanistan’s stability they may now be trying to strengthen it.
# text = “The elections should be a reassurance to all our neighbours that a stable Afghanistan, a peaceful Afghanistan is good for all.
# text = Nobody should feel a looser in Afghanistan,’’ President Hamid Karzai told Pakistan’s English daily The Nation.
# text = All the regional countries have publicly backed the Karzai government and supported the electoral process, but serious undercurrents remain as they all have their favourite contenders in Afghanistan.
# text = Since September 11, Pakistan has been repeatedly accused by Afghan and Western leaders of harbouring Taliban extremists who had pledged to disrupt the elections, but at the highest level the US has avoided criticising President Pervaiz Musharraf on the grounds that he is helping the US catch Al Qaeda elements inside Pakistan.
# text = That changed on September 22 when President George W. Bush, Musharraf and Karzai held a three way meeting in New York on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly.
# text = The meeting was pushed together by the CIA and the US Defence Department who were desperately anxious to secure a peaceful election in Afghanistan and the non-interference of alleged Pakistani backed Taliban.
# text = Western and Afghan diplomats intimately involved with the meeting, said Bush pushed Musharraf hard on reigning in the Taliban so the elections could take place peacefully.
# text = ‘’Where are Mullah Omar, Mullah Usmani and Gulbuddin Hikmetar?’’
# text = Bush is reported to have asked a flustered Musharraf.
# text = All three are extremist Taliban or their allies and known to be living in Pakistan.
# text = (Mullah Omar is leader of the Taliban, Usmani is the former corps commander of Kandahar under the Taliban regime and now a commander of Taliban forces while Hikmetyar heads the extremist Hizb-e-Islami.)
# text = ‘’It was the first time that Bush totally focused on the Taliban threat rather than Al Qaeda with the Pakistanis,’’ says a Western diplomat.
# text = ‘’Bush was very well briefed before the meeting,’’ the diplomat said.
# text = An Afghan official at the meeting added, ‘’The Americans now realise that the Taliban are a bigger threat to our security than Al Qaeda.’’
# text = Karzai was clearly pleased at the results.
# text = ‘’President Musharraf promised to help us and cooperate with us on curbing terrorist activity by the Taliban,’’ says Karzai.
# text = The next day an angry Musharraf categorically said that Pakistan would not send Pakistani troops to Iraq, a clear snub to the Americans.
# text = Until then he had said Pakistan’s options were open.
# text = However Pakistani officials insist that the decision was unconnected to the tripartite meeting.
# text = US and NATO military officers in Kabul say it is too early to say whether Bush’s tough message was instrumental in persuading Musharraf and the ISI to pressure the Taliban to restrain from disrupting the elections.
# text = However there were visible signs of a crackdown on the Pakistan side.
# text = ‘’Pakistan now has a large force deployed in Baluchistan which was not there before,’’ says Lt. General David Barno.
# text = ‘’There is much better tactical cooperation between our forces on both sides of the border, but the movement of Taliban still goes on both ways,’’ he adds.
# text = Also several days before the elections Pakistan closed the border crossing point at Chaman in Baluchistan which is a key entry point for the Taliban into Afghanistan.
# text = However US military officers say regular army officers - many of them Pashtun - leading units of the Frontier Corps who are on the border remain deeply sympathetic to the Taliban and the mullahs of the JUI.
# text = At the same time the US remains oblivious of the serious problems and political fallout which the army is facing in its operations in Waziristan.
# text = Not only is the army facing serious political fallout, growing anti-Americanism and anti-army feeling in the tribal areas but it is also taking heavy casualties -between 400-500 Pakistani soldiers have been killed in the region since March.
# text = Musharraf has always maintained that the US has never provided actionable intelligence about Taliban leaders hiding in Baluchistan.
# text = That too may change.
# text = US and Afghan intelligence will shortly be presenting the ISI with a list of Taliban extremists and their suspected whereabouts.
# text = Moreover there are now major covert attempts under way to try and bring back to Kabul leading Taliban commanders, who have been living quietly in Pakistan and have taken no part in the Taliban insurgency.
# text = With the Taliban failure to disrupt the Afghan elections, the militants are even more isolated from the mainstream Taliban who want to return home.
# text = Until now Pakistan has not facilitated such a return and clearly it cannot happen until there is both a pull from Kabul and a push from Islamabad.
# text = With President Karzai certain to win the elections and the demotion of key former Northern Alliance figures such as General Fahim and warlord Ismail Khan, there is now little reason for moderate Taliban leaders to fear reprisals from former Northern Alliance figures if they return home.
# text = Their removal should also provide increased motivation for Pakistan to help the return of moderate Taliban.
# text = Afghan officials welcomed the appointment on October 3 of Lt. General Ashfaq Kiyani as the new ISI chief.
# text = Kayani is well known and liked in Kabul as during the last year he led the Pakistani delegation in the tripartite military meetings with the Afghan and US military on issues related to border issues.
# text = Karzai also has to deal with the stepped up rivalry between India and Pakistan in Afghanistan.
# text = Islamabad accuses New Delhi of using its consulates in Kandahar and Jalalabad to train Balochi insurgents who are active in Pakistani Balochistan.
# text = Pakistani officials claim there are as many as 42 RAW agents based in Kandahar and another 12 in Jalalabad.
# text = “There have no business being there unless they are undermining Pakistan,’’ says a Pakistani official.
# text = Both India and Afghanistan deny the claim.
# text = ‘’Should Pakistan show us any evidence of an Indian hand using Afghan soil to work against our neighbours we will take it very seriously,” says Amrullah Saleh the head of Afghanistan’s National Security Directorate.
# text = Karzai categorically said that he has assured Musharraf repeatedly that any adverse action against Pakistan taken by Indian diplomats inside Afghanistan would be acted upon swiftly.
# text = Senior US diplomats and military officials have warned India also.
# text = In a major regional shift reflecting the newly strengthened position of Karzai, Iran, Russia and India which have traditionally backed the Tajik dominated former Northern Alliance made strenuous efforts to convince presidential candidate Younis Qanooni to strike a deal with Karzai before the elections and not to oppose Karzai.
# text = Iran in particular feared that Qanooni would loose and then be politically isolated from the mainstream.
# text = Qanooni refused to accept the Iranian advice as his fellow Panjsheri Tajiks urged him to stand against Karzai.
# text = However since the elections Iranian influence has proved critical in convincing the Hazara Shia candidate Mohammed Mohaqeq to accept the results of the elections and later convincing Qanooni to do the same.
# text = With the US military presence posing a threat on their borders in both Iraq and Afghanistan, Iran’s moderate leadership is keen to help stabilise Karzai so that the US presence in Afghanistan is reduced.
# text = However powerful hardliners in Tehran may be trying to undermine that strategy and a new issue is likely to deepen the rift with the moderates.
# text = Iranian officials are deeply concerned about the US occupation of Shindand, a massive Soviet-era airbase just 30 kilometres from Iran’s border.
# text = The enhanced US presence in western Afghanistan was only made possible after the ousting of Ismail Khan, the warlord and Governor of Herat province last month, who was a close ally of Iranian hardliners.
# text = Iranian officials say they made no objections to Khan’s ouster because they want to strengthen Karzai’s campaign against warlords.
# text = At a time of heightened tensions between Tehran and Washington over Iran’s nuclear weapons program and calls by neo-conservatives in Washington that a second Bush term should deal with Iran aggressively, the Iranians fear that Shindand could be used as a listening post, spying facility and even a launching pad for any future US actions against Iran.
# text = Afghan officials say the Americans have moved over 100 Special Forces and helicopters to Shindand.
# text = However General Barno insists the US presence poses no threat to Iran.
# text = ‘’We have a very small number of forces in Shindand with a few helicopters,’’ says Barno.
# text = Nevertheless this places Karzai in a difficult and sensitive situation because he has to maintain excellent relations with both the US and Iran.
# text = ‘’Afghanistan has had the benefit of cooperation from both the US and Iran.
# text = So far what they have done together has been good for us and that’s how we would like to keep it’’, says Karzai.
# text = Nobody can claim that the interference of Afghanistan’s neighbours is over, but the elections will do much to strengthen Karzai and deal more firmly with neighbours’ interference.
# text = In the post election scenario it is becoming abundantly clear that the Taliban do not have the support of the Afghan people nor the Afghan Pashtuns.
# text = In a highly significant move Afghan Pashtun tribes along the Pakistan border warned the Taliban in Quetta and Chaman that if they try and disrupt the elections, they would be resisted.
# text = Many Taliban living in Afghanistan voted for President Karzai.
# text = It is now abundantly clear that with the rapidly changing face of Afghanistan, the demise of key Northern Alliance figures and the fluid political situation in Afghanistan, Pakistan should reconsider its policy of giving unlimited sanctuary to Taliban extremists living on Pakistani soil.
# text = Pakistan Link 16/10/2004
# text = The debate that a handful of Texas multi-millionnaires close to the Bush family have cleverly manufactured over John Kerry's war record is absurd in every way.
# text = The charges that they have put some vets up to making against Kerry are false and can be demonstrated by the historical record to be false .
# text = Most of those making the charges have even flip-flopped, contradicting themselves.
# text = Or they weren't eyewitnesses and are just lying.
# text = But to address the substance of this Big Lie is to risk falling into its logic.
# text = The true absurdity of the entire situation is easily appreciated when we consider that George W. Bush never showed any bravery at all at any point in his life.
# text = He has never lived in a war zone.
# text = If some of John Kerry's wounds were superficial, Bush received no wounds.
# text = (And, a piece of shrapnel in the forearm that caused only a minor wound would have killed had it hit an eye and gone into the brain; the shrapnel being in your body demonstrates you were in mortal danger and didn't absent yourself from it.
# text = That is the logic of the medal).
# text = Kerry saved a man's life while under fire.
# text = Bush did no such thing.
# text = What was Bush doing with his youth?
# text = He was drinking.
# text = He was drinking like a fish, every night, into the wee hours.
# text = For decades.
# text = He gave no service to anyone, risked nothing, and did not even slack off efficiently.
# text = The history of alcoholism and possibly other drug use is a key issue because it not only speaks to Bush's character as an addictive personality, but may tell us something about his erratic and alarming actions as president.
# text = His explosive temper probably provoked the disastrous siege of Fallujah last spring, killing 600 Iraqis, most of them women and children, in revenge for the deaths of 4 civilian mercenaries, one of them a South African.
# text = (Newsweek reported that Bush commanded his cabinet, "Let heads roll!")
# text = That temper is only one problem.
# text = Bush has a sadistic streak.
# text = He clearly enjoyed, as governor, watching executions.
# text = His delight in killing people became a campaign issue in 2000 when he seemed, in one debate, to enjoy the prospect of executing wrong-doers a little too much.
# text = He has clearly gone on enjoying killing people on a large scale in Iraq.
# text = Drug abuse can affect the ability of the person to feel deep emotions like empathy.
# text = Two decades of pickling his nervous system in various highly toxic substances have left Bush damaged goods.
# text = Even for those who later abstain, "visual-spatial abilities, abstraction, problem solving , and short-term memory, are the slowest to recover."
# text = That he managed to get on the wagon (though with that pretzel incident, you wonder how firmly) is laudable.
# text = But he suffers the severe effects of the aftermath, and we are all suffering along with him now, since he is the most powerful man in the world.
# text = We all know by now that Bush did not even do his full service with the Texas Air National Guard, absenting himself to work on the Alabama senate campaign of Winton "Red" Blount.
# text = Whether he was actually AWOL during this stint is unclear.
# text = But it is clear that not only did Bush slack off on his National Guard service, but he slacked off from his campaign work.
# text = This little-noted interview with Blount's nephew Murph Archibald, which appeared on National Public Radio's "All Things Considered on March 30, 2004, gives a devastating insight into what it was like to have to suffer through Bush in that period.
# text = "All Things Considered (8:00 PM ET) - NPR March 30, 2004 Tuesday
# text = This campaign season, there have been questions about whether George W. Bush fulfilled his obligations to the National Guard as a young lieutenant in the early 1970s.
# text = For weeks, reporters scoured Alabama in search of pilots or anyone who might have remembered seeing Mr. Bush at the time he was serving in the National Guard there.
# text = There is one place in Alabama where Mr. Bush was present nearly every day: the headquarters in Montgomery of US Senate candidate Winton "Red" Blount.
# text = President Bush has always said that working for Blount was the reason he transferred to the Alabama Air National Guard.
# text = NPR's Wade Goodwyn has this report about Mr. Bush's time on that campaign.
# text = WADE GOODWYN reporting:
# text = In 1972, Baba Groom was a smart, funny young woman smack-dab in the middle of an exciting US Senate campaign.
# text = Groom was Republican Red Blount's scheduler, and in that job, she was the hub in the campaign wheel.
# text = Ask her about the handsome young man from Texas, and she remembers him 32 years later like it was yesterday.
# text = Ms. BABA GROOM (Former Campaign Worker):
# text = He would wear khaki trousers and some old jacket.
# text = He was always ready to go out on the road.
# text = On the phone, you could hear his accent.
# text = It was a Texas accent.
# text = But he just melded with everybody.
# text = GOODWYN: The candidate Mr. Bush was working for, Red Blount, had gotten rich in Alabama in the construction business.
# text = Prominent Southern Republicans were something of a rare breed in those days.
# text = Blount's support of the party led him to be appointed Richard Nixon's postmaster general.
# text = In Washington, Blount became friends and tennis partners with Mr. Bush's father, then Congressman Bush.
# text = That was how 26-year-old Lieutenant Bush came to Montgomery, at his father's urging . . .
# text = It was Mr. Bush's job to organize the Republican county chairpersons in the 67 Alabama counties.
# text = Back in 1972 in the Deep South, many rural counties didn't have much in the way of official Republican Party apparatus.
# text = But throughout Alabama, there were Republicans and Democrats who wanted to help Red Blount.
# text = It was the young Texan's job to find out what each county leader needed in the way of campaign supplies and get those supplies to them.
# text = Groom says this job helped Mr. Bush understand how even in a statewide Senate campaign, politics are local.
# text = . . . Murph Archibald is Red Blount's nephew by marriage, and in 1972, he was coming off a 15-month tour in Vietnam in the infantry.
# text = Archibald says that in a campaign full of dedicated workers, Mr. Bush was not one of them.
# text = Mr. MURPH ARCHIBALD (Nephew of Red Blount): Well, I was coming in early in the morning and leaving in mid-evenings.
# text = Ordinarily, George would come in around noon; he would ordinarily leave around 5:30 or 6:00 in the evening.
# text = GOODWYN: Archibald says that two months before the election, in September of '72, Red Blount's campaign manager came to him and asked that he quietly take over Mr. Bush's job because the campaign materials were not getting out to the counties.
# text = Mr. ARCHIBALD: George certainly didn't seem to have any concerns about my taking over this work with the campaign workers there.
# text = My overall impression was that he didn't seem as interested in the campaign as the other people who were working at the state headquarters.
# text = GOODWYN: Murph Archibald says that at first, he didn't know that Mr. Bush was serving in the Air National Guard.
# text = After he found out from somebody else, Archibald attempted to talk to Mr. Bush about it.
# text = The president was a lieutenant and Archibald had been a lieutenant, too; he figured they had something to talk about.
# text = Mr. ARCHIBALD: George didn't have any interest at all in talking about the military.
# text = In fact, when I broached the subject with him, he simply changed the subject.
# text = He wasn't unpleasant about it, but he just changed the subject and wouldn't talk about it.
# text = GOODWYN: Far from Texas and Washington, DC, Mr. Bush enjoyed his freedom.
# text = He dated a beautiful young woman working on the campaign.
# text = He went out in the evenings and had a good time.
# text = In fact, he left the house he rented in such disrepair--with damage to the walls and a chandelier destroyed--that the Montgomery family who owned it still grumble about the unpaid repair bill.
# text = Archibald says Mr. Bush would come into the office and, in a friendly way, offer up stories about the drinking he'd done the night before, kind of as a conversation starter.
# text = Mr. ARCHIBALD: People have different ways of starting the days in any office.
# text = They're going to talk about their kids, they're going to talk about football, they're going to talk about the weather.
# text = And this was simply his opening gambit; he would start talking about that he had been out late the night before drinking.
# text = GOODWYN: Archibald says the frequency with which Mr. Bush discussed the subject was off-putting to him.

# text = CRACKDOWN ON POLYGAMY GROUP
# text = Small polygamous groups have existed in the southwestern US under the watchful yet fairly benign eye of authorities ever since a sect known as the Fundamentalist Latter Day Saints (FLDS) separated itself from mainstream Mormonism in 1890.
# text = ...
# text = Now, FLDS leader Warren Jeffs has been added to the FBI's list of "Ten Most Wanted Fugitives," a move that caps law enforcement's dramatic change of approach toward the polygamous group in recent years...[because of] the impact that the group's practices, law enforcement officials say, are having on the most vulnerable within the sect, particularly children and women.
# text = When the FLDS under Mr. Jeffs (and his father before him) grew to some 10,000 followers in several southwestern communities with estimated assets of $110 million; when it became clear that government officials, school authorities, and police in those communities had become intertwined with the sect; when ex-members increasingly reported child and sexual abuse charges (mainly involving underage girls forced to marry older men); and when the sect began to use secluded compounds, state and federal authorities started to crack down more vigorously.
# text = ...
# text = Specifically, Jeffs is charged in Utah and Arizona with sexual assault of underage girls and with arranging "spiritual" marriages for girls and older men.
# text = At weekend press conferences in Salt Lake City and Phoenix, FBI and state officials said Jeffs "is considered armed and dangerous and may be traveling with armed bodyguards."

# text = It is the text of a speech given by an Arab gentleman before the advisory board of a large multi-nation corporation.

# text = "A View from the Eye of the Storm"
# text = Talk delivered by Haim Harari at a meeting of the International Advisory Board of a large multi-national corporation, April, 2004:
# text = "As you know, I usually provide the scientific and technological "entertainment" in our meetings, but, on this occasion, our Chairman suggested that I present my own personal view on events in the part of the world from which I come.
# text = I have never been and I will never be a Government official and I have no privileged information.
# text = My perspective is entirely based on what I see, on what I read and on the fact that my family has lived in this region for almost 200 years.
# text = You may regard my views as those of the proverbial taxi driver, which you are supposed to question, when you visit a country.
# text = I could have shared with you some fascinating facts and some personal thoughts about the Israeli-Arab conflict.
# text = However, I will touch upon it only in passing.
# text = I prefer to devote most of my remarks to the broader picture of the region and its place in world events.
# text = I refer to the entire area between Pakistan and Morocco, which is predominantly Arab, predominantly Moslem, but includes many non-Arab and also significant non-Moslem minorities.
# text = Why do I put aside Israel and its own immediate neighborhood?
# text = Because Israel and any problems related to it, in spite of what you might read or hear in the world media, is not the central issue, and has never been the central issue in the upheaval in the region.
# text = Yes, there is a 100 year-old Israeli-Arab conflict, but it is not where the main show is.
# text = The millions who died in the Iran-Iraq war had nothing to do with Israel.
# text = The mass murder happening right now in Sudan, where the Arab Moslem regime is massacring its black Christian citizens, has nothing to do with Israel.
# text = The frequent reports from Algeria about the murders of hundreds of civilians in one village or another by other Algerians have nothing to do with Israel.
# text = Saddam Hussein did not invade Kuwait, endanger Saudi Arabia and butcher his own people because of Israel.
# text = Egypt did not use poison gas against Yemen in the 60's because of Israel.
# text = Assad the Father did not kill tens of thousands of his own citizens in one week in El Hamma in Syria because of Israel.
# text = The Taliban control of Afghanistan and the civil war there had nothing to do with Israel.
# text = The Libyan blowing up of the Pan-Am flight had nothing to do with Israel, and I could go on and on and on.
# text = The root of the trouble is that this entire Moslem region is totally dysfunctional, by any standard of the word, and would have been so even if Israel had joined the Arab league and an independent Palestine had existed for 100 years.
# text = The 22 member countries of the Arab league, from Mauritania to the Gulf States, have a total population of 300 millions, larger than the US and almost as large as the EU before its expansion.
# text = They have a land area larger than either the US or all of Europe.
# text = These 22 countries, with all their oil and natural resources, have a combined GDP smaller than that of Netherlands plus Belgium and equal to half of the GDP of California alone.
# text = Within this meager GDP, the gaps between rich and poor are beyond belief and too many of the rich made their money not by succeeding in business, but by being corrupt rulers.
# text = The social status of women is far below what it was in the Western World 150 years ago.
# text = Human rights are below any reasonable standard, in spite of the grotesque fact that Libya was elected Chair of the UN Human Rights commission.
# text = According to a report prepared by a committee of Arab intellectuals and published under the auspices of the U.N., the number of books translated by the entire Arab world is much smaller than what little Greece alone translates.
# text = The total number of scientific publications of 300 million Arabs is less than that of 6 million Israelis.
# text = Birth rates in the region are very high, increasing the poverty, the social gaps and the cultural decline.
# text = And all of this is happening in a region, which only 30 years ago, was believed to be the next wealthy part of the world, and in a Moslem area, which developed, at some point in history, one of the most advanced cultures in the world.
# text = It is fair to say that this creates an unprecedented breeding ground for cruel dictators, terror networks, fanaticism, incitement, suicide murders and general decline.
# text = It is also a fact that almost everybody in the region blames this situation on the United States, on Israel, on Western Civilization, on Judaism and Christianity, on anyone and anything, except themselves.
# text = A word about the millions of decent, honest, good people who are either devout Moslems or are not very religious but grew up in Moslem families: They are double victims of an outside world, which now develops Islamophobia, and of their own environment which breaks their heart by being totally dysfunctional.
# text = The problem is that the vast silent majority of these Moslems are not part of the terror and the incitement, but they also do not stand up against it.
# text = They become accomplices, by omission, and this applies to political leaders, intellectuals, business people and many others.
# text = Many of them can certainly tell right from wrong, but are afraid to express their views.
# text = The events of the last few years have amplified four issues, which have always existed, but have never been as rampant as in the present upheaval in the region.
# text = A few more years may pass before everybody acknowledges that it is a World War, but we are already well into it.
# text = These are the four main pillars of the current World Conflict, or perhaps we should already refer to it as "the undeclared World War III":
# text = *1. The first element is the suicide murder.*
# text = Suicide murders are not a new invention but they have been made popular, if I may use this expression, only lately.
# text = Even after September 11, it seems that most of the Western World does not yet understand this weapon.
# text = It is a very potent psychological weapon.
# text = Its real direct impact is relatively minor.
# text = The total number of casualties from hundreds of suicide murders within Israel in the last three years is much smaller than those due to car accidents.
# text = September 11 was quantitatively much less lethal than many earthquakes
# text = More people die from AIDS in one day in Africa than all the Russians who died in the hands of Chechnya-based Moslem suicide murderers since that conflict started.
# text = Saddam killed every month more people than all those who died from suicide murders since the Coalition occupation of Iraq.
# text = So what is all the fuss about suicide killings?
# text = It creates headlines.
# text = It is spectacular.
# text = It is frightening.
# text = It is a very cruel death with bodies dismembered and horrible severe lifelong injuries to many of the wounded.
# text = It is always shown on television in great detail.
# text = One such murder, with the help of hysterical media coverage, can destroy the tourism industry of a country for quite a while, as it did in Bali and in Turkey.
# text = But the real fear comes from the undisputed fact that no defense and no preventive measures can succeed against a determined suicide murderer.
# text = This has not yet penetrated the thinking of the Western World.
# text = The U.S. and Europe are constantly improving their defense against the last murder, not the next one.
# text = We may arrange for the best airport security in the world.
# text = But if you want to murder by suicide, you do not have to board a plane in order to explode yourself and kill many people.
# text = Who could stop a suicide murder in the midst of the crowded line waiting to be checked by the airport metal detector?
# text = How about the lines to the check-in counters in a busy travel period?
# text = Put a metal detector in front of every train station in Spain and the terrorists will get the buses.
# text = Protect the buses and they will explode in movie theaters, concert halls, supermarkets, shopping malls, schools and hospitals.
# text = Put guards in front of every concert hall and there will always be a line of people to be checked by the guards and this line will be the target, not to speak of killing the guards themselves.
# text = You can somewhat reduce your vulnerability by preventive and defensive measures and by strict border controls but not eliminate it and definitely not win the war in a defensive way.
# text = And it is a war!
# text = What is behind the suicide murders?
# text = Money is, money and power and cold-blooded murderous incitement, nothing else.
# text = It has nothing to do with true fanatic religious beliefs.
# text = No Moslem preacher has ever blown himself up.
# text = No son of an Arab politician or religious leader has ever blown himself up.
# text = No relative of anyone influential has done it.
# text = Wouldn't you expect some of the religious leaders to do it themselves, or to talk their sons into doing it, if this is truly a supreme act of religious fervor?
# text = Aren't they interested in the benefits of going to Heaven?
# text = Instead, they send outcast women, naive children, retarded people and young incited hotheads.
# text = They promise them the delights, mostly sexual, of the next world, and pay their families handsomely after the supreme act is performed and enough innocent people are dead.
# text = Suicide murders also have nothing to do with poverty and despair.
# text = The poorest region in the world, by far, is Africa.
# text = It never happens there.
# text = There are numerous desperate people in the world, in different cultures, countries and continents.
# text = Desperation does not provide anyone with explosives, reconnaissance and transportation.
# text = There was certainly more despair in Saddam's Iraq than in Paul Bremmer's Iraq, and no one exploded himself.
# text = A suicide murder is simply a horrible, vicious weapon of cruel, inhuman, cynical, well-funded terrorists, with no regard to human life, including the life of their fellow countrymen, but with very high regard to their own affluent well-being and their hunger for power.
# text = The only way to fight this new "popular" weapon is identical to the only way in which you fight organized crime or pirates on the high seas: the offensive way.
# text = Like in the case of organized crime, it is crucial that the forces on the offensive be united and it is crucial to reach the top of the crime pyramid.
# text = You cannot eliminate organized crime by arresting the little drug dealer on the street corner.
# text = You must go after the head of the "Family".
# text = If part of the public supports it, others tolerate it, many are afraid of it and some try to explain it away by poverty or by a miserable childhood, organized crime will thrive and so will terrorism.
# text = The United States understands this now, after September 11.
# text = Russia is beginning to understand it.
# text = Turkey understands it well.
# text = I am very much afraid that most of Europe still does not understand it.
# text = Unfortunately, it seems that Europe will understand it only after suicide murders arrive in Europe in a big way.
# text = In my humble opinion, this will definitely happen.
# text = The Spanish trains and the Istanbul bombings are only the beginning.
# text = The unity of the Civilized World in fighting this horror is absolutely indispensable.
# text = Until Europe wakes up, this unity will not be achieved.
# text = *2. The second ingredient is words, more precisely lies.*
# text = Words can be lethal.
# text = They kill people.
# text = It is often said that politicians, diplomats and perhaps also lawyers and business people must sometimes lie, as part of their professional life.
# text = But the norms of politics and diplomacy are childish, in comparison with the level of incitement and total absolute deliberate fabrications, which have reached new heights in the region we are talking about.
# text = An incredible number of people in the Arab world believe that September 11 never happened, or was an American provocation or, even better, a Jewish plot.
# text = You all remember the Iraqi Minister of Information, Mr. Mouhamad Said al-Sahaf and his press conferences when the US forces were already inside Baghdad.
# text = Disinformation at time of war is an accepted tactic.
# text = But to stand, day after day, and to make such preposterous statements, known to everybody to be lies, without even being ridiculed in your own milieu, can only happen in this region.
# text = Mr. Sahaf eventually became a popular icon as a court jester, but this did not stop some allegedly respectable newspapers from giving him equal time.
# text = It also does not prevent the Western press from giving credence, every day, even now, to similar liars.
# text = After all, if you want to be an anti-Semite, there are subtle ways of doing it.
# text = You do not have to claim that the holocaust never happened, and that the Jewish temple in Jerusalem never existed.
# text = But millions of Moslems are told by their leaders that this is the case.
# text = When these same leaders make other statements, the Western media report them as if they could be true.
# text = It is a daily occurrence that the same people who finance, arm and dispatch suicide murderers, condemn the act in English in front of western TV cameras, talking to a world audience, which even partly believes them.
# text = It is a daily routine to hear the same leader making opposite statements in Arabic to his people and in English to the rest of the world.
# text = Incitement by Arab TV, accompanied by horror pictures of mutilated bodies, has become a powerful weapon of those who lie, distort and want to destroy everything.
# text = Little children are raised on deep hatred and on admiration of so-called martyrs, and the Western World does not notice it because its own TV sets are mostly tuned to soap operas and game shows.
# text = I recommend to you, even though most of you do not understand Arabic, to watch Al Jazeera, from time to time.
# text = You will not believe your own eyes.
# text = But words also work in other ways, more subtle.
# text = A demonstration in Berlin, carrying banners supporting Saddam's regime and featuring three-year old babies dressed as suicide murderers, is defined by the press and by political leaders as a "peace demonstration".
# text = You may support or oppose the Iraq war, but to refer to fans of Saddam, Arafat or Bin Laden as peace activists is a bit too much.
# text = A woman walks into an Israeli restaurant in mid-day, eats, observes families with old people and children eating their lunch in the adjacent tables and pays the bill.
# text = She then blows herself up, killing 20 people, including many children, with heads and arms rolling around in the restaurant.
# text = Dignitaries condemn the act but visit her bereaved family and the money flows.
# text = There is a new game in town: The actual murderer is called "the military wing", the one who pays him, equips him and sends him is now called "the political wing" and the head of the operation is called the "spiritual leader".
# text = There are numerous other examples of such Orwellian nomenclature, used every day not only by terror chiefs but also by Western media.
# text = These words are much more dangerous than many people realize.
# text = They provide an emotional infrastructure for atrocities.
# text = It was Joseph Goebbels who said that if you repeat a lie often enough, people will believe it.
# text = He is now being outperformed by his successors.
# text = *3. The third aspect is money.*
# text = Huge amounts of money, which could have solved many social problems in this dysfunctional part of the world, are channeled into three concentric spheres supporting death and murder.
# text = In the inner circle are the terrorists themselves.
# text = The money funds their travel, explosives, hideouts and permanent search for soft vulnerable targets.
# text = The inner circles are primarily financed by terrorist states like Iran and Syria, until recently also by Iraq and Libya and earlier also by some of the Communist regimes.
# text = These states, as well as the Palestinian Authority, are the safe havens of the wholesale murder vendors.
# text = They are surrounded by a second wider circle of direct supporters, planners, commanders, preachers, all of whom make a living, usually a very comfortable living, by serving as terror infrastructure.
# text = Finally, we find the third circle of so-called religious, educational and welfare organizations, which actually do some good, feed the hungry and provide some schooling, but brainwash a new generation with hatred, lies and ignorance.
# text = This circle operates mostly through mosques, madrasas and other religious establishments but also through inciting electronic and printed media.
# text = It is this circle that makes sure that women remain inferior, that democracy is unthinkable and that exposure to the outside world is minimal.
# text = It is also that circle that leads the way in blaming everybody outside the Moslem world, for the miseries of the region.
# text = The outer circle is largely financed by Saudi Arabia, but also by donations from certain Moslem communities in the United States and Europe and, to a smaller extent, by donations of European Governments to various NGO's and by certain United Nations organizations, whose goals may be noble, but they are infested and exploited by agents of the outer circle.
# text = The Saudi regime, of course, will be the next victim of major terror, when the inner circle will explode into the outer circle.
# text = The Saudis are beginning to understand it, but they fight the inner circles, while still financing the infrastructure at the outer circle.
# text = Figuratively speaking, this outer circle is the guardian, which makes sure that the people look and listen inwards to the inner circle of terror and incitement, rather than to the world outside.
# text = Some parts of this same outer circle actually operate as a result of fear from, or blackmail by, the inner circles.
# text = The horrifying added factor is the high birth rate.
# text = Half of the population of the Arab world is under the age of 20, the most receptive age to incitement, guaranteeing two more generations of blind hatred.
# text = Some of the leaders of these various circles live very comfortably on their loot.
# text = You meet their children in the best private schools in Europe, not in the training camps of suicide murderers.
# text = The Jihad "soldiers" join packaged death tours to Iraq and other hotspots, while some of their leaders ski in Switzerland.
# text = Mrs. Arafat, who lives in Paris with her daughter, receives tens of thousands of dollars per month from the allegedly bankrupt Palestinian Authority, while a typical local ringleader of the Al-Aksa brigade, reporting to Arafat, receives only a cash payment of a couple of hundred dollars, for performing murders at the retail level.
# text = *4. The fourth element of the current world conflict is the total breaking of all laws.*
# text = The civilized world believes in democracy, the rule of law, including international law, human rights, free speech and free press, among other liberties.
# text = There are naive old-fashioned habits such as respecting religious sites and symbols, not using ambulances and hospitals for acts of war, avoiding the mutilation of dead bodies and not using children as human shields or human bombs.
# text = Never in history, not even in the Nazi period, was there such total disregard of all of the above as we observe now.
# text = Every student of political science debates how you prevent an anti-democratic force from winning a democratic election and abolishing democracy.
# text = Other aspects of a civilized society must also have limitations.
# text = Can a policeman open fire on someone trying to kill him?
# text = Can a government listen to phone conversations of terrorists and drug dealers?
# text = Does free speech protect you when you shout "fire" in a crowded theater?
# text = Should there be death penalty, for deliberate multiple murders?
# text = These are the old-fashioned dilemmas.
# text = But now we have an entire new set.
# text = Do you raid a mosque, which serves as a terrorist ammunition storage?
# text = Do you return fire, if you are attacked from a hospital?
# text = Do you storm a church taken over by terrorists who took the priests hostages?
# text = Do you search every ambulance after a few suicide murderers use ambulances to reach their targets?
# text = Do you strip every woman because one pretended to be pregnant and carried a suicide bomb on her belly?
# text = Do you shoot back at someone trying to kill you, standing deliberately behind a group of children?
# text = Do you raid terrorist headquarters, hidden in a mental hospital?
# text = Do you shoot an arch-murderer who deliberately moves from one location to another, always surrounded by children?
# text = All of these happen daily in Iraq and in the Palestinian areas.
# text = What do you do?
# text = Well, you do not want to face the dilemma.
# text = But it cannot be avoided.
# text = Suppose, for the sake of discussion, that someone would openly stay in a well-known address in Teheran, hosted by the Iranian Government and financed by it, executing one atrocity after another in Spain or in France, killing hundreds of innocent people, accepting responsibility for the crimes, promising in public TV interviews to do more of the same, while the Government of Iran issues public condemnations of his acts but continues to host him, invite him to official functions and treat him as a great dignitary.
# text = I leave it to you as homework to figure out what Spain or France would have done, in such a situation.
# text = The problem is that the civilized world is still having illusions about the rule of law in a totally lawless environment.
# text = It is trying to play ice hockey by sending a ballerina ice-skater into the ring or to knock out a heavyweight boxer by a chess player.
# text = In the same way that no country has a law against cannibals eating its prime minister, because such an act is unthinkable, international law does not address killers shooting from hospitals, mosques and ambulances, while being protected by their Government or society.
# text = International law does not know how to handle someone who sends children to throw stones, stands behind them and shoots with immunity and cannot be arrested because he is sheltered by a Government.
# text = International law does not know how to deal with a leader of murderers who is royally and comfortably hosted by a country, which pretends to condemn his acts or just claims to be too weak to arrest him.
# text = The amazing thing is that all of these crooks demand protection under international law, and define all those who attack them as "war criminals," with some Western media repeating the allegations.
# text = The good news is that all of this is temporary, because the evolution of international law has always adapted itself to reality.
# text = The punishment for suicide murder should be death or arrest before the murder, not during and not after.
# text = After every world war, the rules of international law have changed, and the same will happen after the present one.
# text = But during the twilight zone, a lot of harm can be done.
# text = The picture I described here is not pretty.
# text = What can we do about it?
# text = In the short run, only fight and win.
# text = In the long run, only educate the next generation and open it to the world.
# text = The inner circles can and must be destroyed by force.
# text = The outer circle cannot be eliminated by force.
# text = Here we need financial starvation of the organizing elite, more power to women, more education, counter-propaganda, boycott whenever feasible and access to Western media, internet and the international scene.
# text = Above all, we need a total absolute unity and determination of the civilized world against all three circles of evil.
# text = Allow me, for a moment, to depart from my alleged role as a taxi driver and return to science.
# text = When you have a malignant tumor, you may remove the tumor itself surgically.
# text = You may also starve it by preventing new blood from reaching it from other parts of the body, thereby preventing new "supplies" from expanding the tumor.
# text = If you want to be sure, it is best to do both.
# text = But before you fight and win, by force or otherwise, you have to realize that you are in a war, and this may take Europe a few more years.
# text = In order to win, it is necessary to first eliminate the terrorist regimes, so that no Government in the world will serve as a safe haven for these people.
# text = I do not want to comment here on whether the American-led attack on Iraq was justified from the point of view of weapons of mass destruction or any other pre-war argument, but I can look at the post-war map of Western Asia.
# text = Now that Afghanistan, Iraq and Libya are out, two and a half terrorist states remain: Iran, Syria and Lebanon, the latter being a Syrian colony.
# text = Perhaps Sudan should be added to the list.
# text = As a result of the conquest of Afghanistan and Iraq, both Iran and Syria are now totally surrounded by territories unfriendly to them.
# text = Iran is encircled by Afghanistan, by the Gulf States, Iraq and the Moslem republics of the former Soviet Union.
# text = Syria is surrounded by Turkey, Iraq, Jordan and Israel.
# text = This is a significant strategic change and it applies strong pressure on the terrorist countries.
# text = It is not surprising that Iran is so active in trying to incite a Shiite uprising in Iraq.
# text = I do not know if the American plan was actually to encircle both Iran and Syria, but that is the resulting situation.
# text = In my humble opinion, the number one danger to the world today is Iran and its regime.
# text = It definitely has ambitions to rule vast areas and to expand in all directions.
# text = It has an ideology which claims supremacy over Western culture.
# text = It is ruthless.
# text = It has proven that it can execute elaborate terrorist acts without leaving too many traces, using Iranian Embassies.
# text = It is clearly trying to develop nuclear weapons.
# text = Its so-called moderates and conservatives play their own virtuoso version of the "good-cop versus bad-cop" game.
# text = Iran sponsors Syrian terrorism, it is certainly behind much of the action in Iraq, it is fully funding the Hezbollah and, through it, the Palestinian Hamas and Islamic Jihad; it performed acts of terror at least in Europe and in South America and probably also in Uzbekistan and Saudi Arabia and it truly leads a multi-national terror consortium, which includes, as minor players, Syria, Lebanon and certain Shiite elements in Iraq.
# text = Nevertheless, most European countries still trade with Iran, try to appease it and refuse to read the clear signals.
# text = In order to win the war it is also necessary to dry the financial resources of the terror conglomerate.
# text = It is pointless to try to understand the subtle differences between the Sunni terror of Al Qaeda and Hamas and the Shiite terror of Hezbollah, Sadr and other Iranian-inspired enterprises.
# text = When it serves their business needs, all of them collaborate beautifully.
# text = It is crucial to stop Saudi and other financial support of the outer circle, which is the fertile breeding ground of terror.
# text = It is important to monitor all donations from the Western World to Islamic organizations, to monitor the finances of international relief organizations and to react with forceful economic measures to any small sign of financial aid to any of the three circles of terrorism.
# text = It is also important to act decisively against the campaign of lies and fabrications and to monitor those Western media who collaborate with it out of naivety, financial interests or ignorance.
# text = Above all, never surrender to terror.
# text = No one will ever know whether the recent elections in Spain would have yielded a different result, if not for the train bombings a few days earlier.
# text = But it really does not matter.
# text = What matters is that the terrorists believe that they caused the result and that they won by driving Spain out of Iraq.
# text = The Spanish story will surely end up being extremely costly to other European countries, including France, who is now expelling inciting preachers and forbidding veils and including others who sent troops to Iraq.
# text = In the long run, Spain itself will pay even more.
# text = Is the solution a democratic Arab world?
# text = If by democracy we mean free elections but also free press, free speech, a functioning judicial system, civil liberties, equality to women, free international travel, exposure to international media and ideas, laws against racial incitement and against defamation, and avoidance of lawless behavior regarding hospitals, places of worship and children, then yes, democracy is the solution.
# text = If democracy is just free elections, it is likely that the most fanatic regime will be elected, the one whose incitement and fabrications are the most inflammatory.
# text = We have seen it already in Algeria and, to a certain extent, in Turkey.
# text = It will happen again, if the ground is not prepared very carefully.
# text = On the other hand, a certain transition democracy, as in Jordan, may be a better temporary solution, paving the way for the real thing, perhaps in the same way that an immediate sudden democracy did not work in Russia and would not have worked in China.
# text = I have no doubt that the civilized world will prevail.
# text = But the longer it takes us to understand the new landscape of this war, the more costly and painful the victory will be.
# text = Europe, more than any other region, is the key.
# text = Its understandable recoil from wars, following the horrors of World War II, may cost thousands of additional innocent lives, before the tide will turn."
# text = Zawahiri was associated with a faction of the Egyptian Islamic Jihad known as the Vanguards of Conquest.
# text = Zawahiri and the Vanguards of Conquest were seeking to recreate Mohammed's taking of mecca by a small band through violent attacks on Egyptian leaders.
# text = By 1998, Zawahiri had determined that the Egyptian Islamic Jihad should focus on its struggle against the United States and hold off on further attacks against the Egyptian regime.
# text = A key question is how they acquired the anthrax strain first isolated by the Texas Veterinary Medical Diagnostic Lab in 1980.
# text = According to senior counter terrorism officials, both here and abroad, among the supporters of these militant islamists were people who blended into society and were available to act when another part of the network requested it.
# text = Al Qaeda, Anthrax and Ayman: Means, Motive, Modus Operandi and Opportunity
# text = Homeland Security
# text = In early June 2003, a Central Intelligence Agency ("CIA") report publicly disclosed that the reason for Mohammed Atta's and Zacarias Moussaoui's inquiries into cropdusters was for the contemplated use in dispersing biological agents such as anthrax.
# text = An early September 2003 Newsweek article included a rumor by a Taliban source that at a meeting in April 2003 Bin Laden was planning an "unbelievable" biological attack, the plans for which had suffered a setback upon the arrest of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed ("KSM").
# text = He had been captured the previous month in Rawalpindi, Pakistan.
# text = In November 2003, a report by a UN Panel of experts concluded that Al Qaeda is determined to use chemical and biological weapons and is restrained only by technical difficulties.
# text = In a statement issued June 16, 2004, the 9/11 Commission Staff concluded that "Al Qaeda had an ambitious biological weapons program and was making advances in its ability to produce anthrax prior to September 11.
# text = According to Director of Central Intelligence George Tenet, al Qaeda’s ability to conduct an anthrax attack is one of the most immediate threats the United States is likely to face."
# text = On August 9, 2004, it was announced that in the Spring of 2001, a man named El-Shukrijumah, also known as Jafar the Pilot, who was part of a "second wave," had been casing New York City helicopters.
# text = Photographs from a seized computer disc included the controls and the locks on the door between the passengers and pilot.
# text = In a bulletin, the FBI noted that the surveillance might relate to a plot to disperse a chemical or biological weapon.
# text = The CIA reportedly has been quietly building a case that the anthrax mailings were an international plot.
# text = This is old news.
# text = It's just no longer bureaucratically impolite to openly contest the FBI's (former) theory about a lone, American scientist.
# text = Many people have argued that a US-based Al Qaeda operative is behind the earlier Fall 2001 anthrax mailings in the US, and that the mailings served as a threat and warning.
# text = Princeton islamist scholar Bernard Lewis has explained that while islamists may disagree about whether killing innocents is sanctioned by the laws of jihad, extremists like Zawahiri agree that notice must be given before biochemical weapons are used.
# text = "The Prophet's guidance," says Michael Scheuer, an al-Qaeda analyst who recently retired from the CIA and once headed its Bin Laden unit, "was always, Before you attack someone, warn them very clearly..." The anthrax mailings followed the pattern of letters they sent in January 1997 to newspaper branches in Washington, D.C. and New York City, as well as symbolic targets.
# text = The letter bombs were sent in connection with the detention of the blind sheik Abdel Rahman and those responsible for the earlier World Trade Center bombing in 1993.
# text = Handwritten notes and files on a laptop seized upon the capture of KSM, Al Qaeda's #3, included a feasible anthrax production plan using a spray dryer and addressed the recruitment of necessary expertise.
# text = What your morning paper did not tell you, however, was that the CIA seized a similar disc from Ayman Zawahiri's right-hand, Ahmed Salama Mabruk, 5 years earlier.
# text = The computer disk was confiscated from him during his arrest by the CIA in Azerbaijan and handed over to the Egyptian authorities.
# text = Mabruk, at the time, was the head of Jihad's military operations.
# text = There is a risk that observers underestimate the time that Al Qaeda has had to make progress in such recruitment and research and development.

# text = Zawahiri was associated with a faction of the Egyptian Islamic Jihad known as the Vanguards of Conquest.

# text = After the alert condition had long since returned to yellow, Zawahiri in late February issued another audiotape.

# text = (Khalid Mohammed's involvement dates back to Bojinka, as does Hambali's).

# text = In May 2004, Patrick Hughes, Lieutenant General (Retired), Assistant Secretary for Information Analysis, Homeland Security Department testified before the 9/11 Commission.
# text = He explained that interrogations and other evidence revealed that Al Qaeda wanted to strike the US with a nonconventional weapon, most notably anthrax.
# text = The same week, the WTC head testified that while they had not received any briefing on the use of planes, they had taken steps to prepare for an attack using anthrax based on intelligence that had been received.
# text = Al Qaeda has had anthrax, the raw seed product in its unweaponized form, since at least 1997, when it was purchased by Bin Laden through the Moro Islamic Liberation Front ("Moro Front" or "MILF").
# text = Zawahiri, Al Qaeda's #2, is head of Al Qaeda's biochemical program.
# text = The CIA has known of Zawahiri's plans to use anthrax for a half decade.
# text = The confidante and right-hand man of Dr. Ayman Zawahiri admitted that Zawahiri succeeded in obtaining anthrax and intended to use it against US targets.
# text = Another senior Al Qaeda member (a shura or policy-making council member no less) was working for the Egyptian intelligence services and he confirmed the report in a sworn lengthy confession.
# text = Even Zawahiri's attorney in 1999 said that Bin Laden and Zawahiri were likely to resort to the biological and chemical agents they possessed given the extradition pressure senior Al Qaeda leaders faced.
# text = A recently released islamist who had been a close associate of Zawahiri said that Zawahiri spent a decade and had made 15 separate attempts to recruit the necessary expertise to weaponize anthrax in Russia and the Middle East.
# text = The US Army recipe was not used, and obtaining the unprocessed Ames strain of anthrax used does not warrant the weight given it by some press accounts.
# text = There was lax control over the distribution of the Ames strain that was used, especially in light of the fact that transfers were not even required to be recorded prior to 1997.
# text = Significantly, the individual who isolated it nearly a quarter century ago (now retired), upon being contacted, does not even report that he necessarily sent the only copy of the strain to Ft. Detrick.
# text = Senator Patrick Leahy at a Congressional hearing in the Spring of 2002 noted that the FBI had collected the Ames strain from 20 sources.
# text = In Fall 2004, MSNBC, relying on an unnamed FBI spokesperson, reports that the FBI has narrowed the pool of labs known to have had Ames that was a match from 16 to 4 but cannot rule out that it was made overseas.
# text = Al Qaeda's anthrax production plans on Khalid Mohammed's computer did not evidence knowledge of advanced techniques in the most efficient biological weapons.
# text = At least according to the public comments by bioweaponeer experts William Patrick and Kenneth Alibek, under the optimal method, there is no electrostatic charge.
# text = In the case of the anthrax used in the mailings, there was an electrostatic charge.
# text = Although there was a dominance of single spores and a trillion spore concentration, there were clumps as large as 40 - 100 microns.
# text = (Spores must be no bigger than 5 microns to be inhalable.)
# text = Many point to the trillion spore concentration as extraordinary.
# text = It is far simpler, however, to achieve a trillion spore concentration in the production of a few grams than in industrial processing typical of a state sponsored lab.
# text = The "trillion spore" issue was at the heart of a lot of mistaken theories of the matter concluding that state sponsorship was necessarily indicated.
# text = The reported finding at Dugway undermines the argument of both the "bomb Iraq" crowd and the liberals focused on Dr. Steve Hatfill who object to US biodefense research because they view it as being useful for offensive purposes.

# text = OVERVIEW
# text = This conference will examine the business and regulatory challenges to U.S. electric systems in transition in effectively expanding transmission capacity to meet new demands in the larger and more competitive regional markets emerging under FERC 's RTO initiatives.
# text = The conference will review the parameters of these challenges and possible solutions to them.

# text = I think that it is a great idea to get some press regarding our fundamental operating standards, but I wonder about the most appropriate timing, enough of a global message and the means of delivery.
# text = On the means of delivery, I am not sure from your note whether or not I fully understand the intent.
# text = Or is the letter from John an introduction to be included as a lead in to the article?
# text = With regard to a global message, I think that one of the key points around fundamental operating standards are that they are intended to be global in nature, applied to every commodity and every location where we engage in trading activities.
# text = With these operating standards implemented worldwide, we will know as operations professionals that risk is being mitigated and we will be able to ensure Enron top management that there is consistency in operating standards worldwide.
# text = These global standards also should enable Enron to expand its business reach more quickly, with well defined requirements with regard to trading operations.
# text = I am not sure from the article as written that the global nature of this effort comes across.
# text = Finally, a question regarding timing.
# text = The last I knew after you and Brent drafted this starting point for fundamental operating standards was that this was being circulated (Shona took this to do after Brent's return to Houston) for comments to all business controllers.
# text = I don't believe that we are quite at the point that we can say that all business controllers worldwide have reviewed, understand and have implemented these standards.

# text = Erin Rice
# text = 11/10/2000 11:08 AM
# text = Steve:
# text = At this point, our IT contacts are backpedalling a bit and suggesting they can overcome the TIBCO and Terminal Server problems.
# text = There are still four important issues, however:
# text = IT still cannot commit to transferring messages across domains.
# text = This means that messages initiated at Corp and intended for the entire Enron organization will not reach any business units outside the Corp domain.
# text = No messages will reach the EES organization unless IBM agrees not to use their proprietary message delivery tool, WebSphere, and will use WebLogic instead.
# text = WebLogic is required by BackWeb, although it is designed by a separate company.
# text = HR, intended to be a key user of this tool, will not use BackWeb because survey responses cannot be made anonymous.
# text = HR has already purchased a tool called CONFIRMIT that can execute anonymous surveys.
# text = Messages will not be delivered simultaneously to all users in the same domain, nor will they be delivered for two to five hours after they are sent by the message administrator.
# text = Another thing to consider is that these messages will be set to expire and disappear within a set period of time, meaning users cannot retrieve them and read them later (as they can with e-mail).
# text = This means that I could be away from the office for several days and miss a message entirely, because it would have expired and disappeared by the time I returned.
# text = The plain fact is that a few members of IT are pushing this initiative, but they lack commercial sponsorship.
# text = They are hoping Corp will foot the bill for a pilot which will allow them to fully test this tool before implementing it company-wide.
# text = Please let us know if you have additional questions.
# text = - er

# text = We need to change the Prod Description fro the LME Product.
# text = The change is mainly on the Settlement Date text, which instead of "...Two business days after the date of the Transaction..." shall read as follow:
# text = A currency Transaction with Enron Europe Finance & Trading Limited ("EEFTL") as agent for Risk Management & Trading Corp. under which either (A) for the case in which Counterparty submits an offer to buy from EEFTL, Counterparty shall receive the Base Currency Amount and shall pay the Foreign Currency Amount, or (B) for the case in which Counterparty submits an offer to sell to EEFTL, Counterparty shall pay the Base Currency Amount and shall receive the Foreign Currency Amount.
# text = The Base Currency Amount shall equal the volume submitted by the Counterparty via the Website.
# text = The Foreign Currency Amount shall equal the Base Currency Amount, multiplied by the daily London Metal Exchange (LME) fixing rate as published by Reuters on page MTLE on the date of the transaction, modified by the price submitted by the Counterparty via the Website.
# text = The term of the Transaction shall correspond to the date(s) set forth in the Product description on the Website.
# text = The Settlement date shall be the date(s) set forth in the Product description on the Website.
# text = The price is quoted in JPY (the 'Foreign Currency') per US Dollar (the 'Base Currency').
# text = The unit of measure against which the price is quoted shall be US Dollars.
# text = Please let me know your approval before we make any changes.

# text = David Forster
# text = 03/08/2000 09:45 AM
# text = Fyi
# text = Dear Justin
# text = Marly asked me to respond to you.
# text = As you know, the suffix ONLINE is purely descriptive and now used by many companies.
# text = Therefore, any trade mark registration that incorporates the word ONLINE as a suffix in the way that you use it will not enable its owner to prevent others from using the word ONLINE.
# text = Given the above, if you have adequate protection for the word ENRON (which covers the services that you offer on-line as well as your core activities), I'd say that another application for the words ENRON ONLINE is probably unnecessary.
# text = However, if you use a particular logo for the on-line service, that should be registered.
# text = I hope the above is clear.
# text = Jonathan Day
# text = Marly,
# text = If you could respond to me on this request, thanks
# text = Justin
# text = Paul Goddard
# text = 08/03/2000 11:35
