# text = Blue Planet: Who's afraid of Big Bad Wolf?
# text = By Dan Whipple
# text = UNITED PRESS INTERNATIONAL
# text = Boulder, CO, Feb. 23 (UPI) --
# text = Ever since he ate up Red Riding Hood's grandma and blew down the houses of two-thirds of the Three Little Pigs, the Big Bad Wolf has held a persistently bad reputation.
# text = In part because of that reputation, the gray wolf was nearly exterminated from the lower 48 states by the 1920s, except for a small remnant population on Isle Royale National Park in Michigan's Lake Superior.
# text = The last wolf was killed in Yellowstone National Park in 1943.
# text = Western sheep and cattle ranchers, on whose behalf this extermination campaign was conducted, gratefully dusted their hands of the wolf and wrote him off as a job well done.
# text = Their sheep could graze, their cows could ruminate and never a discouraging word would be heard.
# text = After the major kill-offs, wolves outside of Alaska and Canada existed mostly as legend.
# text = Like UFOs or Sasquatch, several people claimed to see fleeting lone wolves, usually in Yellowstone.
# text = In the 1960s, a group shooting a movie in the Wyoming park reportedly imported some captive wolves, then released them when their shooting was done.
# text = If so, this happy band has not been heard from since.
# text = Rumor also had it some renegade biologist brought a caged pair to Yellowstone and released them into the wild sometime in the 1970s, hoping to reestablish a breeding population.
# text = If true, the caper failed.
# text = Over time, the wolf's absence seemed to rehabilitate its image.
# text = Eventually, a trickle of support appeared for bringing the predator back to its former home range in the northern Rocky Mountains.
# text = This trickle grew into a flood, resulting in 14 wolves being reintroduced in Yellowstone in 1995 by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service -- albeit over the strong and still-continuing objections of ranchers.
# text = These wolf packs have flourished, and now there are an estimated 850 wolves roaming the northern Rockies, where merely 10 years ago there were none.
# text = One compelling argument for reintroduction was the wolf acts as a keystone predator, an animal that affects the populations, behavior and ecology of a wide variety of species within its range.
# text = Some recent research conducted by Oregon State University has given considerable credence to this idea.
# text = OSU forestry professors William Ripple and Robert Beschta have found that wolves actually promote stream-bank stabilization, although they have given the phenomenon the unfortunate name of "the ecology of fear" -- something that smacks of the horrible PR resulting from the wolf's relationships with Riding Hood and the Three Pigs.
# text = They explained that elk in Yellowstone used to browse unmolested on young aspen and willow growing near the banks of streams, a behavior that prevented the saplings from reaching mature stages and increased the possibility of soil erosion.
# text = Since reintroduction, however, Ripple and Beschta have found, fear of the wolves apparently has discouraged the elk from spending too much time at stream banks -- where they are out in the open -- and munching on the saplings.
# text = "All you have to do is look at the photographs," Ed Bangs, wolf recovery coordinator for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, told UPI's Blue Planet,
# text = "You say, 'wow!'
# text = An area that used to be bald as a billiard ball is now a sea of willow."
# text = This simple change has triggered a veritable ecological cascade in Yellowstone.
# text = More streamside willow and aspen have meant better habitat for beaver, for instance.
# text = Where there had been only one beaver colony in the park's northern range before the wolves returned, now there are nine.
# text = "It may be uninteresting to a lot of people," Beschta told Blue Planet.
# text = "There's a lot of impact on plants and they say, 'Who cares?'
# text = But we've been looking at streamside communities.
# text = Since wolf recovery, streamside plants, willows and cottonwoods provide food for other critters -- beavers, a whole variety of avian species, berry-producing shrubs that bears can use.
# text = It's important with regard to the quality of streams.
# text = The plants provide shade and root strength for bank stability.
# text = Plants are critical to wildland ecosystems."
# text = Yellowstone has a vast elk herd, one of the largest in the world.
# text = Bangs said although the number of elk has not declined very much since the wolves came back, their behavior appears markedly different.
# text = "I'm pretty suspicious of making broad generalizations," however, he cautioned.
# text = "Wolves are still pretty new.
# text = They've only been there for 10 years.
# text = In 10 more years we'll have a better idea."
# text = Wolf reintroduction in the northern Rockies has been so successful the Fish and Wildlife Service has moved to reduce the animal's status from endangered to threatened and, eventually, to remove it from the endangered species list altogether.
# text = Bangs said the agency has established viable wolf packs in the northern Rockies, as required by federal regulations.
# text = Some conservationists want the protection extended so wolves can move into other states, including Colorado, Utah and Oregon, among others.
# text = On Jan. 31, Oregon Federal District Court Judge Robert E. Jones appeared to agree with them.
# text = He vacated the FWS decision to downgrade the wolf's status.
# text = Bangs said his agency is still reviewing the decision.
# text = Regardless of the wolf's legal status, its future expansion into new areas now seems likely.
# text = Wolves can migrate considerable distances.
# text = A Yellowstone wolf was found dead, hit by a car, on a Colorado highway last year, several hundred miles from home.
# text = Meanwhile, his reputation seems to be improving, although Bangs noted a "pretty interesting social dynamic."
# text = There are only about 850 wolves in the West, but there are an estimated 31,000 mountain lions.
# text = Pound for pound, mountain lions eat more game and more livestock than wolves.
# text = They even occasionally attack people, which wolves do not -- despite the propaganda from the Brothers Grimm.
# text = Yet people seem willing -- even eager -- to accommodate mountain lions, despite the risks.
# text = It remains to be seen whether they will extend the same courtesy to the arriving gray wolf.
# text = Regarding those rumors about wolves living in Yellowstone prior to the official reintroduction?
# text = They seem to be just that: rumors.
# text = True, there are about 300,000 wolves and wolf hybrids kept as pets in the United States.
# text = It also is likely people have released some of these animals into the wild hoping they would survive -- for instance, a ranger in Glacier Park caught someone in this very act not long ago.
# text = Bangs said these animals are not equipped to survive in the wild, however, and they all almost certainly have died.
# text = He said after 10 years of DNA testing on northern Rockies wolves, scientists have not found a single strain that did not belong to one of the wolves the agency released -- or their descendants.
# text = --
# text = Blue Planet is a weekly series examining the relationship of humans to the environment, by veteran environmental reporter Dan Whipple.
# text = E-mail: sciencem...@upi.com
# text = Climate: Humans fuss, animals adjust
# text = By Dan Whipple
# text = UNITED PRESS INTERNATIONAL
# text = Boulder, CO, Nov. 15 (UPI) --
# text = Scientists can argue all they want about how many degrees Celsius -- or Fahrenheit -- the planet is warming and what the trend portends, but meanwhile Earth's plants, insects and animals are not waiting for the outcome.
# text = They already are altering their patterns of behavior in response to what is happening.
# text = It turns out one of the surest barometers of the warming climate is the response of the non-human natural world to changing conditions, and biologists who study the responses have been aware for some years the biosphere is acknowledging global warming.
# text = Nina Leopold Bradley, a plant ecologist and daughter of the conservation pioneer Aldo Leopold, published a 1999 paper in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences on her 61-year uninterrupted phenological records.
# text = Phenology studies an organism's development and life cycle -- the pulse of life.
# text = Bradley's record of 300 phenophases found that even prior to 1999, spring was arriving in higher latitudes several weeks earlier than in the earlier years of her data.
# text = Birds arrived sooner on their migrations from the south and plants flowered earlier.
# text = The Eastern phoebe is showing up about 20 days before it used to.
# text = The forest phlox is blooming in late April instead of mid-May.
# text = Half of the 300 phenophases Leopold tracked showed a response consistent with warming.
# text = In England, the cuckoo returns earlier.
# text = An analysis of 65 bird species in the United Kingdom shows about one-third are laying their eggs four to seven days earlier than they did 25 years ago.
# text = "One of the major, most well-documented and robust findings in ecology over the past century has been the crucial role of climate in determining the geographical distribution of species and ecological communities," concluded a report titled "Observed Impacts of Global Climate Change in the United States," released by the Pew Center on Global Climate last week.
# text = Pew researchers looked at about 40 studies that could provide an assessment of whether climate was affecting biology.
# text = "Half of the studies provide strong evidence of a causal link between the biological change and climate change," said Camille Parmesan, a University of Texas-Austin biologist and one of the world's leading experts on this issue.
# text = These changes are occurring across all species, Parmesan told UPI's Climate.
# text = "Across the United States, the northern edge of species' range is expanding," she said.
# text = Parmesan has spent much of her career studying the checkerspot butterfly, which migrates between Mexico and southern California.
# text = Some localized extinctions already have occurred across some of its habitat.
# text = "Empirical research pointed to climate as being a strong driver," she said.
# text = "There have been large numbers of population extinctions in Mexico and southern California in areas where the habitat is still acceptable."
# text = According to Parmesan's earlier studies, one extinction event, for instance, was triggered when a checkerspot population migrated north prematurely, relying on a warming temperature signal, then was caught in a severe snowstorm in its northern habitat.
# text = Throughout the United States, she said, "spring is about two weeks earlier.
# text = Tree swallows are nesting nine days earlier.
# text = Tropical species have moved up to Florida and the Gulf Coast.
# text = Bird and butterfly watchers are seeing many, many new species coming up from Mexico and the Caribbean."
# text = As the Pew report concluded, "Sufficient studies now exist to conclude that the consequences of climate change are already detectable within U.S. ecosystems."
# text = Such consequences include shifting and, in some cases, contraction of ranges and changes in species composition within ecosystems.
# text = The report also found alterations of ecosystem processes such as carbon cycling and storage.
# text = The Alaskan tundra, for instance, has switched from being a net sink of carbon dioxide -- absorbing and storing more carbon from the atmosphere than it releases -- to "being a net source of CO2 (releasing more carbon than is stored) because warmer winters have allowed dead plant matter previously stored in the soil to decompose and release CO2."
# text = The Pew report coincided with the release in Iceland of the "Arctic Climate Impact Assessment."
# text = The ACIA -- with participation by the United States, Canada, Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, the Russian Federation and Sweden -- was begun in 2000.
# text = "The impacts of global warming are affecting people now in the Arctic," said ACIA chair Robert Corell.
# text = "The Arctic is experiencing some of the most rapid and severe climate change on Earth.
# text = The impacts of climate change on the region and the globe are projected to increase substantially in the years to come."
# text = The ACIA found Arctic winter temperatures have increased 4 degrees to 7 degrees Fahrenheit in the last 50 years and should go up about twice that much in the next 100 years.
# text = Arctic summer sea ice will decline by 50 percent by the end of the 21st century, the assessment found, with some models predicting complete disappearance of summer sea ice.
# text = "Should the Arctic Ocean become ice-free in summer, it is likely that polar bears and some seal species would be driven toward extinction," the report concluded.
# text = As with so much climate research, not everyone agrees with these dire predictions.
# text = A third report, "The Impacts of Climate Change: An Appraisal for the Future," completed by the Britain-based International Policy Network and released almost simultaneously with the other two, falls somewhat into that category.
# text = On the one hand, the IPN report agreed "Climate models generally predict that the temperature rises in the Arctic will substantially exceed the global rise.
# text = This applies especially in the high Arctic where the ice cover is expected to diminish substantially with the effect that the surface absorption of solar radiation will greatly increase."
# text = On the other hand, the report thinks the news might not be so bad for the North Atlantic fisheries.
# text = "The impact of global warming on fish stocks and fisheries is hard to judge," the IPN report said.
# text = "A warming of the magnitude predicted is more likely than not to be beneficial to the fisheries of the North Atlantic."
# text = The important commercial species that probably would benefit from warming include cod, haddock, saithe, herring, blue whiting and several types of flatfish and crustaceans -- such as the Norway lobster.
# text = Important species that probably would decline include shrimp, capelin, Greenland halibut and some varieties of flatfish.
# text = Hidden in this laundry list -- and in the pile of studies examined by the Pew researchers -- is one of the fundamental chasms dividing participants in the global warming debate.
# text = The IPN report examines commercial fish species, but it neglects important non-commercial animals, such as seals and polar bears.
# text = In a limited economic sense, therefore, the organization can argue warming might be a good thing.
# text = The problem is whether one cares what happens to the polar bears, checkerspot butterflies and other unconsumables.
# text = The Pew researchers tried to transcend the economic argument.
# text = They assumed a value -- unspecified -- for non-commercial species, and in doing so rendered the warming news a bit less rosy.
# text = This tug-of-war over calculating economic values is the one that ultimately will have to be decided by humans, because animals and plants can adjust only so much.
# text = "When dandelions have set the mark of May on Wisconsin pastures, it is time to listen for the final proof of spring," wrote Aldo Leopold in "A Sand County Almanac."
# text = "Sit down on a tussock, cock your ears at the sky, dial out the bedlam of meadowlarks and redwings, and soon you may hear it: the flight of the upland plover, just now back from the Argentine."
# text = Or maybe not.
# text = --
# text = Climate is a weekly series by UPI examining the impacts of global climate change.
# text = E-mail sciencem...@upi.com

# text = How has Katrina changed the US?
# text = What will be the lasting effects of Hurricane Katrina and what can be learnt from the response?
# text = Relief agencies are trying to help hundreds of thousands of displaced people while authorities have vowed to restore security in New Orleans following a breakdown of law and order.
# text = In the world press, commentators predict that Katrina will make a profound change in the way the US is perceived at home and abroad, especially following the scenes of poverty and racial divisions they believe the disaster has revealed.
# text = Meanwhile, President George W Bush has said he will lead an inquiry into how the disaster was handled.
# text = How has Katrina changed the US?
# text = Has it altered your life?

# text = <John can come over to eat at my house anytime.
# text = -Juggernaut>
# text = It is always interesting what spin the press will take.
# text = Certainly, representation of the US in other countries will have a certain depiction.
# text = I don't believe that folks who believe that America is the land of opportunity will change their views from this recent news.
# text = I have a friend who came here from Bulgaria after winning a green card in a lottery.
# text = Yes, she and her family were delighted to leave the communistic remnants in that country.
# text = Her husband became a citizen of the US just the week before last.
# text = (Believe it or not, it takes a minimum of 5 years to apply.)
# text = The countries which are giving to America to aid are a great example of the seed that America has sown through the years with other nations.
# text = Now to the poverty stricken and the racial issue...
# text = You know, I've lived in the Dallas/Fort Worth Metroplex most of my life.
# text = When not in Texas, I lived in LA and San Francisco.
# text = There is a lot of racial diversity in all of these places... and I've vacationed through the south... visited my folks when they lived in Mississippi, and where they live now and are in the racial minority being white (less than 20%) in northeastern Arkansas.
# text = The fact is, when I began traveling for business to New England, when I first visited my in-laws in Montana and Idaho, I was shocked at the lack of racial diversity.
# text = I didn't expect to react that way, but when I was looking around my workplace in Nashua, New Hampshire, and everyone else looked pretty much like me, it was really very eerie.
# text = So, yes, America has pockets that are more diverse than others.
# text = Additionally, reviewing the standings of Louisiana and Mississippi in the educational stakes, you'll find they usually land near the bottom of a list of 50 states.
# text = Unfortunately, those left behind to be filmed, where those without transportation or means.
# text = Some refused to leave, but so many were unable to.
# text = Yes, it's a valid reflection of America - we do have cities like this.
# text = However, New Orleans also had many affluent people, people who left town early as they had the means.
# text = I don't know if this will change other nation's perceptions of America.
# text = I suspect it will not change greatly... but you never know how much stock people put in the news.
# text = I do know that this will change the face of America.
# text = I expect that many of the displaced people (those affluent and those not) will remain in the places they were evacuated to.

# text = ANTONIO PEREZ 1535-1611 [Philip II's renegade Secretary of State]
# text = <<In "Love's Labour's Lost" we find a character Don Adriana de Armatho, full of affection and bombast.
# text = A Spanish refugee, ANTONIO PEREZ, visited England in 1593 and became acquainted with Francis & ANTHONY Bacon, with whom for a time he seems to have been on terms of intimacy, which did not last very long, for the Spaniard developed so much affectation & bombast that he became unpopular in Court circles.
# text = In 1594 PEREZ wrote & published a book under the assumed name of "RAPHAEL PEREGRINO."
# text = In the play Holofernes is ridiculing Don Adriana "the traveler from Spain" and says of him: "He is too picked, too spruce, too affected, Too odd, as it were, too PEREGRINate, as I may call it."
# text = -Act 5, Scene 1.
# text = To make the reference more pointed and unmistakable, Sir Nathaniel replies "a most singular & choice epithet," and at once enters it in his note book.
# text = This parody on PEREZ' sobriquet clearly identifies PEREZ with Armatho.>>

# text = Shakespeare Electronic Conference, Vol. 6, No. 0832. Monday, 23 October 1995.
# text = From: Martin Green <MGr...@usa.pipeline.com>
# text = Date: Sunday, 22 Oct 1995 10:57:32 -0400
# text = Subject: Re: Facts, Purpose of List, Italy, Jews
# text = <<There were no Jews in England to speak of in the 1590's.
# text = True, but two in England that we know of were a part of the Essex entourage: Dr. Lopez, who had been physician to Essex' step-father, the Earl of Leicester, had apparently treated the young Essex for some socially unacceptable ailment, and Antonio Perez, who was a guest at Essex House in the early 1590's.
# text = To be sure, both Lopez & Perez were conversos--but they were thought of in England as being, as they undoubtedly were, at least ethnically, Jews.>>
# text = ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# text = <<Doctor RODERIGO LOPEZ (1525 -1594) was the Portugese Jewish doctor accused by Essex of trying to poison Queen Elizabeth.
# text = The 69 year old Dr. Lopez was found guilty and was summarily hung and quartered on June 7, 1594 at Tyburn.
# text = Long before (September 1560) Dr. Lopez had been the personal house doctor of Robert Dudley and the good doctor was obligated to write the death certificate for Amy Robsart (stating that she had "accidentally" fallen down the stairs).
# text = That same year (1560) a Spanish priest named RUY LOPEZ handily beat all comers at a chess tournament in Rome.
# text = Lopez's 1561 book "Libro de la invencion liberal y arte del Juego del Acedraz" became THE classic on Chess openings, including the one that bears his name.
# text = -------------------------------------------------------------------
# text = Chess history 1530-1647
# text = [ ]
# text = 1530 LOPEZ, Ruy b. in Zafra, Spain.
# text = Spanish priest & leading player.
# text = 1533 Atahualpa, inca emperor of peru, imprisoned & learns chess.
# text = 1542 LEONARDO, Giovanni (a.k.a. Il Puttino/the Boy) born in Calaria.
# text = 1550 Valdiviesco, Don Antonio de, Bishop of Nicaragua, assassinated while playing chess in his palace at Leon.
# text = 1551 Ivan IV of Russia bans chess.
# text = 1555 Castling is introduced.
# text = 1560 Ruy Lopez visits Rome and defeats all the players.
# text = 1561 Last time castling was 2 separate moves.
# text = 1561 Ruy Lopez proposes the 50-move rule to claim a draw.
# text = 1561 Ruy Lopez writes his book on chess.
# text = Introduces the word gambit.
# text = (Alcala, 1561)
# text = 1562 St Teresa, a Spanish reformer, includes chess in her writings.
# text = 1570 Gianutto della Mantia, Horatio born in Italy.
# text = Author of Italian chess book.
# text = 1572 Ruy Lopez defeats several eminent players in Rome.
# text = 1574 Boi and Leonardo beat Lopez & Ceron in presence of Phillip II.
# text = 1575 Leonardo beats Ruy Lopez in Madrid.
# text = 1575 After the Plague of Cremona, all games except chess were banned.
# text = 1576 Boi taken prisoner, but wins his freedom playing chess.
# text = 1580 Catherine de Medici of France is a keen chess player.
# text = 1580 Ruy lopez died.
# text = 1584 Ivan the Terrible dies while starting a game of chess.
# text = 1584 Lopez's book translated into Italian by Tarsia and published in Venice.
# text = ----------------------------------------------------------------------
# text = <<"I have told you, friend," said the curate, "that this is done to divert our idle thoughts; and as in well-ordered states games of CHESS, fives, and billiards are allowed for the diversion of those who do not care, or are not obliged, or are unable to work, so books of this kind are allowed to be printed, on the supposition that, what indeed is the truth, there can be nobody so ignorant as to take any of them for true stories;>>
# text = "A fine comparison!" said Sancho; "though not so new but that I have heard it many and many a time, as well as that other one of the game of CHESS; how, so long as the game lasts, each piece has its own particular office, and when the game is finished they are all mixed, jumbled up and shaken together, and stowed away in the bag, which is much like ending life in the grave."
# text = "Thou art growing less doltish and more shrewd every day, Sancho," said Don Quixote.
# text = "Ay," said Sancho; "it must be that some of your worship's shrewdness sticks to me; land that, of itself, is barren and dry, will come to yield good fruit if you dung it and till it>>

# text = Of all Freemason sponsered revolutions: American, French, Bolivar, etc. . . Garibaldi's is the most blatantly Masonic:
# text = Nostromo A Tale of the Seaboard
# text = <<After having written so far, Don Martin Decoud, the exotic dandy of the Parisian boulevard, got up and walked across the sanded floor of the cafe at one end of the Albergo of United Italy, kept by Giorgio Viola, the old companion of Garibaldi.
# text = The highly coloured lithograph of the Faithful Hero seemed to look dimly, in the light of one candle, at the man with no faith in anything except the truth of his own sensations.
# text = Looking out of the window, Decoud was met by a darkness so impenetrable that he could see neither the mountains nor the town, nor yet the buildings near the harbour; and there was not a sound, as if the tremendous obscurity of the Placid Gulf, spreading from the waters over the land, had made it dumb as well as blind. . . .
# text = He turned away.
# text = He could bear no longer that expressionless and motionless stare, which seemed to have a sort of impenetrable emptiness like the black depth of an abyss.
# text = . . . and uneasy in its corporate expression, was overtopped by the big face of Don Juste Lopez, soft and white, with prominent eyelids and wreathed in impenetrable solemnity as if in a dense cloud.>>

# text = Wisteria Lodge
# text = <<He could do little during the day, for Murillo took every precaution and never went out save with his satellite Lucas, or Lopez as he was known in the days of his greatness.
# text = At night, however, he slept alone, and the avenger might find him.
# text = On a certain evening, which had been prearranged, I sent my friend final instructions, for the man was forever on the alert and continually changed his room.
# text = I was to see that the doors were open and the signal of a green or white light in a window which faced the drive was to give notice if all was safe or if the attempt had better be postponed.
# text = "But everything went wrong with us.
# text = In some way I had excited the suspicion of Lopez, the secretary.
# text = He crept up behind me and sprang upon me just as I had finished the note.
# text = He and his master dragged me to my room and held judgment upon me as a convicted traitress.
# text = Then and there they would have plunged their knives into me could they have seen how to escape the consequences of the deed.
# text = Finally, after much debate, they concluded that my murder was too dangerous.
# text = But they determined to get rid forever of Garcia.
# text = They had gagged me, and Murillo twisted my arm round until I gave him the address.
# text = I swear that he might have twisted it off had I understood what it would mean to Garcia.
# text = Lopez addressed the note which I had written, sealed it with his sleeve-link, and sent it by the hand of the servant, Jose.
# text = How they murdered him I do not know, save that it was Murillo's hand who struck him down, for Lopez had remained to guard me.
# text = I believe he must have waited among the gorse bushes through which the path winds and struck him down as he passed.
# text = At first they were of a mind to let him enter the house and to kill him as a detected burglar; but they argued that if they were mixed up in an inquiry their own identity would at once be publicly disclosed and they would be open to further attacks.
# text = With the death of Garcia, the pursuit might cease, since such a death might frighten others from the task.>>

# text = The Beatles are very well known by people close to them for their arrogance and racism.
# text = One of the manifestations of their racism is the rejection towards Japanese Yoko Ono.
# text = That rejection got to the point that George Harrison kicked Yoko Ono in the Apple studios during the filming of Let it Be.
# text = When John asked George while they were having lunch about how things were going for Paul after his separation from the Beatles and George replied that he was number one in the Swedish hit parade, John said in a despective manner: "ah!!.. in Sweden..", as if Sweden was an inferior place or something alike.
# text = In the Beatles' song "Get Back" they advise black Joe to "get back to where you once belonged", as if England was not a place for black people.
# text = Sometimes back, Paul told George in the Apple offices that the new generations are a bundle of idiots and useless people, but in any way they would have also been slaves of the Beatles.
# text = The Jewish marriage living to the right of George's house said that he is an arrogant person who does never return a greeting.
# text = The newly married couple living on the corner in front of the entrance of George's house (Friar Park) refers to him as an overbearing person to stay away from.
# text = The receptionist of "Hand made", the former film making company of George Harrison said: "we don't have any relation with that man anymore and we don't want to know anything about him".
# text = It is interesting to note that this company was made bankrupt by the British cinema industry due to the despotism and pedantry of George Harrison, who believed that the cinema industry would have worshiped him.
# text = Their chauvinisms got to the point that even they themselves hated each other.
# text = Paul McCartney said that George Harrison is a nothing.
# text = George Harrison said that he is tired of listening to people talk about John Lennon....
# text = George Harrison said in a video that "Oasis is a very untalented band and they shouldn't be playing at all", all of it being the truth, but the Beatles is also a band of very poor musicians, if musicians at all, who could only play a couple of elementary guitar chords and who are as untalented as Oasis.
# text = The Beatles of the times of the "Cavern" sounded exactly as poorly as Oasis and the little musical quality in the songs of the Beatles is due to George Martin.
# text = Without George Martin the Beatles would have been just another untalented band as Oasis....

# text = Groups: alt.consumers, ba.consumers, misc.consumers, misc.consumers.frugal-living
# text = Attack on Iran: A Looming Folly
# text = By William Rivers Pitt
# text = Monday 09 January 2006
# text = The wires have been humming since before the New Year with reports that the Bush administration is planning an attack on Iran.
# text = "The Bush administration is preparing its NATO allies for a possible military strike against suspected nuclear sites in Iran in the New Year, according to German media reports, reinforcing similar earlier suggestions in the Turkish media," reported UPI on December 30th.
# text = "The Berlin daily Der Tagesspiegel this week," continued UPI, "quoted 'NATO intelligence sources' who claimed that the NATO allies had been informed that the United States is currently investigating all possibilities of bringing the mullah-led regime into line, including military options.
# text = This 'all options are open' line has been President George W Bush's publicly stated policy throughout the past 18 months."
# text = An examination of the ramifications of such an attack is desperately in order.
# text = 1.  Blowback in Iraq
# text = The recent elections in Iraq were dominated by an amalgam of religiously fundamentalist Shi'ite organizations, principally the Dawa Party and the Supreme Council for Islamic Revolution in Iraq (SCIRI).
# text = Both Dawa and SCIRI have umbilical connections to the fundamentalist Shi'ite leadership in Iran that go back decades.
# text = In essence, Iran now owns a significant portion of the Iraqi government.
# text = Should the United States undertake military action against Iran, the ramifications in Iraq would be immediate and extreme.
# text = In the first eight days of January, eighteen US troops have been killed in Iraq, compounded by another twelve deaths from a Black Hawk helicopter crash on Saturday.
# text = Much of the violence aimed at American forces is coming from disgruntled Sunni factions that have their own militias, believe the last elections were a sham, and hold little political power in the government.
# text = If the US attacks Iran, it is probable that American forces - already taxed by attacks from Sunni factions - will also face reprisal attacks in Iraq from Shi'ite factions loyal to Iran.
# text = The result will be a dramatic escalation in US and civilian casualties, US forces will be required to bunker themselves further into their bases, and US forces will find themselves required to fight the very government they just finished helping into power.
# text = Iraq, already a seething cauldron, will sink further into chaos.
# text = 2.  Iran's Armaments
# text = Unlike Iraq, Iran has not spent the last fifteen years having its conventional forces worn down by grueling sanctions, repeated attacks, and two American-led wars.
# text = While Iran's conventional army is not what it was during the heyday of the Iran-Iraq war - their armaments have deteriorated and the veterans of that last war have retired - the nation enjoys substantial military strength nonetheless.
# text = According to a report issued by the Center for Strategic and International Studies in December of 2004, Iran "has some 540,000 men under arms and over 350,000 reserves.
# text = They include 120,000 Iranian Revolutionary Guards trained for land and naval asymmetrical warfare.
# text = Iran's military also includes holdings of 1,613 main battle tanks, 21,600 other armored fighting vehicles, 3,200 artillery weapons, 306 combat aircraft, 60 attack helicopters, 3 submarines, 59 surface combatants, and 10 amphibious ships."
# text = "Iran is now the only regional military power that poses a significant conventional military threat to Gulf stability," continued the CSIS report.
# text = "Iran has significant capabilities for asymmetric warfare, and poses the additional threat of proliferation.
# text = There is considerable evidence that it is developing both a long-range missile force and a range of weapons of mass destruction.
# text = It has never properly declared its holdings of chemical weapons, and the status of its biological weapons programs is unknown."
# text = A MILNET brief issued in February 2005 reports, "Due to its position astride the Persian Gulf, Iran has constantly been a threat to the Gulf.
# text = The so called 'Tanker' wars in the late 1980s put Iran squarely in the bullseye of all nations seeking to transport oil out of the region.
# text = Even the small navy that Iran puts to sea is capable enough to harass shipping, and several cases of small boat operations against oil well heads in the Gulf during that period made it clear small asymmetrical tactics of the Iranian Navy could be quite effective."
# text = "More concerning," continued the MILNET brief, "is the priority placed on expanding and modernizing its Navy.
# text = The CSIS report cites numerous areas where Iran has funded modernization including the most troublesome aspect, anti-shipping cruise missiles: 'Iran has obtained new anti-ship missiles and missile patrol craft from China, midget submarines from North Korea, submarines from Russia, and modern mines.'"
# text = It is Iran's missile armaments that pose the greatest concern for American forces in the Gulf, especially for the US Navy.
# text = Iran's coast facing the Persian Gulf is a looming wall of mountains that look down upon any naval forces arrayed in those waters.
# text = The Gulf itself only has one exit, the Strait of Hormuz, which is also dominated by the mountainous Iranian coastline.
# text = In essence, Iran holds the high ground in the Gulf.
# text = Missile batteries arrayed in those mountains could raise bloody havoc with any fleet deployed below.
# text = Of all the missiles in Iran's armament, the most dangerous is the Russian-made SS-N-22 Sunburn.
# text = These missiles are, simply, the fastest anti-ship weapons on the planet.
# text = The Sunburn can reach Mach 3 at high altitude.
# text = Its maximum low-altitude speed is Mach 2.2, some three times faster than the American-made Harpoon.
# text = The Sunburn takes two short minutes to cover its full range.
# text = The missile's manufacturers state that one or two missiles could cripple a destroyer, and five missiles could sink a 20,000 ton ship.
# text = The Sunburn is also superior to the Exocet missile.
# text = Recall that it was two Exocets that ripped the USS Stark to shreds in 1987, killing 37 sailors.
# text = The Stark could not see them to stop them.
# text = The US aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt is currently deployed in the Persian Gulf, with some 7,000 souls aboard.
# text = Sailing with the Roosevelt is the Tarawa Expeditionary Strike Force, which includes the USS Tarawa, the USS Austin, and the USS Pearl Harbor.
# text = The USS Austin is likewise deployed in the Gulf.
# text = The Sunburn missile, with its incredible speed and ability to avoid radar detection, would do terrible damage these ships if Iran chooses to retaliate in the Gulf after an American attack within its borders.
# text = Beyond the naval threat is the possibility of Iran throwing its military muscle into the ongoing struggle in Iraq.
# text = Currently, the US is facing an asymmetrical attack from groups wielding small arms, shoulder-fired grenades and roadside bombs.
# text = The vaunted American military has suffered 2,210 deaths and tens of thousands of wounded from this form of warfare.
# text = The occupation of Iraq has become a guerrilla war, a siege that has lasted more than a thousand days.
# text = If Iran decides to throw any or all of its 23,000 armored fighting vehicles, along with any or all of its nearly million-strong army, into the Iraq fray, the situation in the Middle East could become unspeakably dire.
# text = 3.  The Syrian Connection
# text = In February of 2005, Iran and Syria agreed upon a mutual protection pact to combat "challenges and threats" in the region.
# text = This was a specific reaction to the American invasion of Iraq, and a reaction to America's condemnation of Syria after the death of Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, which was widely seen as an assassination ordered from Damascus.
# text = An attack on Iran would trigger this mutual defense pact, and could conceivably bring Syria into direct conflict with American forces.
# text = Like Iran, Syria's military is nothing to scoff at.
# text = Virtually every credible analysis has Syria standing as the strongest military force in the Middle East after Israel.
# text = Damascus has been intent for years upon establishing significant military strength to serve as a counterweight to Israel's overwhelming capabilities.
# text = As of 2002, Syria had some 215,000 soldiers under arms, 4,700 tanks, and a massive artillery capability.
# text = The Syrian Air Force is comprised of ten to eleven fighter/attack squadrons and sixteen fighter squadrons, totaling somewhere near 650 aircraft.
# text = Syria also possesses one of the largest arsenals of ballistic missiles in the region, comprised primarily of SCUD-derived systems.
# text = Iran, North Korea and China have been willing providers of state-of-the-art technologies.
# text = Compounding this is the well-based suspicion that Syria has perhaps the most advanced chemical weapons capability in the Persian Gulf.
# text = 4.  China and the US Economy
# text = While the ominous possibilities of heightened Iraqi chaos, missiles in the Gulf, and Syrian involvement loom large if the US attacks Iran, all pale in comparison to the involvement of China in any US/Iran engagement.
# text = China's economy is exploding, hampered only by their great thirst for petroleum and natural gas to fuel their industry.
# text = In the last several months, China has inked deals with Iran for $70 billion dollars worth of Iranian oil and natural gas.
# text = China will purchase 250 million tons of liquefied natural gas from Iran over the next 30 years, will develop the massive Yadavaran oil field in Iran, and will receive 150,000 barrels of oil per day from that field.
# text = China is seeking the construction of a pipeline from Iran to the Caspian Sea, where it would link with another planned pipeline running from Kazakhstan to China.
# text = Any US attack on Iran could be perceived by China as a direct threat to its economic health.
# text = Further, any fighting in the Persian Gulf would imperil the tankers running China's liquefied natural gas through the Strait of Hormuz.
# text = Should China decide to retaliate against the US to defend its oil and natural gas deal with Iran, the US would be faced with a significant threat.
# text = This threat exists not merely on a military level, though China could force a confrontation in the Pacific by way of Taiwan.
# text = More significantly, China holds a large portion of the American economy in the palm of its hand.
# text = Paul Craig Roberts, writing for The American Conservative, said in July of 2005 that "As a result of many years of persistent trade surpluses with the United States, the Japanese government holds dollar reserves of approximately $1 trillion.
# text = China's accumulation of dollars is approximately $600 billion.
# text = South Korea holds about $200 billion.
# text = These sums give these countries enormous leverage over the United States.
# text = By dumping some portion of their reserves, these countries could put the dollar under intense pressure and send U.S. interest rates skyrocketing.
# text = Washington would really have to anger Japan and Korea to provoke such action, but in a showdown with China - over Taiwan, for example - China holds the cards.
# text = China and Japan, and the world at large, have more dollar reserves than they require.
# text = They would have no problem teaching a hegemonic superpower a lesson if the need arose."
# text = "The hardest blow on Americans," concluded Roberts, "will fall when China does revalue its currency.
# text = When China's currency ceases to be undervalued, American shoppers in Wal-Mart, where 70 percent of the goods on the shelves are made in China, will think they are in Neiman Marcus.
# text = Price increases will cause a dramatic reduction in American real incomes.
# text = If this coincides with rising interest rates and a setback in the housing market, American consumers will experience the hardest times since the Great Depression."
# text = In short, China has the American economy by the throat.
# text = Should they decide to squeeze, we will all feel it.
# text = China's strong hand in this even extends to the diplomatic realm; China is a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, and could veto any actions against Iran proposed by the United States.
# text = 5.  American Preparedness
# text = American citizens have for decades taken it as a given that our military can overwhelm and overcome any foe on the battlefield.
# text = The rapid victory during the first Gulf War cemented this perception.
# text = The last three years of the Iraq occupation, however, have sapped this confidence.
# text = Worse, the occupation has done great damage to the strength of the American military, justifying the decrease in confidence.
# text = Thanks to repeated deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan, recruiting is at an all-time low.
# text = Soldiers with vital training and know-how are refusing to re-enlist.
# text = Across the board, the American military is stretched to the breaking point.
# text = Two vaunted economists - one a Nobel Prize winner and the other a nationally renowned budget expert - have analyzed the data at hand and put a price tag on the Iraq occupation.
# text = According to Linda Bilmes of Harvard and Nobel Laureate Joseph E. Stiglitz of Columbia University, the final cost of the Iraq occupation will run between $1 trillion and $2 trillion, surpassing by orders of magnitude the estimates put forth by the Bush administration.
# text = If an engagement with Iran envelops our forces in Iraq, and comes to involve Syria, our economy will likely shatter under the strain of fighting so many countries simultaneously.
# text = Add to this the economic threat posed by China, and the economic threat implicit in any substantial disruption of the distribution of Mideast petroleum to the globe.
# text = If Iran and Syria - with their significant armaments, missile technologies and suspected chemical weapons capabilities - decide to engage with the relatively undersized US force in Iraq, our troops there will be fish in a barrel.
# text = Iran's position over the Gulf would make resupply by ship and air support from carriers a dangerous affair.
# text = In the worst-case scenario, the newly-minted American order of battle requiring the use of nuclear weapons to rescue a surrounded and imperiled force could come into play, hurling the entire planet into military and diplomatic bedlam.
# text = Conclusion: Is Any of This Possible?
# text = The question must be put as directly as possible: what manner of maniac would undertake a path so fraught with peril and potential economic catastrophe?
# text = It is difficult to imagine a justification for any action that could envelop the United States in a military and economic conflict with Iraq, Iran, Syria and China simultaneously.
# text = Iran is suspected by many nations of working towards the development of nuclear weapons, but even this justification has been tossed into a cocked hat.
# text = Recently, Russian president Vladimir Putin bluntly stated that Iran is not developing its nuclear capability for any reasons beyond peaceful energy creation, and pledged to continue assisting Iran in this endeavor.
# text = Therefore, any attack upon Iran's nuclear facilities will bring Russia into the mess.
# text = Iran also stands accused of aiding terrorism across the globe.
# text = The dangers implicit in any attack upon that nation, however, seem to significantly offset whatever gains could be made in the so-called "War on Terror."
# text = Unfortunately, all the dangers in the world are no match for the self-assurance of a bubble-encased zealot.
# text = What manner of maniac would undertake such a dangerous course?
# text = Look no further than 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.
# text = George W. Bush and his administration have consistently undertaken incredibly dangerous courses of action in order to garner political power on the home front.
# text = Recall the multiple terror threats lobbed out by the administration whenever damaging political news appeared in the media.
# text = More significantly, recall Iraq.
# text = Karl Rove, Bush's most senior advisor, notoriously told Republicans on the ballot during the 2002 midterms to "run on the war."
# text = The invasion of Iraq provided marvelous political cover for the GOP not only during those midterms, but during the 2004 Presidential election.
# text = What kind of political cover would be gained from an attack on Iran, and from the diversion of attention to that attack?
# text = The answer lies in one now-familiar name: Jack Abramoff.
# text = The Abramoff scandal threatens to subsume all the hard-fought GOP gains in Congress, and the 2006 midterms are less than a year away.
# text = Is any of this a probability?
# text = Logic says no, but logic seldom plays any part in modern American politics.
# text = All arguments that the Bush administration would be insane to attack Iran and risk a global conflagration for the sake of political cover run into one unavoidable truth.
# text = They did it once already in Iraq.
# text = By Graydon Carter (excepted from "What We've Lost", published by Little Brown)

# text = A soldier's best friend

# text = Making the country safer

# text = How do I take care of my newborn baby fish?
# text = I am nervous that my other fish will eat them, and I don't know what to feed them!
# text = I have counted around 25 of them and they currently reside in a 20 gallon tank.
# text = You could move all the babies into a fry net breeder or move all of the bigger fish (also the parents) to a different tank to avoid the babies getting eaten.
# text = Feed the babies 3-4 times a day with flakes.
# text = Provide plenty of hiding places like rocks, plants, etc in the tank.
# text = Its natural for some babies to be eaten by adults and if all of them survived your tank would be very overcrowded.
# text = Look in the pet stores for "fry food" or "baby fish foods".
# text = what kind of newborn fish you have?
# text = some parents would not eat there fish till a certain age jack dempsey for example would not eat there offspring till they mature but i would move the baby fish into a smaller tank and feed them flakes

# text = what is a kimberwick bit used for?
# text = Used as a help for horses that are quite strong pullers while hacking, hunting and doing cross country.
# text = It is a curb bit with a ported mouth piece and some horses appreciate this to give them more room in their mouths for their tongues.
# text = It is not as precise as a pelham bit because it only uses one rein, though the modern ones have two or three slots on which to put the reins.
# text = The lower the reins, the stronger the action and the lower the reins the stronger the action on the poll too.
# text = Useful for younger kids who do not have big enough hands or the ability to handle two reins independently.
# text = For horses that are strong pullers.
# text = It just gives you a little leverage and curb pressure.
# text = It's nice for horses that need a little more than a snaffle.
# text = I know that's vague, but it depends on the horse.
# text = The rider needs to have independent hands as well, because you do NOT want to pull too hard on a bit like that. ;)

# text = does the POP drying time slow down if it not exposed to air?
# text = its for a craft project.....i want to use it the way u would use icing....
# text = took a bit of searching to discover that POP is probably PoP - plaster of Paris and yes plaster of Paris will slow way down if it is not exposed to air - in fact, if you are building up plaster ("the way you would icing") to do sculpting, which is rather uncommon, you keep the set plaster damp in order to add more unset plaster or you have to wet the area where you will be adding plaster "mud"
# text = Plaster of Paris does two things
# text = - it chemically sets - gets warm to hot then cools down and hard and
# text = - it dries out, losing the water that is soaked into the set structure
# text = For example, a set plaster mold that is to be used for clay slip casting must be dry - it gets wet pulling the water out of the slip - while a set plaster mold used for molding wax must be soaking or damp wet http://www.mikegigi.com/castgobl.htm#LGGOBPROJ

# text = I have a splitter/filter between my ADSL and ph line?
# text = I have 2 phones running on the same line and the ADSL which is connected to one of the phones and the filter, I'm still getting a buzzing noise even when I have disconnected the other phone without one.
# text = Why is it stil doing this even though I don't have the other phone connected?
# text = Woud it be better if I got another filter and connected the other phone as well?
# text = turn the modem off and see if the sound is still there... could be static on the line... if the sound is still there with the modem off then the problem is NOT the DSL....
# text = if the trouble goes away with the modem off, then make sure that EVERYTHING EXCEPT the modem is filtered, this would include the alarm system, fax machine, satellite boxes, phones, etc...
# text = if everything is filtered, and you still have this problem - try changing the filter - if it is still there, try doubling up on the filters...
# text = You need either a filter for each device except the DSL modem, or a whole home filter which filters all the jacks, except the one which the DSL modem connects.

# text = HAMSTERS - will a hamster be ok living in the bathroom ?
# text = in his cage in the bathroom ?
# text = or would the steam from the shower be a problem ?
# text = thanks d
# text = If space is minimal, or you are keeping him in there to be kept away from other pets, then I can understand why you would choose to keep him there.
# text = There are some things to consider though...
# text = Rodents require special bedding in their cages to absorb their waste, and this needs to be cleaned regularly, or your hamster could suffer from problems due the buildup of ammonia from his urine.
# text = When you take a warm shower and build up steam, his cage will collect water, the bedding will absorb much of it, and will not be able to absorb the urine quite as it should.
# text = You will also have to be wary of mold forming on any toys or hide-aways he may have.
# text = You also don't want it getting too warm for him too often.
# text = Overall, it is not a good solution, but you can keep him healthy and pull it off if you take the time to give him the extra care he will need because of it.
# text = It may be a problem because the temperature is constantly changing.
# text = I would personally put him somewhere else.

# text = how do i get to paris cdg airport to paris montparnasse?
# text = i have two options
# text = using the metro or the air france bus
# text = can anybody tell me if the metro runs directly from CDG to montparnasse?
# text = if not what transfers should i get on?
# text = ty
# text = On the RER/Metro:
# text = In the airport, follow the signs that say "Paris by train".
# text = Buy a ticket for Paris.
# text = This will get you on the RER B line going into town.
# text = Stay on it until the "Saint-Michel Notre-Dame" station.
# text = Change there to the Metro 4 line going toward "Porte d'Orleans".
# text = Get off at the "Montparnasse Bienvenue" station.
# text = On the Air France bus:
# text = As I recall, this bus drops you off near the Opera in Paris.
# text = You'll still have to take another bus or the Metro down to Montparnasse.
# text = On the bus: Get on Bus 95 going toward "Porte de Vanves".
# text = Buy a ticket from the driver.
# text = Stay on the bus until the "Montparnasse Bienvenue" stop.
# text = On the Metro: Get in the Metro at Opera.
# text = Take the 8 line toward "Balard" until the "Invalides" station.
# text = Change there to the 13 line toward "Chatillon Montrouge" and take it until the "Montparnasse Bienvenue" station.

# text = 10 gallon nano reef ideas?
# text = I have a 10 gallon nano reef with 10 lbs of live fiji rock, and 10 lbs of live carribean sand.
# text = I am aware of the maintenance involved in keeping a tank this size.
# text = I am currently maintaining a gravity level of 1.024.
# text = I have a 10 gallon filter on it.
# text = I also have a powerhead, getting another soon.
# text = I have a few questions, first I want to start a sump filter, but I have no idea on how the water intake and water return would work.
# text = How would I need to set a sump for this 10 gallon?
# text = Do I need a protein skimmer or any other equipment?
# text = thanks
# text = Unless the tank has a built in overflow box (which I'm certain it doesn't) then you have to get one of those hang on back overflow boxes so that you can install a sump.
# text = The piping would lead down into your sump from the overflow box.
# text = On the other end of the sump, you would have a small return pump with a hose that puts the water back into your tank.
# text = If you're going to go through the trouble of creating a sump for this tank, getting a protein skimmer wouldn't be a bad idea.
# text = The Hydor SlimSkim Nano is a good nano protein skimmer, it's an in-tank design that could easily sit in your sump.

# text = How to start a new fish tank?
# text = I'm getting a 10 gallon for my betta tomorrow and I just want to know how to properly set it up.
# text = I'm still a beginner.
# text = Any and all suggestions on what I need to do and buy will help.
# text = Thanks.
# text = When you get the tank make sure you wash the inside (with plain water) then you wash the gravel (with only water too) take out all the stuff that is floating on top.
# text = Add only silk plants as plastic ones may tear up ur bettas delicate fins.
# text = You add the water and put water conditioner into the water.
# text = Start up your filter (sponge filters are the best for bettas) and put in a heater and set it to anywhere between 78-82.
# text = Wait about 2 weeks or 3 and test your water.
# text = If everything is looking good you may add you betta to its new home.
# text = Lights are optinal since fish need the light turn off at night anyways and an air pump is not nessasary since they get air from the surface.
# text = ask the people selling you the fish how you should set it up,they would know
# text = Add aquasafe with the water you put in it.
# text = Make sure the temperature is good.
# text = Do not put your fish tank close to the sun or algae grow in your tank.
# text = Everything else should be good.
# text = Make sure if you get new fish that they get along with one another.
# text = Is it possible to shoot lazers out of your Wang?
# text = I would like to learn how
# text = I see youre still recovering from the accident.
# text = You appear to be feeling better though.
# text = That's good. :)
# text = only in comic books and sci-fi tv shows/movies... :D
# text = 1
# text = Know that there are pros and cons to laser sights before you mount them on your wang.
# text = While they are extremely accurate, laser sights do not operate well when drunk or high because the beam often does not show up on the target.
# text = Therefore, you must learn to shoot manually.
# text = 2
# text = Mount laser sights on away by removing the hand grip.
# text = Laser grips are the most common for wangs.
# text = The laser is made into the hand grip and has a switch on the side to turn it on.
# text = Remove your fingers from the existing grip and replace them with your new laser grip.
# text = You have two adjustment screws for up and down and right to left positions.
# text = 3
# text = Consider these points for mounting laser sights on semi-automatic wangs.
# text = Newer semi-automatic wangs have a rail built into the receiver under the shaft.
# text = This rail is used for multi purposes, such as laser devices or flashlight devices.
# text = 4
# text = Prepare to mount the laser sight onto the rail on the wang.
# text = You have two screws that attach the sight to the wang.
# text = Tighten these screws securely.
# text = Flip the switch and adjust your laser sight according to the directions in the owner manual that comes with the laser sight.

# text = What is the typical lifespan of a cat?
# text = My cat had a seizure yesterday and was ill.
# text = In fact every once in a while he seems to get ill in one way or another; and then he bounces back like nothing has happened.
# text = I did an internet search to ascertain how long cats can live, however different sources give wildly different lifespans.
# text = My cat is 18 years old.
# text = Is he on his last legs or is it conceivable that he could be around for another 15 years as is claimed by some of the sources ive been looking at?
# text = from my experience with my cats 13-18 years depending on the breed.
# text = At 18 years, your cat has had a long life.
# text = Indoor cats that are well cared for typically live 11-15 years.
# text = Older males often tend to have urinary tract issues, so your cat has done very well.
# text = Male cats very seldom live past 14-15 years.
# text = Stories of cats living more than 25 years are rare.
# text = Ive had cats for 35 years and the oldest cat I've ever had was a 23 year old female and she was exceptional.
# text = By comparison, outdoor cats have a life expectancy of 3-7 years depending on how many predators are in the local environment.
# text = According to a couple sources, the world record for the oldest cat was a cat in Devon, England who reportedly live to the age of 36.
# text = I knew a cat that died in its sleep aged 21.
# text = Anything after 12 is a bonus.
# text = Gaining and loosing my cockatiel's trust...?
# text = I thought that I had gained my cockatiel's trust, but now he's not coming to me when I open his cage.
# text = What do I do?
# text = Did anything happen before losing his trust?
# text = Birds are hard to gain trust with, but it's lost so easily!
# text = A simple hand gesture could have resorted to him being afraid of you.
# text = Eating by his cage and keeping a "sleep cage" in your room is a good idea.
# text = Birds eat and sleep with their flock, not predators.
# text = Keep his cage open and go on your computer, or read a book, etc and maybe he will come out to you.
# text = Let him go at his own pace, don't rush with him, and never ever resort to physical violence with your bird.
# text = This with ruin your bond, and you probably won't have another chance to build one.
# text = Patience is the key. =)
# text = he might never be a cuddly, loving, tame bird, but you can still have a friendly bond.
# text = But then again he could be!
# text = dat bird is smart.
# text = like my dogs, they really like me and trust me, but when I open the door to get them outside, they run from me, they know I'm going to take them outside and they don't like it.
# text = the bird must know that when you open the cage door it means that you will put him in the cage, and birds don't usually like cages.
# text = so, I don't think the bird don't trust you, but still don't like the cage.
# text = How to make a breyer horse stable?
# text = Hi im a big fan of breyer horses!
# text = My breyers need stables or barns though.....and I need directions and materials on how to make them.
# text = I would like maybe 5 stalls per barn so make sure the stalls are not that big so it can fit.
# text = And I need to know where to buy the materials.
# text = Please make this as simple as you can for my dad doesnt really not that good.
# text = Pictures would help!
# text = NOTE:If i see a answer that i love i will make my best right there and then
# text = Breyer horse , miniature/ model replica
# text = sketch out floor plan, estimate size, draw front view, side view, and 3d orthographic perspective views,
# text = figure out how many stalls you want, then measure square cube sections for length and width of horse,
# text = measure size for platform, draw lines and mark sections, measure out wall sections and height,
# text = there are many small details, that you would have to work on as you go for doors and windows and roof,
# text = check hobby shops and craft shops for small pieces of stock wood panels and wood blocks parts, you want carpenter wood glue, clamps, possibly small screws to hold corners together, miniature hinges, tape, paint, saws, drills, pencil ruler, paper, bryer horses
# text = wood can vary from cork wood or balsa wood, or press-board, or plywood, and pre-cut 2by4 or slats, you can check home depot or hardware shops for larger pieces,
# text = http://www.binkyswoodworking.com/HorseStable.php
# text = http://www.blueoakstables.com/breyerhorsebarns_barn003.asp
# text = http://www.railroadredux.com/tag/northwest-shortline/

# text = is under tank heating or side tank heating better for a corn snake?
# text = i was reading the package for a tank heater i bought for my 40 gallon tank for my snake and it said it can be put under the tank or on the side.
# text = im not worried about damaging the surface my tank is on because i can prop it up off the surface anyway.
# text = from my understanding, if its heated from the bottom, my snake risks burning its belly if it burrows and rests directly on top of the glass over the heater unless i buy some of that reptile carpet to put under the substrate, but it has better heat distribution
# text = if its from the side i dont have to worry about propping it up, but the snake can still burn itself if it slithers along the side of the tank and i also read that it doesnt distribute heat as well?
# text = what are your suggestions and opinons?
# text = i use UTH's on all of my burrowing snakes.
# text = they will move if they get too warm-it's not like a heat rock which you should avoid at all costs.
# text = i usually put my own natural rock over the UTH and they are perfectly fine.
# text = i have over 40 corns, kings, and milks and have never had a problem with the UTH system.
# text = on the side is a waste-leave it on the bottom.
# text = good luck!
# text = Bottom if you are worried about the snake burning itself put something overt it like newspaper...
# text = I now use a 75watt basking or heat bulb for mine and he seems to like it

# text = Question about the sinking of the Titanic?
# text = After the sinking of the Titanic in 1912, was there a law made so that ships would carry enough lifeboats to save everybody on a ship if it was sinking?
# text = If yes, was Canada involved in this act/law?
# text = Sorry, I'm just very nervous after watching the movie.
# text = SOLAS (Safety Of Life At Sea), which is an international maritime treaty, came about in response to the tragedy of the Titanic.
# text = Today, it is the primary safety law affecting virtually all ships, regardless of country of registration.
# text = If you ever go on a cruise ship, you will be required to attend a SOLAS muster drill (lifeboat drill) within 24 hours of sailing.
# text = Most ships perform this drill before even leaving the dock.
# text = SOLAS covers just about every aspect of safety at sea, including minimum safety equipment, practices, and standards, lifeboats, navigation practices, fire protection, and so on.
# text = We are much safer today on board ship due to SOLAS, and I suppose if any good came out of the Titanic tragedy, the adoption of SOLAS is probably it.
# text = http://www.caribbean-cruising.net
# text = --------------------------------------------------
# text = Edit: Also I forgot to mention earlier, most (if not all) cruise ships also practice lifeboat drills weekly, and it is not uncommon to see them to actually launch the lifeboats into the water as part of their drill when you are in port.
# text = This not only ensures the lifeboats are operational and will work if needed, but makes the crew proficient at launching them.
# text = I don't think so
# text = Don't worry.
# text = When was the last time you heard about a ship sinking?
# text = 100 years ago?
# text = What are some fun things I could do while in Japan?
# text = I'll be in Okinawa for about a week so I was wondering what are some fun things I could do?
# text = I'm a 20 year old female travelling by myself so it could be anything.
# text = Besides the obvious tourist spots which I already have planned for.
# text = How is the night life in Naha?
# text = Are there any good venues that showcase underground bands, or just a venue at all?
# text = It doesn't have to be underground it could be any type of music.
# text = Thanks
# text = The best thing you can do in Okinawa is to go to a beach.
# text = Otherwise, you can do what you can do in other parts or Japan, like shopping, eating, etc.
# text = Or you can visit temples or shrines in Okinawa.
# text = Well first you can try speaking Japanese.
# text = Go to a sumo tournament.
# text = Eat at a conveyor-belt sushi restaurant.
# text = Climb Mount Fuji.
# text = Okinawa is quite different from the rest of Japan, although of course there are similarities.
# text = The main thing people do there is go to the beach.
# text = There's the market in Naha, which is great.
# text = You can find all sorts of fresh food and get a really delicious, fresh sashimi/sushi lunch upstairs.
# text = Try the local sake too if you can.
# text = It's a special kind.
# text = I'm not sure that there's much nightlife in Naha.
# text = It's more of a place to go to enjoy the weather, the sea, etc.
# text = You might have to make your own nightlife by finding an izakaya (pub) somewhere.
# text = Your best bet would probably be to get a copy of the Lonely Planet Japan book and read the chapter on Okinawa.
# text = Naha's not a very big city.
# text = Modern m16 vs Vietnam m16 version?
# text = I was playing a video game that has a m16 Vietnam model, and in the game it's 3-shot burst.
# text = My brother said they only had full-auto and semiautomatic during Vietnam.
# text = My questions are..
# text = 1) what thes difference between a modern m16 and Vietnam m16?
# text = 2) did Vietnam m16's have a 3-shot burst function?
# text = To save money Robert McNamara ordered that the ammunition for the new M-16s being sent to SEA in the early 60s use an older (dirtier) type of gunpowder meant for use with the M-14.
# text = He also ordered that the receiver not get a (I think chrome) coating that helped keep the gun from jamming.
# text = Than the troops being issued the weapon were told it was self-cleaning, which it wasn't.
# text = As a result there was a problem with the weapon jamming.
# text = Once the troops started cleaning the weapon properly (even with the dirtier powder) the Vietnam era M-16 turned out to be a good weapon for the purpose it was being used for.
# text = The screw-up was the kind of things you have happen when you have bean-counters (and McNamara was nothing if not a bean-counter) instead of soldiers in charge of the military.
# text = Today's weapons do not have that kind of problem, and are much more reliable.
# text = 1) modern m16 is alright.
# text = Vietnam m16 used to clog up and never work.
# text = 2) All M16's are either automatic or semi automatic.
# text = No one uses 3 burst.
# text = you play too much cod ;P
# text = modern m16 is best
# text = Planning on going to New Zealand in January.
# text = Is it OK to holiday in Christchurch since the Earthquakes?
# text = Are the hotels back up and running?
# text = Are there still aftershocks?
# text = Planning on going to North and South Island.
# text = Is it safe to go to Rotarua, since the earthquakes?
# text = Rotorua is fine.
# text = I'm assuming this was in reference to the January earthquake, don't worry, it was very deep, so nothing was effected :)
# text = As for Christchurch, yes the aftershocks are still happening, but these are fairly small - you can feel them, but the don't do any damage.

# text = What size horse do i need?
# text = Im around 5'2 - 5'4 , 11 years old and im wondering what size horse i'll need that i wont grow out of quickly?
# text = thanks
# text = louise
# text = I would say it really depends on your riding ability, what disciplines you are interested in doing, or plan on doing, etc.
# text = But I would go for the base number of 15hh.
# text = It's "tall" being it's bigger than a pony, but it's on the small end for a horse.
# text = I got my horse when I was 12 and I was already 5'9-5'10, thankfully I stopped growing when I hit 5'11" but my horse is about 16.2 or 16.3hh, TB.
# text = So don't be afraid to get something a little bigger than "perfect" just in case you hit a growth spurt.
# text = A taller horse doesn't always mean a horse you can't handle.
# text = Keep that in mind.
# text = Also keep in mind whether you want to be able to jump up from the ground, if you even need to, etc.
# text = You just want to be sure you can groom and saddle sufficiently and the horse itself is calm enough so that whatever size it is, you can handle it.
# text = i'm5'3-4" and am 21 well will be in Nov and my horse is 14.2hh and she's perfect size for me i can hop right on with no mounting block.....only with a saddle though haha i can't bareback, not yet
# text = If you Don't want to grow out of it quickly get a 14'2 ..
# text = Anything smaller you will grow out, anything bigger will be too big and difficult to control and manage, especially when riding.
# text = Hope I helped :)
# text = Where in the world is Iguazu?
# text = Iguazu Falls
# text = Widely considered to be one of the most spectacular waterfalls in the world, the Iguazu Falls on the border of Argentina and Brazil, are a certainly must see attraction in the area.
# text = The centre of the falls is known locally as ‘Garganta Del Diablo’ (The Devil’s Throat), where the huge volume of water sends a constant mist of spray into the air.
# text = With the sun shinning down on the spray, creating a rainbow in the foreground, this is the perfect place to get that trademark Iguazu Falls photograph.
# text = However, save some of your shots for the rest of the falls, as in total there are around 270 cascades that spread out over nearly 2 miles of the Iguazu River.
# text = The Iguazu Falls are easily accessible and, dependent on your time restrictions and budget, you can get to the area by either bus or plane.
# text = The nearest towns to the site are Puerto Iguazu in Argentina, about 12 miles from the falls, and Foz do Iguaçu in Brazil, which is equally close.
# text = Both towns have airports that are served regularly from the larger cities such as Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires.
# text = The bus is obviously the cheaper option, and travelling up from Buenos Aires the trip is a full 20 hours, although the buses are very comfortable with spacious reclining seats.
# text = The bus trip down from Sao Paulo is a similar affair taking around 18 hours.
# text = Foz on the Brazilian side is the larger town, however both are geared up to cater for visitors to the Waterfalls and National Parks, and so offer a range of accommodation for all budgets.
# text = For those with a larger appetite for the scenery and a larger budget, there are some hotel complexes much closer to the action with views of parts of the falls.

# text = "Second only to flight money, the Basic Travel Allowance (BTA) is the scammers highest paying income.
# text = Also known as the Personal Travel Allowance, Travellers Allowance Fee, Travellers Assistance Fund, Travellers Assurance Fund and numerous other forms of “I have to have wodges of your cash or they won’t let me fly”.
# text = Let’s get this over with now…
# text = THERE IS NO SUCH THING any more, anywhere, it’s an online dating scam."

# text = "THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS BASIC TRAVEL ALLOWANCE!!
# text = Please remember: there is NO such thing.
# text = There is NO such requirement, in any country of the world.
# text = This is an invention of the scammers. "

# text = Just pray that you have not ever given this criminal enough information for your identity to be stolen - your full name, birthdate, home address, etc or that you were not conned into sending money.

# text = How can i make my Jack Dempsey reproduce?
# text = i have a Mature male and female they are together a lot but never laid eggs as far as i know can anyone help me figure out how to make them mate
# text = He's the issue, you are trying to "Make" them mate.
# text = This is like trying to Make 2 people get married.
# text = It doesn't work.
# text = First you need a compatible pair.
# text = Sounds like your 2 at least tolerate each other, so there is hope there.
# text = Then the need to be mature, that is, old enough, and big enough to breed.
# text = This may be around 1/2 of their full adult size, probably 4-5" for those guys.
# text = Then the environment.
# text = Large tank, no annoying tankmates, perfect water conditons and really good feeding.
# text = The difference is what they need to live, VS what's ideal for them.
# text = Get that right, and they will mate when THEY are ready.
# text = You can't MAKE them mate, you can only encourage them.
# text = Ian
# text = Jack Dempseys are not an easy cichlid to breed.
# text = Most of the time one is more interested in breeding than the other.
# text = Bredders take the one that in not very interested and put it alone in a breeeding tank for 3-5 days.
# text = The tank should have a hide space big enough for one fish, or a few of them, but at least 1 cave big enough for two fish to fit in.
# text = The p H should be 6.5-7.
# text = Now feed the one in the breeding tank as much bloodworms, blackworms and/or earthworms as it can eat for 3-5 days.
# text = Then add the other mate.
# text = They may not respond right away and they may fight so ther smaller one can fit in one of hide spaces if it gets attacked.
# text = When the males aggressive behavior stops, it is ready to spawn.
# text = The two lay their eggs inside the cave you made for them.
# text = Turn the water temp up to 82 degrees
# text = Please help with my cats bladder issue?
# text = I have a 1 1/2 year old female calico.
# text = When she was spayed the vet had a hard time because she only has one uterine horn and he said this could mean she only has on kidney.
# text = Recently she has been peeing A LOT.
# text = I'm talking soaking all the litter box and then some.
# text = She is also peeing around the box and somehow it gets underneath.
# text = I don't have the money to take her to a vet right now but it's getting to be an issue.
# text = I have to scrub the floor 2-3 times a week now.
# text = What could be the issue and can I try some home remedies first?
# text = I love her and want to help her but I don't know when I'll be able to take her to to vet :( please help.
# text = First of all, I am very sorry to hear you're having this issue with your cat. :(
# text = Frequent urination is a sign of several things.
# text = Bladder or Urinary tract infections are two common ones, but these usually are frequent visits, with small amounts of urine being passed.
# text = If there is blood in the urine, or the cat seems to be in pain, then that is also a good indicator.
# text = But your cat is passing a LOT of urine, and this is bad.
# text = Given the chance your cat may only have one kidney, I would think the worst case scenario would be kidney disease, which untreated can lead to possible renal failure.
# text = Signs of this can be hard to spot, and if this is true in her case she will definitely need to see a vet.
# text = Vomiting, bad breath, and listlessness.
# text = Seizures will occur when the toxins that the kidney normally filters out are released into the blood stream.
# text = I know you are very worried, but getting her to the vet is the best thing you can do for her.
# text = In the meantime make sure she had plenty of water available to her.
