# text = HOWEVER ... that same web page also states that "The current pass mark is 67.
# text = The pass mark could change.
# text = You should check for updated information on a regular basis."
# text = The Skilled Worker category was my first attempt at permanent residency.
# text = And between the time I began my research and the time I applied, the minimum score did change once.
# text = Unfortunately, both minimums were above my score.
# text = But I got lucky because I qualified under another category to become a permanent resident.
# text = So keep checking at least on a weekly basis.

# text = Here is what they posted there
# text = "4. May I qualify under the Skilled Worker category even if I score less than 67 points?"
# text = "If the Canadian Immigration Visa Officer believes that the point total does not accurately reflect your ability to become economically established in Canada, the Canadian Immigration Visa Officer may use his or her positive discretion (referred to as substituted evaluation) and approve your application even though you score less than 67 points."
# text = Read the full answer at that web page for conditions.
# text = Sure you can apply.
# text = The points system acts as a guide to sort out the best candidates.
# text = Your application is still evaluated on a number of criteria, not all of them as "cast in steel" as the points.

# text = What is Italian High Renaissance?
# text = Have a look at this, it may help.
# text = 1) The Italian Renaissance began the opening phase of the Renaissance, a period of great cultural change and achievement in Europe that spanned the period from the end of the 13th century to about 1600, marking the transition between Medieval and Early Modern Europe.
# text = The term renaissance is in essence a modern one that came into currency in the 19th century, in the work of historians such as Jacob Burckhardt.
# text = Although the origins of a movement that was confined largely to the literate culture of intellectual endeavor and patronage can be traced to the earlier part of the 14th century, many aspects of Italian culture and society remained largely Medieval; the Renaissance did not come into full swing until the end of the century.
# text = The word renaissance (Rinascimento in Italian) means “rebirth”, and the era is best known for the renewed interest in the culture of classical antiquity after the period that Renaissance humanists labelled the Dark Ages.
# text = These changes, while significant, were concentrated in the elite, and for the vast majority of the population life was little changed from the Middle Ages.
# text = 2)The expression High Renaissance, in art history, is a periodizing convention used to denote the apogee of the visual arts in the Italian Renaissance.
# text = The High Renaissance period is traditionally taken to begin in the 1490s, with Leonardos fresco of the Last Supper in Milan and the death of Lorenzo de' Medici in Florence, and to have ended in 1527 with the sacking of Rome by the troops of Charles V.
# text = This term was first used in German (Hochrenaissance) in the early nineteenth century, and has its origins in the "High Style" of painting and sculpture described by Johann Joachim Winckelmann.
# text = [1] Over the last twenty years, use of the term has been frequently criticized by academic art historians for over-simplifying artistic developments, ignoring historical context, and focusing only on a few iconic works.
# text = [2]
# text = Hope it helps!
# text = I'm American and I am going to the UK for the first time, what should I expect?
# text = do you get your visitors visa immediately at the airport?
# text = I was told that americans automatically get a six months visitors visa.

# text = There is no medical exam or blood test or others like that.
# text = You do not need to call the embassies to get professional advice.

# text = Above is the link to the Department of State travel website, which will give you all the info that you need, including passport information.
# text = It is free.

# text = You should be fine with just a passport, unless you're staying longer than six months.

# text = What would you get if you cross a sussex male and a silkie female?
# text = i had a sussex male and a pekin female i bought 2 silkies what would the sussex female and the silkie females would make ?
# text = if you had any pics of your hens i would like to see them to compare them to mine thanks?
# text = A Sussex crossed with Silkie would make a crossbred *mutt* chicken.
# text = There are a lot of genetics at play between a Sussex and Silkie, so the offspring would vary in appearance.
# text = You don't say what color Silkie or Sussex you are dealing with so I can't say what color your chicks would be likely to be.
# text = However, I can say what features they would/could have.
# text = Feather Type.
# text = Silkies have hookless feathers.
# text = Sussexs have soft feathers.
# text = All offspring from this cross will have soft feathers, as hookless feathers are a recessive gene.
# text = Skin Color: Silkies have black skin color, which is dominate.
# text = Sussex have White Skin which could be recessive or dominate.
# text = Either way rec. and dom. white genes dilute the black gene.
# text = Skin will be darker but lighter then the Silkies.
# text = Beards/Muffs: If your Silkie has a beard/muff the offspring could have a beard as well, as these genes are incomplete dominate.
# text = Feathered Feet/Shanks- Chicks could have feathered feet/shanks as this is also incomplete dominate.
# text = Crest: Chicks could also develop a small crest due to this being another incomplete dominate gene.
# text = Comb Type: Silkies have walnut combs which is actually genetically two comb types (Rose and Pea) single is also there, but is recessive.
# text = So crossed to a Sussex you could get a walnut, pea, rose, or single combed bird.
# text = Five Toes: Silkies have five toes.
# text = Sussex have four toes.
# text = Crossed together (five toes is incompletely dominate) chicks could develop to have an fifth toe on both, or even one foot.
# text = Silkie crosses are great birds, and very neat looking.
# text = Hens make excellent mothers as they are bigger, can see better, and are smarter the Silkies.
# text = Best wishes,
# text = Jamie/RhodeRunner

# text = Using a fairly wide aperture is also helpful in blurring out unwanted background elements.
# text = I've had a few great shots ruined myself because there was something in the background I didn't notice at first.
# text = what are some unique customs in ireland?
# text = As far ask I’m aware our most unique custom would be the “Country Wake”.
# text = In all my travels I’ve never seen anything like it and am often met with an odd look when I explain them to foreigners.
# text = After a person dies, their remains are “waked ” in their home for roughly 2-3days.
# text = In this time visitors will come to the house, pay their respects to the desisted and their family and have a couple of cups of tea with a sandwich or a bun.
# text = The wake also included the night sit were friends and family sit up through the night with the remains.
# text = Wakes are common both north and south of the boarder with Protestants and Catholics alike.
# text = But only really in the countryside.
# text = The only notable difference I have noticed is that in the south of Ireland one night of the wake is often held in the chapel the night before the funeral, this tradition started after the civil war.
# text = Another unique custom (and a dying one at that) is the Pioneers.
# text = The Pioneers was an organization started at the end of the 19th century which pushed and supported the ideal of temperance (abstaining from alcohol), in an attempt to deal with the massive issue of alcoholism that Ireland was gripped by.
# text = Pioneers take a pledge to remain tee-total and at the hight of the organization popularity, had an estimated two million members even filling Croke Park on the 25th anniversary.
# text = The Orange Order and the 12th of July Marches would be argued by some not to be an Irish custom but unarguable ticks every criteria to be considered one.
# text = The marches on the 12th of July are only really attended by protestants in the Ulster but in spite of the are the largest attended paraded in Ireland.
# text = Barn brack and the ring.
# text = the irish customs we have in our family are; we make sinnel cake for easter ,barn brack and col-cannon for Halloween.
# text = christmas cake for christmas day.
# text = Do animals see images on a TV screen like humans do?
# text = Do animals see images on a TV screen like humans do?
# text = I'm unsure of this, because once I watched a commercial of cat food with my cat and she didn't react to seeing another cat on TV.
# text = I heard that a company (here is a link: http://news.yahoo.com/nestl-purina-releases-commercial-aimed-dogs-183443091.html ) is trying to make a dog food commercial aimed at dogs, complete with squeaky chew-toy sounds, and high pitched sounds that humans can't hear.
# text = As far as I understand, this ad will get dogs excited, but my question is: Can dogs actually see the images featured in the advert like humans?
# text = Also, can animals remember images on TV like us, humans?
# text = If so, then does that mean that if you watched a scary movie and your dog/cat/parrot was in the same room as you they will also get scared?
# text = I wouldn't know--I don't particularly like scary movies, and I haven't tried this with my pet.
# text = Although, I don't think that scary movies will affect pets for a long time; I am sure they'll forget sometime--or am I wrong?
# text = So what about T.V.?
# text = Do dogs enjoy watching T.V.?
# text = Well, T.V. is a series of flickering pictures that are streamed together to make a moving picture.
# text = The pictures are broadcast at a rate of about 60Hz, which is how fast they need to move for us to see them as a moving, flawless picture.
# text = To a dog, watching T.V. is a lot like watching and old scratchy silent film because their flicker fusion seems to occur at a rate of 70 to 80Hz.
# text = So chances are that if your dog likes to watch T.V., it’s probably because of the sounds.
# text = Hearing is a dog’s secondary sense, and I will discuss that in another blog entery.
# text = Yes they do.
# text = im pretty sure that they do see things on the tv screen because my cat chases things around the tv screen
# text = How much should I be looking at for horse transportation?
# text = I need one horse transported to shows throughout the 2012 show season, and the location is about 3 hours away from where I live.
# text = The place where I'm boarding is not likely to want to take me this far, and I do not have any ways of hauling him myself.
# text = So I want to hire someone (or multiple people) to transport me to these shows.
# text = If they ask how much I'm willing to pay, what is a good price range?
# text = I saw a site that charges $0.70 per mile.
# text = Is that reasonable?
# text = Impossible to say, but I guess you would have to work out fuel consumption for the particular vehicle that they are using and pay a proportion of that, and some on top for the driver's time and effort, unless you are able to share transport with another or more, that would keep the costs down.
# text = Remember that you get what you pay for.
# text = Three hours isn't far, but you are doing multiple shows.
# text = Some people are willing to take your horse, but they really have old trailers that are not the safest in the world.
# text = Rusted, torn corners in the stalls, unhealthy air, straight load instead of slant load can all make travelling hard, if not downright dangerous, on your horse.
# text = I had my horse transported from CA to WA and he came on this big, open stock trailer.
# text = He was dehydrated when he got there and lost weight.
# text = Since then, I now use a professional horse hauling service with people who ride with my horse to keep an eye on him, stop every few hours for water, and their trailers all have super smooth suspension.
# text = All horses I've had delivered to me since then are happy and healthy when they arrive.
# text = I would call Bob Hubbard Transport and get a quote.
# text = Even though you may not want to use them, it will give you some idea of what it might cost and what is fair.
# text = See link below.
# text = Make sure the trailer service you use is bonded/insured and knows something about first aid.

# text = 1. Here's a site that lists world cruises including prices.
# text = http://www.cruisecompete.com/specials/regions/world/1
# text = Prices listed, however, are usually based on two people in a cabin, and you will likely face some high "single supplement" costs in addition.
# text = (Two people in a cabin will spend more onboard, so cruise lines charge you more to sail alone.
# text = You may be able to do better on the rates if you request competitive quotes via CruiseCompete).
# text = 2. Short of chartering your own ship and crew, I don't see any way you could customize your own itinerary.
# text = Good luck!
# text = Various world cruises from most of the major cruise lines, typically 100 days in duration.
# text = Travelling on your own you would have to pay double as cabins are sold on the basis of double occupancy.
# text = No possibility to customise ports of call.
# text = Prearranged about 18 months in advance as the cruise lines sell segments all along the way i.e Transatlantic to London (England), England to Barcelona (Spain), Barcelona to Alexandria (Egypt), Egypt to India via Suez canal etc.
# text = yes there are multiple around the world cruises, mainly offered by the more upscale lines.
# text = HOWEVER: you will pay as if there are 2 people in the cabin, even if it is just you.
# text = so any price you find, DOUBLE IT figure, $40K at least.
# text = and no you cannot customize an itinerary unless you book several different legs of a cruise with stops in between on shore.. say book a Panamal Canal crossing, then fly to Asia and pick it up again and sail to India then fly to Europe to sail the Med before flying to England to hit the Transatlantic corssing.
# text = Was the San Francisco Bay Area mostly Caucasian back in the early 1970s?
# text = No.
# text = There has been a large Asian presence in the SF Bay Area for a long time--the Chinatown here was the largest population of chinese outside of China, there were lots of Japanese who'd been displaced during WWII.
# text = The whole Western Addition and a large portion of the Haight was black.
# text = The Mission was basically latin-american.
# text = As the southeast asians and philipinos came over, they added to the cultures.
# text = So, the Bay Area has been fairly mixed ethnically for a long time--caucasians may have seemed to be a large populous but that's because most tourists back then were caucasian and many of the hippies were caucasians so that's who the photographers took pictures of.
# text = The other ethicities weren't well represented in politics yet--or rather, they were just breaking the color barrier in the 70's due largely to the more open-minded hippy generation.
# text = Marin County was predominantly caucasian and many of the expanding outer east bay areas started out as white suburbs.
# text = It was not so long after Civil Rights laws against discrimination started to have an impact.
# text = You never saw black MUNI drivers, Asian police, Latino politicians until then.
# text = It was an evolution.
# text = Many illegals were not counted in the population until the mid-80s.
# text = We did not have big percent of Chinese migration until the mid 90s.
# text = We had fewer people running across the Mexican border then.
# text = We had fewer social benefits at that time for people so many immigrants were not counted.
# text = Only Caucasians had any political power, corporate presence or owned businesses except for Mom and Pop stores in some neighborhoods.
# text = San Francisco was settled in the 19th and 20th century by mainly European immigrants except for some Asian workers who were manual laborers.
# text = There has always been a Mexican-American cultural influence since Calif was owned by Mexico.
# text = We had a larger black population in the 70s than we have now but they did not have any power until Willie Brown was elected.
# text = San Francisco was always progressive and welcoming and tolerant to all kinds of people historically.
# text = The counties outside San Francisco were more white than San Francisco in the 70s.
# text = EDIT: My memory may not be good so you might get a more accurate answer from someone else who remembers the time.

# text = melting brass did not work?
# text = my friends and I are trying to melt bras to make some little figures.
# text = we have made a furnace as such, we took a clay flower pot with a hole in the bottom put a piece of steel pipe in the middle of it with a cap on the bottom, filled the pipe with brass scrap, surounded the pipe with charcoal lit it off and pumped air through the hole in the pot, everything got red hot but did not melt.
# text = what am I doing wrong
# text = I would recommend to start with something more simple like tin, pewter, aluminum or zinc, they all have a much more reasonable melting point.
# text = I'll just echo both other answers.
# text = Molten brass is damn hot and usually it's pressurized gas and forced air or oxygen.
# text = Even if you did melt it, I doubt you foresaw the issues of handling it and pouring it.
# text = It's really too advanced for a beginner, both in tooling and safety.
# text = Just the zinc fumes will get you, if you don't take precautions.
# text = Pewter is perfect for what you are doing, and it melts on a stove top.
# text = I would recommend to start with something more simple like tin, pewter, aluminum or zinc, they all have a much more reasonable melting point.
# text = Brass has an even higher melting point than bronze and I would think your charcoal just doesn't get hot enough.
# text = I bet you also did take charcoal as it is used for barbecue which does not get as hot as real coal (e.g. for blacksmithing one needs coal, not barbecue charcoal).
# text = I have done a fair amount of metal casting, but never tried to build my own furnace, but I think your version is just too small and doesn't get hot enough.
# text = I have melted small amounts of bronze in a crucible with a large propane torch (much larger than the plumbers torch, but it can be run of those propane cylinders you can buy for a gas grill).
# text = I melt brass and cast it http://www.mikegigi.com/castgobl.htm
# text = Brass melts at just under 2000F which is a bright yellow heat, not red hot.
# text = http://www.mikegigi.com/techspec.htm#SELCTEMP
# text = You might be able to make a version of your setup work, but it would take quite a bit of charcoal and a lot of forced air.
# text = I use propane with a blower and a burner I built http://www.mikegigi.com/meltmetl.htm and http://www.mikegigi.com/firehole.htm

# text = How to convince my parents to let me get a Ball python?
# text = They don't know ANYTHING about Ball pythons.
# text = When I ask my mom she says she will never let a snake in her house.
# text = She has no experience with snakes and has never held one.
# text = I did all my research and am well prepared to keep one, I'm 14 by the way
# text = Lay some knowledge on them dude.
# text = Maybe if they see how much time and effort you've devoted to researching the animal they'll reconsider.
# text = Tell them it costs like 8 dollars a month (if even that much) to keep it fed.
# text = Be helpful around the house to show that even if you can't pay for it yourself that youre willing to work for it.
# text = Once you've buttered them up a bit try to get them to the pet store and ask one of the employees to handle the snake showing your mom how gentle and harmless they can be.
# text = Maybe even try to get your mom to hold it a bit.
# text = My wife was TERRIFIED of snakes when we first met, I introduced her to one out my baby corn snakes and she fell in love with it.
# text = Be persistent, but don't pester them about it cause that'll get you nowhere fast.
# text = Good luck!
# text = My general convince your parents to let you get a reptile advice:
# text = 1. Be responsible.
# text = Do all your chores without being nagged, take care of any existing pets, keep your room clean, and so on.
# text = Prove, to your parents' satisfaction, that you, not they, will be the one actually taking care of your new pet.
# text = 2. Save up, and research, so that you are ready for your new pet.
# text = 3. Bargain with them.
# text = Offer to do extra chores, ask for your pet as a reward for good grades, something like that.
# text = 4. Play the sympathy card.
# text = If you can find a pet at a shelter, or that a friend needs to get rid of because they're moving or whatever, you might be able to talk your parents into "giving it a good home" where you might not be able to talk them into buying a new pet.
# text = On the fear angle--talk her into coming to the pet store with you.
# text = Once you're there, ask if you can hold a ball python.
# text = Once you're holding it, try to get her to touch/pet it...
# text = My Snake's meal is TOO big, what can I do?
# text = Just today I bought a medium rat for my beloved Ball Python Salazar (name after Harry Potter).
# text = Last time I got a medium rat it was a girl and my snake handled her easily.
# text = But today, I got a boy and realized that he is HUGE!
# text = I really do love my snake cause she is actually an affectionate cold-blooded creature.
# text = So my true question comes to this, how can I knock the rat out?
# text = If I threw him against a wall and still conscious he will run away, do I hang him by the tail so the blood can flush into his skull?
# text = I really do need answers and advice, and NOT INSULTING ANSWERS!!
# text = LIKE SERIOUSLY!! >:(
# text = Best answer shall receive points :)
# text = Ok so if youre snake will take pre-killed, you can "gas it".
# text = Just put the rat in a sealed tupperwear container with no airholes and wait until it passes out and dies and then feed it.
# text = If it won't take pre-killed and you usually feed live then you could hold the rat by the tail and whack it against a hard surface, like a refrigerator or wall.
# text = I don't like that option though - I think it's pretty cruel and I'd not done properly you'll end up really hurting the rat but not stunning him enough to stop possible injury to your snake.
# text = I would do the tupperwear idea TBH - easiest and most humane.
# text = You could also just wait until the rat passes out for about 1 minute and them feed it - at this point, it could still have a bit of a heart beat and be slightly still alive.
# text = And also maybe try holding the rat in feeding prongs so your snake can get a good hold and grip on his prey.
# text = Good luck!
# text = Just my opinion here - no judgement - getting your snake on frozen/thawed will prove to be much easier for you and safer for your snake in the long run.
# text = My opinion - take it for what it's worth… :-)

# text = Im moving from South Carolina so this will already be a huge culture shock.
# text = Any suggestions?
# text = Being gay and living in Toronto is just fine.
# text = You may consider the Gay Village on Church Street, right downtown.
# text = It is full of gay friendly "everything".
# text = For obvious reasons, knowing how extremely difficult it is to drive a car in the city, you should probably try to be near the subway system.
# text = But, can you immigrate?
# text = Being an American guarantees you no favours when it come to going to Canada.
# text = Start your process here, if you haven't already.
# text = (Marrying a Canadian is not enough - that doesn't count for at least two years.)
# text = http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/immigrate/index.asp
# text = A normal processing time, unless you have an advanced degree or a "specified" skill is from 3 - 5 years.
# text = Coming to stay, and overstay your three months visit will lead to immediate expulsion and a lifetime ban to immigrate to Canada - NOT GOOD.
# text = Lets be clear about this...........
# text = Just 'wanting to come to Canada " is NOT enough.
# text = You MUST apply, to become a Immigrant, and WAIT to be approved, by the Canadian Government.
# text = YOUR education ( the more the better ) and your past work history, combined with a CLEAN FBI and State Police record, and a satisfactory financial history ( no bankruptcies or large outstanding debts in the USA ) are all taken into consideration.
# text = It is a competition, and YOU will be competing with hundreds of thousands of others, from all over the world, for a place in the line up.
# text = IF you have NOT begun the Application process's NOW< you are about 2 to 3 years away from being approved by Immigration Canada.
# text = So don't pack your bags ,yet.
# text = Being an American and from the "south " you will be noticed as soon as you speak out loud .
# text = Do it properly, and legally, and you will be OK.

# text = Toronto.
# text = How to train my puppy ?
# text = I have a 4 months Shih Tzu puppy.
# text = Recently I'm having trouble training him.
# text = He is kind of hate walking with leash, every time I put the leash on, he will try to bite it.
# text = And he is not following me when I was walking.
# text = I saw lots of videos about this, but actually it didn't help.
# text = Is there any way can let him know how to walk with leash ?
# text = He is really excited about anybody he see.
# text = How to prevent this ?
# text = Last thing is every time I sit on a chair or something higher than him, he will try to jump on, if he can't, he will bark all the time until I let him get on, what should I do with this ?
# text = Anyone have any suggestion?
# text = thank you very much.
# text = Hi, I am a dog trainer for 25 yrs.
# text = You need to purchase what is called a shoulder point harness.
# text = This type of harness goes around the dogs chest and legs and has a clip for the leash up on the back of the dog in middle of shoulder blades.
# text = This way, he cannot reach the leash to chew it.
# text = When he swivels his head to go for it anyway, tell him sharp "UH UH" gently correct him with a small tug and continue your walk.
# text = Do this repeatedly and frequently and he will learn to walk on a leash.
# text = Patience is the key here.
# text = He is a young pup and will learn over time and consistency in his training.
# text = And always, always train with love and positive methods- never hit or harshly scold.
# text = Never train out of fear.
# text = You want your dog to admire you as his pack leader, not fear you.
# text = Good luck with your puppy!
# text = All the best.
# text = Put him in dog obedience school or call a professional dog trainer. :)
# text = why dont you get some treats that he loves and only give him them when he does something right.
# text = or, as i saw on embarrassing pets on tv, get a clicker type thing and treats as well.
# text = try to train him to heel, which means to walk round you before he needs to go on a leash, and he may do that.
# text = or you could even spray some scented spray on the leash and he will go for the scent and probably, if you act quick enough, will stay on the leash.

# text = which one out of these makes the best pet?
# text = a degu, a rat, a mouse, a hamster or a guinea pig?
# text = and why is the one a better pet?
# text = Get a guinea pig.
# text = I have a hamster, and mice and rats like to escape.
# text = The Guinea pig is better because its a lot larger than a hamster, rat, mouse, or degu.
# text = So if you lose him, he is easier to find, because smaller rodents just LOVE to escape from their cages.
# text = So my opinion is Guinea pigs.
# text = (plus they dont stink that bad)
# text = Depends on what you want in a pet, to be honest.
# text = Also depends on the space you have, how much time you can handle the pet, how much money you can spend, etc.
# text = I've had experience with all of those pets except Degus.
# text = My favorite would have to be the rat.
# text = They're incredibly social, highly trainable, and very clean.
# text = Mine learned to "go to the bathroom" only in their cages and loved to ride on my shoulder or hang out in my hoodie pouch.
# text = The only downside is they should be kept in pairs or trios and require a pretty large habitat.
# text = That means expense, space, and they require weekly cage cleaning.
# text = My second favorite would have to be the Guinea Pig - not quite as social with people as rats (at least mine wasn't) but more so than most hamsters or mice.
# text = Again, pairs or trios and pretty big living space.
# text = They, too, need weekly cage cleaning and can cost quite a bit.
# text = I could handle my mice, but they where skittish and preferred their cage.
# text = I've never met a hamster that didn't bite me.
# text = Never had/handled a Degu.
# text = Get a guinea pig.
# text = We have two.
# text = They are social and like to be handled.
# text = You have to have two because they don't do well alone.
# text = Make certain you get two females.
# text = Two males can fight and you definitely don't want babies!!
# text = Guinea pigs (also called cavies) are gentle creatures and are awake during the day and sleep at night.
# text = They will whistle when they hear you as an encouragement for you to give them a treat like leaf lettuce.
# text = They love leaf or romaine lettuce and tomatos, celery, cucumbers, carrots.
# text = Don't feed them broccoli, cauliflower, garlic, onions, head lettuce ....they are all too difficult for them to digest.
# text = Also they can't eat potatos, they are toxic for them.
# text = If you keep the cage clean they don't smell and you can buy spray on cleaser for them, just massage it into their coat and groom them.

# text = Need Advice!?

# text = This is my first experience and I have two six week old kittens right now and am at my wits end.
# text = I do not want to have to bring them back before they are eight weeks old but they are ruining my apartment.
# text = They track poop everywhere (most disgustingly my bed....), and am constantly trying to climb up everything, including my bare legs!
# text = My legs and hands are just full of scratches.
# text = I realize they are young and that cats do climb, but this is just ridiculous.
# text = My apartment also smells repulsive even though I am cleaning out their litter box at least once a day if not twice.
# text = Any suggestions and helpful hints to make this a more positive experience would be extremely appreciated.
# text = That's kind of the way it goes..lol.
# text = Limit them to one room with easy to clean flooring.
# text = If you have limited options, try the bathroom.
# text = Make sure there are plenty of litter boxes that are cleaned often.
# text = Depending on the batch of kittens, I will often have as many as one per kitten.
# text = They can produce a lot of waste and even scooping twice a day they can get messy.
# text = For some reason it takes them awhile to learn not to step in poop.
# text = Also if they have diarrhea, check in with your foster coordinator.
# text = They made need medication or deworming or something.
# text = They are testing out their claws and teeth.
# text = To some degree you can/should help teach them not to use their teeth and claws inappropriately.
# text = But in the meantime, highly recommend jeans and long sleeves anytime you'll be interacting with the kittens.
# text = Then take care of yourself.
# text = Get plenty of sleep and make sure you take time out to do some things you enjoy.
# text = Try visiting the kittens a few times a day for short periods of time.
# text = Try to go in there with the right frame of mind and enjoy them for what they are.
# text = If you still don't enjoy the kittens, see what other opportunities are available.
# text = They may need foster homes for adult cats in different situations.. sick, recovering from surgery, need a little socialization, etc.

# text = Generally they're not clawing and biting, they don't make nearly as much mess, they don't need nearly as much litterbox scooping, etc :)

# text = what r the requirements to apply for a delay birth certificate in canada?
# text = what r the evidentary requirements to apply for a delay birth certificate in canada?
# text = including fees and forms
# text = It depends on if you ever registered the birth.
# text = Some places do the registration right at the hospital....in some smaller places, you need to register your child's birth at the town hall/registrar's office.
# text = My first three children were born in Southern Ontario cities.
# text = The birth registration was done right in hospital.
# text = My last son, was born in Northern Ontario....
# text = I didn't know that I didn't register him in the ridiculous amount of paperwork I had filled out in the hospital and was supposed to go to city hall within 90 days.
# text = Two years later when I got around to filling for his birth certificate, I find out he was never registered.
# text = I had to call the Office of the Registrar General in Thunder Bay, have copies of the delayed registration form mailed out to me, as they don't have an online area for it yet, fill those out, send them away, then apply for his birth certificate.
# text = If you are just applying for a birth certificate for the first time, its simple to do it over the computer.
# text = For $56 you can even have it expedited and will get in three business days or your money back.
# text = This is in Ontario of course, the rates may be slightly different for other provinces/territories.
# text = You just need basic information, and answer a few questions like what hospital was the child born at/who was the doctor....
# text = they may then chose to ask you to bring more evidence, or just look up the record and hand you the certificate.
# text = You can probably do it all on-line.
# text = Start here if you were born in Ontario.
# text = http://www.ontario.ca/en/information_bundle/birthcertificates/119274.html
# text = If you were born elsewhere, start here.
# text = http://www.ontario.ca/en/information_bundle/birthcertificates/119275.html
# text = Good luck
# text = My parents didn't send for my birth certificate until I was 16 and needed it for summer employment.
# text = It was no problem to get PROVIDED the birth was registered in the first place.
# text = I add that in because there have been some people who have tried to claim citizenship by sending for their birth certificate when they were never really born in Canada or to Canadian parents.
# text = When a child is born in Canada the birth is registered before the baby can leave the hospital.
# text = As long as that was done you can send for it at any time.
# text = Each provincial government has a website that lists the process for that Province so depending upon where you were born you can google it.
# text = Royal Caribbean or Carnival cruise?
# text = ONLY IF YOU HAVE BEEN ON BOARD *BOTH* !!

# text = include which one had:
# text = -better food
# text = -more fun activities
# text = -more teens
# text = -AND JUST MORE STUFF YOU LIKED OVERALL
# text = please specify which royal or carnival ship (:
# text = Carnival and Royal Caribbean are two popular cruise lines that have strong followings.
# text = Some cruise aficionados refuse to sail on one or the other.
# text = Are there any major differences between them?
# text = Explore which cruise may fit your needs the best.
# text = For our comparison we sailed on two similar ships - the Carnival Liberty and the Royal Caribbean Mariner of the Seas.
# text = Itinerary Both ships go to Caribbean Islands like Jamaica, Grand Cayman, Cozumel, St. Thomas, the Bahamas and St. Martin / St. Maarten.

# text = How do you make your cat adjust to a new house?
# text = Me and my family are moving into a new house just outside a small town.
# text = We are currently living a mile from the town in a house surrounded by fields but the new house is beside a busy road.
# text = We have had the cat for 10 years and dont want to leave it.
# text = How could we make it settle in a new house.
# text = you are not just moving house - your cat is losing his territory.
# text = territory is very important to cats, and they are very nervous when they go into a new place - a new house could be full of predators, or unknown menaces - well at least he thinks so.
# text = you will need to give him only a small place to explore, so he can make it his territory, and feel safe there.
# text = then, he can have a place to retreat to when he feels scared.
# text = you will need to get his box and bowls, and whatever blanket and toys are his, and smell like home, and put him in a room.
# text = the room you sleep in is best (seeing you so relaxed that you are sleeping will send the message that everything is OK), but others will work just as well.
# text = close the door, and keep him in there for a week.
# text = he will feel much safer in that one room, than in a huge unknown house.
# text = he will explore the room, mark everything with his cheek, and try to make it feel like his territory.
# text = he will reassure himself that no other animal is in there, and that no other animal will come in - he is afraid that he is in someone else's territory when he is in a new house.
# text = in a week's time, he will have made it his, and will be getting more bored than afraid.
# text = let him out for half an hour, to explore.
# text = then put him back in.
# text = he will be freaked out, so going back to his territory will make him much happier.
# text = extend the time he is out each day, but for the first month, always put him in his room at night, so he feels safe to sleep.
# text = soon he will make the whole house his, but he needs that one safe place to start from.
# text = remember to visit with him while he is in the room, and tell him how good he is.
# text = remember to give him the time he needs to feel that the room is his - rush it, and he will be afraid of the whole house for a long time.
# text = he might even start peeing on things in fear.
# text = good luck with your new house and with his new territory!
# text = Let her explore when we moved my cat had to explore the entire house before she felt comfortable.
# text = In time though she/he will adjust. :)
# text = they just do it on their own.

# text = Is there any tricks I could use?
# text = Maybe get a book on training.
# text = You have to be in command at all times.
# text = There are ways to get your new dog used to the crate or going out.
# text = I would start with a leash.
# text = Put the leash on the dog and just walk around the crate a few times.
# text = Then take the leash off and do nothing else but that.
# text = Later do it again.
# text = When the dog is ok with this, then open the door and walk around the crate, leave the door open all the time.
# text = Put something fun inside.
# text = Let your dog go in when he wants to for no reason.
# text = Do not shut the door.
# text = Let him walk in and out for a few days.
# text = At some point he will feel ok with this and you can then close the door but not for long at all.
# text = Open the door and let him out and see how he acts.
# text = If you push it, it will never work.
# text = With going outside, put the leash on and just take him for a walk.
# text = He will learn to really like this.
# text = Potty outside will come at some point.
# text = Try obedience classes.
# text = Have patience with him, you just got him and who knows how he was treated before you brought him home.

# text = yoga and horses.....?
# text = I got a riding lesson today on one of my boss's fino horses and it made me realize just how unsteady my left leg is.
# text = I mentioned it to my boss and she said to start doing yoga.
# text = But there are just so many poses and programs!
# text = Any good poses or programs (I'm willing to buy a dvd as long as it is under $20) to help specifically with leg stabilization?
# text = I just have a few issues supporting my back and my left leg flops.
# text = Because I don't feel like spending over $20 on a freakin DVD
# text = I also have back problems that transfer into my legs.
# text = Here is what I do now and it really helps....
# text = When I first get on I take 1 leg and pull it back up to touch my butt with my heel and hold it there for 1 lap at a walk around a large dressage arena.
# text = Then the same thing with the other leg.
# text = Then 1 lap at a walk around the arena with both my legs pulled out as far as I can, so they are not touching the saddle.
# text = Then a lap doing scissors, one leg forward as far as I can and the other back, then switch legs.
# text = I'll also trot doing, down 2 beats, up one for a wile, then up 2 down 1 making sure the weight is going into the balls of my feet.
# text = If the weight is going into your heels (it throws your leg forward) put the stirrups up against the heel of your boot.
# text = Do a nice working trot, not a slow trot.
# text = All this will help you use both legs evenly, keep proper contact and use your wight correctly, to keep your leg in a good position.
# text = BTW you dont want your leg locked in place, it will move WITH the horse a bit.
# text = When I first started doing it I'd do it every day.
# text = Now I just do it once or twice a week or as needed.
# text = Now not only is my leg better, but my back is relaxing.
# text = what are you having problems with?
# text = i wouldn't bother with yoga i'd practice more with riding and fixing my problem, ride bareback, with no irons, theres also a way to ride on your knees?
# text = that help alot with your thigh muscles (bareback though)
# text = ya i really wouldn't bother with the yoga
# text = maybe a back brase will help, sometimes my back really gets to me and i've thought about getting one.
# text = with your leg flopping, just try putting all your weight in your heel and hangon with only your legs, holding my leg back helps me with flopping the more it's forward the more it flops :/ work your calf muscles, maybe try standing on the edge of your steps (on the ball of your foot) and balance to strengthen those muscles

# text = To answer your questions in order:
# text = 1) It is not normal for dogs to be vomiting, much less to have blood in it.
# text = However, if they have been vomiting numerous times, then the blood could be due to irritation of the stomach and intestines.
# text = He could also have Parvovirus, a GI foreign body, or any number of things.
# text = Did your vet take radiographs (x-rays)?
# text = 2) Your vet would not prescribe them if they didn't think it would be helpful.
# text = 3) If he shows no interest in water, then take him back to your vet.
# text = It could be due to nausea or any number of things.
# text = He could become severly dehydrated (especially if he continues to vomit and have diarrhea).
# text = From there you end up with electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to heart and kidney problems.
# text = And being dehydrated, vomiting, and having diarrhea just doesn't feel good.
# text = 4) Call your vet.
# text = They should have discussed a bland diet with you, including the frequency of feeding and how much to feed at each sitting.
# text = It sounds like your dog may benefit from being hospitalized, and put on IV fluids to help his hydration, administer the antibiotics IV, and to ensure that he starts to recover.
# text = You should ABSOLUTELY call your veterinarian back immediately to clarify anything you have questions about.
# text = They have seen your pet, and are most aware of his condition.
# text = No one online will be able to assist you more than your vet can.
# text = You need to ask your vet these questions.
# text = Boiled WHITE rice and boiled chicken breast.
# text = Bland food.
# text = NO SPICES!
# text = My vet told me when a dog is vomiting a lot, it could be a sign of obstruction.
# text = Did they do any x-rays?
# text = I don't know if vomiting blood is common with this ailment.
# text = You should call your vet now and ask them what is normal or not.

# text = why does my baby king snake refuse to eat?
# text = i have a baby eastern king snake.
# text = i have tried EVERYTHING i can to get him to eat but he refuses.
# text = he has a great environment, with water and lots of hiding places and a heat lamp.
# text = as far as i know, everything is as good as it can be where his aquarium is concerned.
# text = according to the vet, he is healthy and looks good.
# text = he has been going to the bathroom like he should.
# text = (i know that snakes that have problems going to the bathroom won't eat.)
# text = he has been drinking water (i am pretty sure he has been drinking it out of his bowl, but also i have been feeding him water and he doesn't ever give me a problem with that - i just stick his head near the water and he sucks it down.)
# text = i handle him every few days.
# text = he is feisty, as most king snakes are, but he is a very nice little guy - he never tries to bite or anything.
# text = i just love him to death.
# text = i don't know why he won't eat though!
# text = i have tried feeding him 5 or 6 live pinkies and 4 or 5 frozen (thawed) pinkies.
# text = i have never tried feeding him a pinky that was bigger around than he is.
# text = i have tried putting him in a small container and putting him in a dark place for an hour or so and he won't touch the pinky.
# text = he crawls on top of them but does not try to eat them.
# text = he doesn't seem to know that they are food.
# text = i have tried "braining" both live and dead pinkies, and bloodying them up to get his attention, but he doesn't care.
# text = i have tried dipping both live and thawed pinkies in tuna juice, and in used gerbil bedding.
# text = i have bought some long reptile feeding tweezers and have tried holding the pinky in front of the snake's face.
# text = he wont even try to bite.
# text = i am very discouraged and sad and i don't know what to do.
# text = he hasn't eaten in an entire month.
# text = i've only tried to feed him one at a time.
# text = he's just a tiny baby, about the width of a pencil.
# text = do babies this small hibernate?
# text = When you feed him how many pinkies do you feed him?
# text = If you feed him too many he could just not be hungry.
# text = If he doesn't seem interested in them at all I would say he's just not hungry.
# text = My boyfriend has one and when she's hungry she attacks the pinkie right away.
# text = They can smell it so i'm sure he knows what it is and just don't want it.
# text = Remember snakes can go awhile without eating.
# text = In the winter, they will usually go deep underground and enter a hibernation-like state called brumation, which is characterized by a slowed metabolism and reduced activity.
# text = King snakes sometimes stop eating, particularly during the cooler part of the year.
# text = They have a natural instinct to hibernate.
# text = If the snake is not pregnant or shedding, and its enclosure is properly equipped, a loss of appetite probably signals a beginning of hibernation.
# text = Hibernation is natural, and a necessity for snakes that are going to be bred.
# text = Another thing that can cause a king snake to stop eating is shedding.
# text = You can tell when your king snake is about to shed, because its eyes will get milky looking.
# text = Its body will be dull looking, too.
# text = In a few days the snake will begin to shed its skin.
# text = For example, some snakes will routinely go off their food in both the summer and winter, feeding mainly in spring and fall.
# text = It's natural and so long as you don't see any serious deterioration in their health is nothing to worry about.
# text = You see, some snakes for no obvious reason will simply go off their food.
# text = They're fit and healthy and their care is suitable.
# text = hope this helped.
# text = That's why it's good to have a python!
# text = It's twice my size and eats a rabbit once a month.
# text = are my two cats fighting or playing?
# text = how rough is too rough?
# text = help!?
# text = i have a 1 and a half year old male neutered cat and a new 2 month old spayed female kitten.
# text = the first night i brought her home i did the sniffing under the door thing and left it at that.
# text = the next day i let her out of the bedroom so they could check each other out, and the kitten hissed twice within the first 20 minutes of meeting each other and now she no longer hisses and they have been playing(chasing each other up and down the hall, rolling around on the ground and pawing at each other).
# text = only once it looked like my male cat was biting at her neck and then her stomach and she was meowing fairly loud and hissed once then he backed off and now they are fine.
# text = were they roughhouse playing?
# text = or were they actually fighting?
# text = he has been "biting" at her neck and stomach previously while they play without her meowing or anything so im wondering if he went a little to far that one time.
# text = any answers help!!!!!!
# text = you did not leave the new kitten in the room long enough.
# text = you need to do that for a least a week, or else this type of territorial fighting will happen.
# text = giving the new kitten her own small territory will help her to feel safe and will give her a place to go to when scared.
# text = right now, your male is fighting off an intruder, and he feels that all of the house is his.
# text = put her back in the room, and keep the door closed for a week.
# text = then let her out for ten minutes.
# text = make it fifteen the next day, then twenty, and so on.
# text = this will do two things; the new kitten will rub her cheek on the furniture in her room, making it her territory.
# text = she will start to calm down and feel safe - you can bet she doesn't now.
# text = she will be able to sleep without being afraid.
# text = as well, your male will be able to see that his territory is not threatened.
# text = when the door opens, he will get that the one room is hers, and he will be OK with that.
# text = the territory thing will be solved.
# text = your male is hurting her to put her in her place - biting her scruff is dominance and biting the belly is a move cats use when hunting - to pull the guts out of their prey.
# text = this is not good.
# text = give them time to set up their territories, and once you bring the new kitten out, pay a lot of attention to the male.
# text = you have brought someone else into his territory, and he needs to be reminded that you still love him, and support his claim to his space.
# text = that will help to reassure him, and he will be less aggressive with her.
# text = when they play fight, they don't hiss.
# text = if they hiss, they are not playing.
# text = if they bite, and one cries, you must separate them, and you must keep an eye on them.
# text = hissing is OK, unless they start to fight.
# text = if that happens, separate them, and give them time apart.
# text = putting the girl in her territory will make her feel less afraid, and she will relax.
# text = good luck!
# text = A hiss is basically a "get the f*ck away" sound.
# text = It means they've gone too far.
# text = When they start bleeding that means they're really fighting.
# text = If they're going kinda slow and like fake biting (not biting as hard as they can), and fake scratching (not hitting as hard as they can with their paws) then they're playing.
# text = I have two cats, and at first they hissed at each other because cats are very territorial, but now they do fight and play.
# text = The difference is when the cat hisses, that means they are annoyed and they want the other cat to go away.
# text = That means they are fighting.
# text = When they are just jumping at each other and their tails are wagging that means that they are playing.
# text = I can see how you get confused though. :)
# text = What was the goal for North Vietnam in the Tet offensive?
# text = When Johnson deployed troops in 1964 he was advised by the military it would take a half-million troops about ten years to pacify South Vietnam.
# text = He refused to believe them and ordered the military to win the war within two to three years (before the next election in 1968).
# text = He did not give them the number of troops they requested.
# text = This left Westmoreland with few options, so he adapted a Search and Destroy strategy instead of a Clear and Defend strategy which is, in the long run, the preferred method of pacifying an insurgency.
# text = Thing is, it worked.
# text = The ARVN was not having a big problem with the Local VC (the guerilla movement), they were being challenged by the Main Force VC (which was light infantry) and the North Vietnamese Army (NVA).
# text = When the Americans swept in with their Search and Destroy operations the Communists quickly leaned they could not stand up to the US firepower, and these regular troops were forced to flee the country and take sanctuary across the borders in Laos and Cambodia.
# text = All those sunny reports about the progress in Vietnam were correct, the Communists WERE being defeated.
# text = However, Johnson would not let the military cross the borders and clean out the Communist bases.
# text = He was warned that they were building up a huge Army and would eventually launch an attack, but he ignored his military advisers.
# text = The Communists agreed.
# text = They could not defeat the Americans.
# text = However, what they hoped to do during the Tet Offensive was to sneak past the Americans and attack the ARVN in the urban areas where they were deployed doing successful Clear and Defend operations.
# text = The Communists thought they could defeat the ARVN, cause the fall of the South Vietnamese government, and the people would than rally to the Communist cause and leave the Americans stranded in a sea of angry peasants.
# text = THAT WAS THE PLAN.
# text = What happened?
# text = The Americans detected the attempt to infiltrate the urban areas and were already redeploying troops from the rural areas.
# text = The ARVN rushed back from holiday leave and counterattacked.
# text = Within 24 hours every Communist assault had been defeated except in the ancient capital of Hue.
# text = The government did NOT fall.
# text = And the South Vietnamese people?
# text = When give the ultimate choice, they rallied…
# text = TO THE SOUTH VIETNAMESE GOVERNMENT….
# text = Tet was a huge military and political disaster for the Communists.
# text = They were chased back into Laos and Cambodia with the ARVN in hot pursuit.
# text = The people rejected their attempt to topple the government, and for all intents and purposes the US military (and the ARVN) handed Johnson the victory he had ordered them to achieve within the time-frame he ordered it.
# text = All he had to do for a complete victory was allow the military to go into Laos and Cambodia and finish off the shattered Communist forces.
# text = But Johnson was so obtuse he didn’t understand he had a victory when it was handed to him on a silver platter.
# text = Instead he pulled the military off, stopped the bombing of North Vietnam, withdrew from the presidential race, and spent the rest of his term in office trying to surrender to North Vietnam.
# text = They screwed up by not accepting his surrender when he offered it.
# text = The American people were NOT having any of it, and elected Richard Nixon to fix the mess LBJ had made (not to surrender like the antiwar movement was demanding).
# text = In the end Nixon kept his promise for “…peace with honor….”
# text = But that’s another question.
# text = To emancipate the south, but it was a serious failure.
# text = To make the war unpalatable to the American public.
# text = In that, they pretty much succeeded.
# text = Before Tet, the war was unpopular but tolerable to the majority of Americans in that the loss of American lives was seen as the cost of subduing the VC and NVA.
# text = Tet made it clear that the war was a long way from being over if the Americans thought they could preserve the South and that the North was perfectly willing to suffer great losses to continue their fight.
# text = There is a very good book on the subject that was written by General Vo Nguyen Giap.
# text = Try google to find the title if you would like to read it.
# text = Bearded dragon question...?
# text = I just bought a baby one yesterday.
# text = I have a basking spot lamp that says it is a double reflector that focuses 35% more light/heat and provides beneficial UVA rays important to the psycholical well-being of him.
# text = My question is does that mean it gives him not only the heat, but the "sun rays" he needs?
# text = I also was wondering how long should this light be on.
# text = The lady at pet smart said 4 hours, but on places on the net it says 10 to 12 hours.
# text = He's getting used to his new home, but hasn't eatin yet.
# text = I have bearded dragon juvenile food and freeze- dried crickets.
# text = Any advice would be greatly appreciated.
# text = Thank you for your time.
# text = Let me try to break this down as simply as I can: diurnal (active during the day time) reptiles like the bearded dragon require 3 types of "light," UVA, UVB, and heat.
# text = Any white light emitting light source will emit UVA, including heat bulbs, that's the easy one to provide for.
# text = UVB on the other hand can only be reproduced by a fluorescent source.
# text = UVB will always be a separate bulb from the heat lamp, unless you use a MVB (mercury vapor bulb) which is the only reptile use bulb that will emit both UVB and heat from one bulb.
# text = I highly recommend that you do not use coiled/compact UVB bulbs as they are known to cause severe eye damage and/or blindness in reptiles not to mention they have trouble maintaining UVB output over time.
# text = The long tube UVB bulbs are best, like Zoomed's Repsitun model: http://lllreptile.com/store/catalog/reptile-supplies/uvb-fluorescent-lights-mercury-vapor-bulbs/-/zoo-med-24-repti-sun-100-fluorescent-bulb/ Remember to replace UVB bulbs according to the manufacturers recommendation after which time the bulb will no longer produce UVB even if visible light still is.
# text = So, to answer your question, no, if you just have a bulb that says it produces UVA then you do not have "the sun's rays" that your bearded needs.
# text = You need to also provide a source a UVB lighting.
# text = The person at Petsmart is very wrong; in fact it is always a good idea to second guess what most pet store employees tell you; they don't have the best track record regarding giving reliable pet care info.
# text = UVB and basking temp (should be about 110 F for a baby, 95 F for an adult) should be available for 10 - 12 hours a day.
# text = Freeze dried food is not a good staple food source; you need to offer live feeder insects.
# text = Bearded dragons are sight hunters, they need to see the food move to trigger a feeding response, especially when they are babies.
# text = Live food is also higher in nutritional value than freeze dried.
# text = Crickets, silk worms, phoenix worms, and various feeder roaches, like red-lobster, turkistan, and dubia, are good example of staple insects to offer your bearded.
# text = Wax worms and meal worms should only be offered as treat items, for variety's sake.
# text = I would highly recommend that you read through some reliable bearded guides to make sure you have everything set up correctly:
# text = http://herp-info.webs.com/beardeddragon.htm
# text = http://www.beardeddragon.org/articles/caresheet/?page=1
# text = mm it depends on the size of his tank or cage or whatever you have him in..atleast as far as i'm concerned.
# text = if there are shady areas he can move to (for example a 3x5x4 tank with light on one side) then you can leave it on a full 12-14 hours, if its a small tank and he can't escape the light then 4-6 at most at a time though quite possibly 4-6 hours at a time twice a day.
# text = either way you also need to keep an eye on the temperature if you are using a dry fish tank as UV lights in my experience up the temperature significantly and without proper ventilation it can become an oven.
# text = as to what the light provides it gives UV rays..which is important for health in lizards as it is in humans.
# text = That lady at PetSmart is a disgrace to the rest of us PetSmart associates... sheesh.
# text = Yes, it gives him the "sun rays" necessary, that's what UVA is.
# text = And it should be on 10-12 hours, just like the sun would be up for 10-12 hours in his natural environment.
# text = As for the heat, just be sure to use a thermometer.
# text = Also, Beardies often do not eat food that is not moving, so its anyone's guess whether or not he'll touch the freeze-dried crickets or the processed food.
# text = I tell all my customers they can try it, but don't count on it.
# text = Also try green leafy veggies, like kale and spinach.
# text = Best of luck!
# text = Is a finch or a parakeet better?
# text = I am making a christmas list for my parents and i was going to ask for a bird and these are the affordable ones that i like, and i was wondering : which would not bite alot, and which are more fun to have as pets AND I NEED TO KNOW WHICH WOULD BE QUIETEST i honestly dont care but my family does !
# text = Please help me!
# text = oh and please say y one is better thx!!!!!!
# text = Hi there,
# text = Please choose the parakeet...
# text = Heres my reason.....
# text = I did the same thing that you did for christmas.
# text = I ended up getting a pair of zebra finches for christmas.
# text = At first it was all cool and all.
# text = After a couple of weeks I got tired of them.
# text = They are quite messy and you cannot hold or pet them.
# text = Ive tried to tame them and they just would not get tamed.
# text = They dont want to be held or touched.
# text = I want a bird that I can hold and do tricks.
# text = I still have them and they are doing well.
# text = A couple of months after I got parakeets/budgies.
# text = They are adorable they have beautiful colors and personality.
# text = I love them.
# text = First of all they are very tame.
# text = I tamed them in 4 days.
# text = They can do tricks and they arent messy.
# text = The whole family loves them.
# text = My parents even plays with them.
# text = They are a big part of our family.
# text = I hope this helps you with your decision.
# text = They are both about the same noise level.
# text = When choosing a parakeet look for a young one.
# text = (the younger the eaiser to tame) Look for clean smooth feathers, beak, and clean vent feathers (the feathers around the butt..dirty vent feathers means the bird is not healthy) Look for a dark eye with no circles (the older ones have a circle ring in their eyes).
# text = Look for a lot of stripes in their head that starts from the beak and goes back to the back fo the bird.
# text = the stripes are like hair the less stipes the older.
# text = (think of a balding man lol) Look for clean feathers.
# text = If you want a boy the cere (the nostrils piece above the beak) must be blue.
# text = The girl has either pink or brown.
# text = I would recommend that you get two parakeets.
# text = But get either one male and one female, or two males.
# text = Do not get two females.
# text = They sometimes dont get along (you know how some girls are lol hahahaahh but for real though, two girls tend to fight a lot.
# text = I have one yellow girl and a green and yellow boy.
# text = They are the best!
# text = If you choose to get a parakeet this is a trick that I used to tame them.
# text = However if you plan on getting one, then get more than one at the same time they need company.
# text = My mom told me how to tame them and I was very happy with the results.
# text = It took me 4 days to get the new one to be able to step on and eat out of my hand.
# text = These are the steps I used.
# text = Honestly they have worked for me twice with my parakeets.
# text = Hopefully they will work for you.
# text = 1) When you get the bird, place him or her or them in the cage.
# text = Leave them in there with food and water and such for about 2 hours.
# text = 2) Then place you hand in the cage.
# text = I took the cage and place it next to the couch.
# text = Then I sat on the couch, placed one hand in the cage, holding a millet spray.
# text = (this way the will associate your hand with food, and birds love food lol) Then I turned on the tv and watch.
# text = This way they will see that your hand is good and its not going to grab them or hurt them.
# text = Do this for about one hour.
# text = (you can take breaks if you have too) and repeat the steps after about 2 hours.
# text = 3) After about day 2, they will start to eating the millet spray from your hand.
# text = (do not take away the food dish from the birds, they will associate you as the person who takes away their food)....
# text = Then take your finger and place it under their belly, in front of their feet and say up.
# text = Push you finger to their feet gently and say up.
# text = ( the first couple of times they will fly all over the cage but as long as you dont jump back or screem they will get used to you) They will have no choice but to go on your finger.
# text = When they see that you arnt harming them, the will go up on your finger when you say up.
# text = 4) If they are not going up by now you just gotta keep trying and keep trying.
# text = Do not hit, yell, or harm them.
# text = You have patience.
# text = Dont give up!
# text = After a couple of weeks mines knows when I say shoulder it means ot go on my sholder, when I say up it means to jump up on my finger, when I say up and out it means up on my finger and out of the cage.
# text = and when I say go home it means to go in the cage.
# text = Good luck!
# text = They worked for me and I hope they worked for you!
# text = They are awesome!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
# text = And thats my reason why you should choose a parakeet over a finch.
# text = a parakeet is friendlier
# text = Parakeet.
# text = They are normally quiet and it is easy to take care of them.
# text = They are also friendly.
# text = I have a parakeet named Cookie . :P
# text = When is the best time to travel to Ireland?
# text = My sister and I would like to go to Ireland.
# text = I graduate in the spring, and so we'd like to go between then and winter.
# text = We don't want too many tourists, and since we'll both be out of school we can go anytime between the middle of June to early November.
# text = We don't want it to be too cold (not sure when exactly there fall is... or what the weather is really like there during our autumn months), but we don't feel like we need to go right in the middle of summer either.
# text = We're both in our early 20s and just wanting to explore the beautiful country while we're still young and before our lives start to get even crazier!
# text = Can anyone give me an idea of when the best time for us to go to Ireland would be?
# text = People do not go to Ireland on holiday for the weather, it is unpredictable.
# text = One thing you can be sure of about Irish weather is how little you can be sure of.
# text = It may be shirtsleeves and sunglasses in February, but winter woollies in March and even during the summer.
# text = And then there’s the rain.
# text = Ireland receives a lot of rain, with certain areas getting a soaking as many as 270 days of the year.
# text = County Kerry is the worst affected.
# text = The southeast is the driest, enjoying a more continental climate.
# text = The Irish weather works on the ‘four seasons in a day’ principle, which basic­ally means that you can’t predict a thing when it comes to the behaviour of the sky.
# text = Some basic assumptions, however, can be made.
# text = In summer, from May to July, the days are reasonably warm and – most importantly – very long: at the height of summer you won’t need to turn on lights until after 10pm.
# text = It is also peak tourist season, which means there are far more people just about everywhere but the most remote corners of the island, and prices are at their highest.
# text = Not surprisingly, most of the yearly festivals occur during these times so as to take advantage of the crowds and the more favourable weather.
# text = Spring (February to April) and Autumn (August to October) make good alternatives, although the country’s ever-growing popularity as a tourist destination can often blur the lines between mid- and high-season tourism.
# text = Still, you have a better chance of some peace and quiet, and the weather can be surprisingly better in April and September than in mid-July – again, it’s all part of the uncertainty principle.
# text = Spring festivities include the ever-popular St Patrick’s Festival.
# text = Although temperatures do not often venture below freezing, winter (December to February) can be brutal, for huge parts of the country – the west and northwest in particular.
# text = Crowds are at their thinnest, but many of the country’s tourist attractions and services close down in October and don’t reopen until Easter, which paradoxically leaves visitors with a more convincing taste of how Ireland is experienced by most of the Irish: it’s cold, grey and dark by 5pm, but there’s always a pub to escape into when the rain starts sheeting down.
# text = The thing to do is to bring the right clothing with you, clothes so you can layer up if it is cold and take off layers when it warms up.
# text = Waterproof clothing and footwear are essential plus an umbrella..
# text = As that famous Scotsman Billy Connolly says "there is no such thing as bad weather just the wrong clothes"
# text = Afraid I cannot be more helpful, it is really a case of pot luck, although as the weather is so changeable often a cold wet morning will turn into a lovely warm sunny afternoon and evening or visa versa.
# text = If you mean the Republic of Ireland (Dublin) then anytime.
# text = The summer there is much more mild than most of the US (are you coming from the US?).
# text = Their seasons are the same as all the countries in the Northern Hemisphere but I would suggest fall.
# text = It does get pretty cold in Ireland so going before winter is your best bet.
# text = September for example.
# text = Rent a car and spend a couple days outside of Dublin seeing the countryside and you will have the trip of a lifetime.
# text = To explore the beautiful countryside you will need to be old enough to hire a car because public transport is expensive & only goes as far as the main towns/cities, most rural places don't have a bus or train service.
# text = You could stay in a city & get a bus tour to say the Cliffs of Moher or Dingle peninsula but you will be with all the other tourists.
# text = By definition most tourists will go to the best places so you might have to put up with a few tourists along the way.
# text = Best weather the past couple of years has been around late April - late May but it can pour with rain for days on end at any time of the year so be prepared with waterproof jackets/boots etc.
# text = We only had a few sunny days this summer, barely 24C on a few occasions, more like 14C most days.
# text = We used our BBQ on precisely 4 occasions.
# text = Autumn is from mid August onwards as far as the weather goes if not officially according to the calender.
# text = The days start to shorten & it gets even wetter, windier & colder.
# text = We had frosts in October so I wouldn't advise visiting late in the year to be honest, Spring time is your best bet.
# text = You do realise it is quite expensive to visit Ireland?
# text = You are going to need a few thousand dollars saved up for flights, insurance, food, accommodation & spending money.
# text = Eating out in particular is quite expensive compared to America I believe.
# text = Golden Wonder KilliFish Breeding Help?
# text = I have 4 Golden Wonder Killifish.
# text = 1 of them is really colorful and is about 6cm long.
# text = 2 of them are kinda whitish and are about 4-5cm long.
# text = The last one is colourful too but it is about 4cm long.
# text = I feed them Flakes, and Live Earthworms uncut everyday.
# text = Can you tell me the whole process of breeding them and taking care of the babies?
# text = Thanks in Advance.
# text = Wow!
# text = If they are able to take earthworms uncut, that is really impressive!
# text = I aspire to your feeding regime, flakes early and something live later in the day.
# text = Worms (and Daphnia) are also rich in Lipids, substances important in forming eggs and growing young.
# text = I think that you understand that your largest and smallest golden wonders are males.
# text = If you would like more on sexing out Aplocheilus lineatus take a look at the discussion in the first source below.
# text = If you have plants in your tank.
# text = your lineatus are already spawning.
# text = If conditions are favorable (78-82 F) and the fish are obviously well fed as yours are, they will spawn.
# text = (I've even had a pair of killies leave eggs on a floating thermometer!
# text = If you wish to pick eggs make a acrylic spawning mop.
# text = Checkout the second source.
# text = I prefer darker colors because I can see their eggs ,more easily and the fish look better next to them.
# text = Use a well rinsed medicine vial, a cork, new fishing bobber or even a piece of non-crumbly styrofoam to float them.
# text = There are a couple ways one could spawn lineatus - mop spawning & water incubating them for two weeks, picking eggs from a mop & putting them in a tray of treated, seasoned water or setting up the parents in a planted tank & moving them so the fry can hatch out there.
# text = If you have the room to separate the male(s) & females(s),& feed them well on live foods, (assuming that you are doing weekly 50% water changes) when you put them together they will leave a lot more eggs.
# text = Just making up examples, but if a pair is constantly together, they may lay 10-15 eggs a day.
# text = With extra blackworms and maybe frozen (defrosted, rinsed) frozen foods earlier in the day, they may leave 30-40 eggs at a time.
# text = Separated and feed extremely nourishing stuff, they may produce more.
# text = Separating a pair some time before a show (killies are usually shown & judged & often sold as pairs) will encourage them to court and show their best colors.
# text = They also start the day with no nicks or dings in their fins.
# text = The water changes help with that too.
# text = You also may need to treat the incubation water.
# text = The chlorine and ammonia (choramine) are not good for the eggs.
# text = Ironically sometimes it is wise to leave the newly picked eggs in fresh tap water with some chlorination to kill microscopic critters that ride in with the eggs.
# text = THEN put the eggs in water treated a couple of days before with a water treatment and left open to "breathe".
# text = Leaving a jar with a dozen black worms in it will sate the adult's desire for snacks and they are more likely to leave fry or eggs alone.
# text = If a pair isn't leaving eggs... check the following:
# text = 1. Is a tank mate (such as another female killie or a Cory or large snails) rating the eggs?
# text = 2. Have we kept up with partial water changes?
# text = 3. Is there too much mineral in the water?
# text = Aplo. lineatus are wide-spread over southern India.
# text = That indicates that they thrive in different water chemistries.
# text = Still if you can get your pet shop to do a hardness or TDS (total Dissolved Solids) test, that may give you a hint.
# text = Winging it a little here, a hardness of 100 to nearly 200 PPM (parts per million) or 5.8 to 10.6 DH should be fine for gardneri.
# text = TDS meters (the thrifty aquarist's hardness meter can be used if one has seen one of your municipal water department's annual reports.
# text = They include a number of minerals there and you can figure out what percentage of that would be your hardness minerals (calcium, magnesium and iron).
# text = A number of minerals are not of much consequence.
# text = However if there is a high level of sodium chloride (common salt) that can break down the chorion (shell) around the egg and allow critters to get in and eat the yoke and embryo.)
# text = Ironically sometimes it is wise to newly picked eggs in fresh tap water with some chlorination to kill microscopic critters that ride in with the eggs.
# text = THEN put the eggs in water treated a couple of days before with a water treatment and left open to "breathe".
# text = If you get eggs in the mail in a medicine vial, that is fine.
# text = But get the eggs out, maybe rinsed in fresh tap water and then into the incubation water.
# text = In time the eggs can suffocate in the shipping container.
# text = After a number of people began complaining about "mystery deaths"among incubating eggs, some of the more advanced killie people began suggesting that after 7-8 days of incubation, one should do a 100% water change - as the eggs develop, they do release waste material.
# text = Another problem is that sometimes bad eggs will fungus and the fungus will spread out and kill all the eggs.
# text = Some people put in a very dilute Acriflaven solution to slow down the fungus, so one can take white eggs out with a pipette or eyedropper.
# text = Other will add a drop of Methylene blue.
# text = If an egg turns blue, it had died and then became dyed as the outer membrane broke down.
# text = Get those out ASAP too.
# text = Hope there is useful grist for the mill here.
